DOC.HEAD: New Threats to Foreigners; Bush Acknowledges They Are Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to ADD Amnesty International report on abuses, minor editing. Picks up graf 17 pvs, `American military...' Edits thereafter to trim.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DUB01,LON4,DUB03,AMM1
DOC.TEXT: Iraq announced Monday it had carried out a plan to move Western hostages to vital military installations to deter any U.S. attack and warned its people not to try to hide any of the thousands of foreigners trapped in the country. With the United State building up its armed forces in Saudi Arabia and blocking Iraqi ports with an armada of ships, the Iraqi regime moved to use the Westerners as human shields. For the first time, President Bush publicly referred to the 3,000 Americans and the other Western captives as hostages. ``Whatever these innocent people are called, they are in fact hostages,'' he said in Baltimore. He demanded their release. In a blow to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, Iran announced Monday that it will abide by a U.N. resolution ordering economic sanctions against Iraq. This followed Saddam's moves last week to make peace with Iran, his longtime enemy, so as to better focus on his confrontation with the West. Late Monday, the U.N. Security Council met informally to pursue possible U.N. action to enforce its embargo of Iraq. Diplomats entering the meeting carried draft papers that called for members to use ``all necessary action'' to enforce the embargo. The meeting occurred as an Iraqi tanker, one of two tankers fired on Saturday by U.S. ships, was reported about to enter Yemeni waters. The official Iraqi News Agency quoted a spokesman for Baghdad's National Council, or parliament, as saying: ``Iraq's foreign guests have been in fact moved to all vital and military installations. They have been provided with all modern facilities and they are all in good physical condition.'' It did not say how many foreigners were moved or give other details. In Washington, the State Department reported that 12-14 Americans and some other foreigners were taken from their Kuwait hotels and moved to undisclosed locations. A U.S. official said the Americans included both men and women, adding, ``they may be going to Baghdad.'' Earlier Monday, Saddam's government informed diplomats they had until Friday to close their missions in Kuwait or lose their special status. Several countries said they had no plans to close their embassies. They included Austria, Britain, Denmark, Finland, France, Italy, Spain, Sweden, the Soviet Union and West Germany. In other developments Monday: _Israel said it will allow Egyptians fleeing Iraq and Kuwait to travel through the Jewish state on their way home, Israeli TV said. _A U.S. Embassy spokesman said in Amman that American citizens in Jordan were being advised to leave on a ``voluntary basis.'' _An NBC News-Wall Street Journal poll conducted over the weekend found that 72 percent of those surveyed approved of how Bush is handling the crisis. Seventy percent said they approve of the decision to send military forces to Saudi Arabia and the gulf. The telephone poll had a margin of error of four percent, NBC said. _Jane's Defense Weekly in London reported that an Iraqi freighter is heading to Jordan with 17 East German-made armored bridgelayers. The bridgelayers are capable of crossing difficult terrain because it has a 66-foot-long scissor-like bridge. Iraq received seven last year in an earlier deal, the magazine said. _Amnesty International demanded the immediate release of all foreigners detained in Iraq and Kuwait, and protested reported human rights abuses by Iraqi troops in Kuwait. _American military cargo planes are being allowed to operate from the United Arab Emirates, becoming the second gulf nation to accept foreign troops in response to the Iraq crisis, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said. _In New York, wholesale unleaded gasoline prices surged over the $1 mark for the first time, boosted by the belief among traders that the Mideast crisis will persist and continue creating tight supplies. _In Hampton, Va., 20 F-117A Stealth fighters left Langley Air Force base for deployment in the Middle East. _Col. Moammar Gadhafi criticized both Iraq and the United States for provocative actions in the Mideast and threatened to withdraw Libya from the United Nations. In warning their own people about harboring foreigners, Iraqi authorities said Monday that anyone doing so faced the ``severest punishment,'' according to Iraqi radio. The report said the rule applied to Iraq's ``entire administrative border,'' apparently including Kuwait. Iraq invaded the small emirate Aug. 2 after accusing it of cheating on OPEC production quotas, thus driving down world oil prices and depriving Iraq of billions of dollars in revenue. Iraq declared four days later that it had annexed Kuwait and began referring to it as a city in southern Iraq. Two senior U.N. officials went to Baghdad to press for release of foreigners held in Kuwait and Iraq. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said Saddam asked that the envoys be sent. Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet foreign minister, appealed to a visiting Iraqi deputy premier in Moscow to free the foreigners. Tass said he ``expressed satisfaction'' to Saadoun Hammadi that Soviet citizens were allowed to leave and asked for ``a similar decision in relation to citizens of other states.'' OPEC said there was not enough support among members to call an emergency meeting on Saudi Arabia's request for increased output to make up the shortage of 5 million barrels a day caused by the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti production. Hisham Nazer, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, said Saturday his country would increase production by up to 2 million barrels a day with or without support from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Ship radios crackled Monday with the sounds of U.S. warships challenging nearly every commercial vessel in the southern Persian Gulf, but no Iraqi vessels were found in the area, shipping sources reported. Addressing the national Veterals of Foreign Wars convention in Baltimore, Bush said: ``We have been reluctant to use the term hostage. But when Saddam Hussein specifically offers to trade the freedom of those citizens of many nations he holds against their will in return for concessions, there can be little doubt that whatever these innocent people are called, they are in fact hostages. ``And I want there to be no misunderstanding. I will hold the government of Iraq responsible for the safety and well-being of American citizens being held against their will.'' On Sunday, Saddam offered to release foreigners if the United States withdrew its forces from the Persian Gulf region and promised to lift the economic embargo. U.S. officials refused. He said later he would free citizens of nations that remained neutral in the conflict, including those of Austria, Switzerland, Sweden, Finland and Portugal. They account for only about 600 of the 21,000 foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait. Iraq said Monday that Indonesian and some Argentines would be allowed to leave. China's official news agency, Xinhua, said the first group of 97 Chinese was leaving and Tass said 122 Soviet citizens crossed into Jordan on Monday, 346 had reached the border and only 188 remain in Kuwait. Foreign Minister Saud al-Faisal of Saudi Arabia visited Damascus on Monday to discuss the gulf crisis with Syrian leaders. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said Iraqi soldiers continued withdrawing from occupied Iranian territory, freeing thousands of troops to face U.S. forces. Iraq and Iran also are repatriating prisoners from their eight-year war, which ended with a cease-fire in August of 1988. Despite their newly established peace, however, Iran informed Perez de Cuellar that as a U.N. member, it would go along with the sanctions ordered by the world body, IRNA reported. The United States is pouring military personnel into Saudi Arabia, and U.S. officials have said the deployment could reach 200,000. American warships and aircraft carriers are stationed in and near the Persian Gulf. Other Western and Arab countries have contributed troops to the growing multinational force, but it is predominantly American.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Hear Closing Arguments in Contra Supply Case
DOC.TEXT: Contra supplier Eugene Hasenfus and a fellow courier killed during a failed mission in Nicaragua had no formal contract and knew the risks of the covert flight, defense attorneys said Monday during closing arguments. But lawyers for Hasenfus and the family of Wallace Sawyer Jr. say the men deserve to be ``taken care of'' for working on behalf of a network, approved by the White House, to support the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. Jury deliberations were scheduled to begin Tuesday in the five-week civil trial, which was severely limited after U.S. District Judge C. Clyde Atkins threw out a major portion of the claims last week. All that remains to consider are some financial issues such as whether Hasenfus is due back pay and if Sawyer's family can collect death benefits from Gen. Richard Secord and Miami-based Southern Air Transport. Atkins ruled Friday that jurors cannot consider damages for mental stress suffered by Hasenfus or his wife, Sally, after the plane was shot down by Sandinista troops in October 1986. Hasenfus of Marinette, Wis., was the sole survivor of the crash. He was detained for three months before being returned to the United States. The judge also removed from the case claims seeking punitive damages and allegations the aircraft was unsafe. Thomas Spencer, an attorney for Secord, said his client did not have the authority to make a contract with Hasenfus or Sawyer, of Magnolia, Ark., who went by the nickname ``Buzz.'' ``My client didn't contribute to the death of Buzz Sawyer or the harm to Gene Hasenfus,'' said Spencer. ``The White House called him and asked to help with the resupply operation.'' Southern Air attorney Robert Beckman said the carrier was just one of several companies involved flights to supply the U.S.-backed Contra rebels, who were fighting the Marxist Sandinista government of Nicaragua. ``Hasenfus could just as well brought suit against the maker of the parachute that saved his life,'' he said. Defense attorney Brian Strange told the jury Hasenfus and his wife should at least be reimbursed for expenses connected to Hasenfus' legal battle in Nicaragua. ``They were told their families would be taken care of and then the defense comes before you and says, `Not us,''' said Strange. Secord helped former National Security Council aide Oliver North organize the Contra supply network. Secord was sentenced to two years' probation after pleading guilty to lying to Congress about his role in the Iran-Contra affair.

DOC.HEAD: Groups Say Test Discriminates Against Non-Hearing
DOC.TEXT: An advocacy group for the deaf sued state education officials Monday, alleging the state's teacher certification test discriminates against deaf people. The lawsuit filed in Travis County state district court is the first challenge in the nation by deaf educators of a teacher certification exam, the group said. One of the plaintiffs, Nancy Mumme, 32, said the test asks questions about how to instruct students on the differences in the sound of certain letters. ``How am I supposed to be identifying a sound?'' Ms. Mumme said in sign language through an interpreter. The lawsuit against the Texas Education Agency and State Board of Education says deaf people who want to become teachers shouldn't have to take the test until it has been adjusted. The lawsuit was filed by the Texas Association of the Deaf and Ms. Mumme. Jorjanna Price, a spokeswoman for the education agency, said lawyers for the agency had yet to see the lawsuit. She said Education Commissioner W.N. Kirby has met with deaf educators. ``He said he wanted to look into the test matter,'' Ms. Price said. Ms. Mumme, who has a Maryland teaching certificate, failed the Texas test twice. Despite favorable evaluations and performance as a classroom teacher she was demoted last year and her contract at the Texas School for the Deaf has been canceled for this school year, according to the lawsuit. ``I have been very, very frustrated. I cried and cried after I got my test results back,'' she said in an emotional statement at a news conference.

DOC.HEAD: Jeffersonian Idea Brings Power to Powerless in Rural South
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A quiet revolution is under way in dozens of rural Southern counties where people historically unrepresented are nurturing a shadow government to help them take ``the last step up from slavery.'' This alternative power structure, conceived by a descendant of slaves and based on Thomas Jefferson's ideas, is called simply ``the assembly.'' It has brought millions of dollars' worth of new schools, miles of paved roads and, most important to the assembly members, who are mostly black, a voice that can no longer be ignored. In Appomattox County, gospel songfests and candy sales helped the local assembly raise $65,000, purchase six acres and clear the land for a community center. ``We were always going from one place to another, having our meetings,'' said Milton Chambers, the 36-year-old assembly president, a foundry worker who lives three miles from the spot where the Civil War ended 125 years ago. ``To have a building to call our own,'' he said, members gladly sacrificed, some contributing hundreds of dollars. ``The only way to control our destiny,'' he said, ``is to be able to turn on and cut off the lights when we want to.'' In a phrase, he was stating the goal and purpose of the 40-odd assemblies in Virginia and other Southern states: organization for self-help and representation. ``I'll say it 'til I die, if you give people something, you'll build dependency,'' said Don Anderson, a black former congressional committee lawyer who created the assembly system. ``But if you just organize the voluntarism, they'll do it themselves. ... ``And once it's done it's like magic.'' For 22 years, Anderson has been trying to work that magic through his Washington, D.C.-based National Association for the Southern Poor. With a staff of 10 and an annual budget of nearly $500,000, mostly from individual donors and foundations, its goal is to create assemblies in 258 Southern counties with low incomes and black populations of about 30 percent to 80 percent. Anderson has written that his aim was to give these people ``a vehicle for solving their problems, and for taking the last step up from slavery.'' Most assemblies are in Virginia and North Carolina, but new ones are being formed in Georgia and South Carolina and plans are to expand to Alabama, Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas and Tennessee. To spread his self-help concept across the region, Anderson touts assemblies' accomplishments to date: the paving of 20 miles of roads in black areas of Washington County, N.C.; job training for the hardcore unemployed in Portsmouth, Va.; $2.5 million in water line extensions and home renovations through federal grants in Jones County, N.C.; and many other projects. The assemblies operate within ``a very refined structure, based on Jefferson's idea of ward republics,'' Anderson explained. ``We go into a county and divide it up into manageable groups of 50 people each,'' the equivalent of Jefferson's wards, Anderson said. ``And these are represented in a central decision-making body called the assembly.'' To establish an assembly, Anderson's organizers usually spend two months locating community leaders and bringing them together in preliminary meetings. Anderson, who attends a final organizational gathering, said it costs $18,000 on average to organize a county. Procedurally, the assembly is ``a very accurate copy of the British House of Commons,'' said Anderson, who holds a degree from the London School of Economics. At a recent meeting of the Assembly of Charlotte County, Va., in a muggy school auditorium, members who were dressed as if for church closely followed parliamentary rules _ calling ``questions'' printed on an agenda named the Order Paper, rising whenever addressing the group, and directing all comments to the Speaker. The difference is that at the House of Commons, they don't serve fried chicken and biscuits beforehand. Assembly members must be at least 18 and must be registered voters. Although the groups are non-partisan, voter registration often is a first-priority project. The relationship between the assembly and local elected officials varies. ``I see it as a system to assist the government that's in place,'' said Andrew Murray, who heads the assembly in Caswell County, N.C. Others see it as a watchdog organization. The Appomattox assembly and others have appointed members to monitor county supervisor and school board meetings. In Surry County, Va., three assembly members sit on the five-member county Board of Supervisors. ``So all the issues that come up in the assembly are heard by members that can actually vote on them,'' said Surry Assembly President Thomas Hardy, who also chairs the county planning commission. Surry's assembly, founded 21 years ago, is the oldest and most successful. Hardy proudly showed off its projects to a reporter. Some came about through grants the group applied for, some through its pressure on local officials: _ A neat, 50-unit subsidized apartment complex, built after the assembly decried the falling-down, tin-roofed shacks that many lived in, is to be expanded. _ A $1 million medical clinic put up by the assembly with foundation grants has visiting specialists and is working to find full-time doctors. _ A handsome $540,000 recreation center hums with activity: a summer day camp program for schoolchildren, meetings of senior citizens, civic group gatherings, even wedding receptions. As everyone benefits from the improvements, relations between the races have improved, Hardy said. A white official, Sheriff W.C. Andrews, agreed. ``It's a lot of times that maybe we don't see eye to eye,'' the sheriff said. ``But we get together and try to work things out.'' Of all the changes the assembly has brought in Surry, a farming county where pork, peanuts and pines are grown, Hardy is proudest of the schools. Before the assembly started its work with a house-by-house voter registration drive that made clear the black majority, the schools ``were in a desperate condition,'' he said. At the high school, ``We didn't have a gymnasium; we didn't have a cafeteria.'' After integration was ordered, all but nine white students left the 1,300-student district for private schools, according to a 1971 news story. Only two of the district's 60 teachers were white, but whites held all but one seat on the school board. Now, there's a brand new $1 million elementary school, a $4 million high school. Surry's per capita student spending is $5,633, nearly the highest in Virginia. And although the assembly sometimes criticizes the black superintendent, ``He has been successful in working to bring at least 80 percent of the white children back,'' Hardy said. The black-white ratio among students is now 73 percent to 27 percent, according to Martha Rollings, assistant to the superintendent for instruction. In the general population, about six out of 10 people are black, Hardy said. There are 58 black teachers, 34 white. Three blacks and two whites sit on the school board. Improvement in standardized test scores has been dramatic. For example, Surry eighth graders ranked in the eighth percentile nationally in reading in 1979. Now they're at the 49th _ ``within reach,'' Ms. Rollings said, of the national average 50th percentile. ``We're working on it,'' she added. Anderson knows the statistics and the faces they represent. ``You don't have to think of symbolic changes,'' he said. ``You can transform a whole community.''

DOC.HEAD: Some Are, Experts Say, but Not Like Savings and Loans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: While politicians loudly ask who's to blame for the savings and loan mess, regulators and analysts are quietly asking a much more urgent question: Is commercial banking headed for disaster too? ``The answer is yes,'' said economist R. Dan Brumbaugh of Stanford University. ``We're already there.'' He believes that more banks would be declared insolvent _ and the government fund protecting $2.6 trillion in deposits at 12,500 banks would be broke _ if regulators stopped using outmoded accounting methods to determine when a bank has failed. No, said L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., which, through separate funds, guarantees both bank and thrift deposits up to $100,000 per account. ``We will be able ... to handle any failures we can currently foresee,'' he said. He vigorously disputes Brumbaugh's methodology and conclusions. But from another perspective, the two sides are not far apart. They are arguing about how bad the condition of the banking system is, not whether it is in bad or good shape. The bank insurance fund is ``in a very much stressed position,'' Seidman conceded at a recent Senate hearing. Because bank deposits are nearly triple the $930 billion held by savings institutions, the bank insurance fund's health has always been potentially even more critical than the condition of the now-bankrupt Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. The funds were established half a century ago to restore confidence in the nation's financial system after a wave of bank and S&L failures swept the nation during the Depression, wiping out the savings of thousands of Americans. For decades, both funds thrived, supported by insurance premiums paid by member institutions. But so many savings and loans failed during the 1980s that taxpayers had to rescue the S&L fund at a cost now estimated as high as $500 billion over 40 years _ $2,000 for every man, woman and child in the nation. The bank fund has so far been able to handle bank failures, though the balance has been dropping for three years now. And if it falls to zero in the 1990s, taxpayers would have to bail out banks, too. The bank fund, which ended 1987 with $18.3 billion, lost $4.24 billion in 1988, when bank failures hit a post-Depression high of 221. That was its first decline ever. When another 207 banks failed last year, it lost an additional $851 million. Failures remain high in 1990 _ 121 through Aug. 16 _ and Seidman has estimated the fund will lose around $2 billion, reducing it to near $11 billion. A key ratio measuring the fund's health has been deteriorating even longer. In 1963, the FDIC had $1.50 for every $100 in deposits. By 1981, that had gradually eroded to $1.24. As failures soared during the 1980s, the ratio plummeted. After this year's loss, Seidman estimates it will be between 50 cents and 60 cents. Last week, his board proposed emergency action to battle the decline, preliminarily endorsing a 62-percent increase in the insurance premium banks pay. It is the maximum increase allowed by law. The move would increase the FDIC's premium income from $2.8 billion in 1990 to $4.8 billion in 1991. Much of the added expense will be passed on to depositors through higher fees for checking accounts and other services. Analysts, however, say the added income would provide only a little extra protection for taxpayers should soaring oil prices trigger a recession and another wave of bank failures. ``The wild card right now in all these forecasts is Iraq,'' said economist Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution, a Washington-based, liberal think tank. ``Clearly, right now the fund is skating on the edge. It is conceivable that it could get by if the economy escapes a recession and if oil prices stabilize in the low- to mid-$20s'' a barrel, he said. ``However, Iraq could change all that.'' If the recession was deep, bank troubles in the 1990s could dwarf those of the 1980s, which occurred despite an unprecedented eight years of expansion in the national economy. An additional worry is that bank regulators, like S&L regulators before them, would be tempted to allow insolvent banks to remain open. Then, with federal insurance guaranteeing their deposits, the banks would have every motive to take wild risks. If they win, they avoid bankruptcy. If they lose, taxpayers pay. A few analysts, like Brumbaugh, contend that is already happening. ``The FDIC's behavior is deja vu all over again and it is irresponsible,'' he said. However, others believe that, with the lesson of the S&L mess still fresh, bank regulators would appeal for taxpayer assistance much earlier and Congress would respond more quickly. Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va., who made his reputation with early predictions of disaster for the savings and loan fund, said comparisons between banks and S&Ls are overdone. ``Banks are fundamentally sounder institutions. ... And, basically, the FDIC has not been sweeping the problems under the rug to the extent that the (thrift regulators) were,'' he said. The root of the S&L crisis was planted when the institutions were created. They borrowed deposits short-term and lent the money long-term to home buyers. When inflation pushed interest rates past 20 percent they had to pay more interest on their deposits than they were earning on their mortgages. Cures applied in the early `80s _ expansion into new lending areas coupled with lax oversight _ only worsened the problem. The roots of banking's woes are different, but still formidable. In the 1970s, the nation's largest banks had lent billions of dollars to Third World countries, who by the 1980s were defaulting. By the mid-80s, small farm banks began collapsing, along with agriculture commodity and farm land prices. Then came the drop in oil prices, triggering a collapse in real estate values in the Southwest. Now, real estate problems have spread to the Northeast and are threatening the Southeast, Southern California and even a few Midwestern cities. Longer-term, innovations in the financial system are eroding banks' profitability. Their best deposit customers have been lured to money market mutual funds. Their largest and most credit-worthy borrowers raise money by issuing commercial paper, a service that banks are substantially barred from delivering along with other securities underwriting. Banks' defenders point out that the industry earned a record $24.8 billion in 1988 and a respectable $15.7 billion in 1989. Critics, however, say that does little to reduce the potential for disaster. Although commercial banks collectively earned $6.2 billion in the first three months of this year, 10 percent of them lost money and 1,058 were considered ``problem'' institutions by the FDIC. ``Ten percent can easily send you under. Deep under,'' Litan said. ``The 10 percent of the banks that are unprofitable ... hold roughly the same assets that the open, but insolvent thrifts held in the mid-1980s. We saw what they could do.''

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Replaces Soccer as Cafe Topic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Arabs at seafront coffee shops have stopped talking about soccer and turned their attention to the Persian Gulf crisis and the American role in the Middle East. Puffing at water pipes in the cafes of this island state that has become a banking and business center, Arabs from Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and elsewhere gather to endlessly discuss the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the American response and where it all will lead. ``America's image in the Arab world is 70 percent bright these days,'' merchant Abdullah Ahmed suggested. ``But this will not remain so in the fullness of tie of pro-Israeli America will surface again, once the Kuwait crisis is over.'' Listeners in white dishidasha gowns and kaffiyeh headgear nodded approval.me. The ugly fac ``Don't tell me that (Saudi Arabian king) Fahd brought the Americans to the Persian Gulf waters and the sacred land,'' said one. ``Not at all,'' Ahmed responded. ``Saddam did. But, in the thick fog of Arab politics, we'll hear many different versions to the same story. Truth can easily be camouflaged.'' Lawyer Mohammed Adel interjected loudly: ``No, no, no. First of all, let's define the basic elements of our discussion, to gain clarity and avoid moving i ``Four, all supposed warlike scenarios are frightening and lots of innocent blood might be shed and someone will likely be blamed for this. Besides, if Israel gets involved in any military action against Saddam, all his Arab adversaries would look very, very bad and his sins be forgotten.'' A number of religious men, fingering worry beads, shouted expressions of disapproval. One mosque keeper interjected, ``We go by the book of Allah and say that Fahd is struggling with a clean heart while Saddam resists with a dirty mind.'' The loudspeaker blared an Egyptian song about Arab unity. Garage owner Ali Juma had to raise his voice when he said ``the Kuwaitis may have have been money-minded, but it is their money anyway and no one has any right to blame them for investing it in whatever manner they deem best for themselves.'' Many people in the gulf consider Kuwaitis ``money-minded,'' and they are widely considered clever investors and sharp traders. Abdullah Ahmed clapped, and the waiter replaced the burned out tobacco in his water pipe. Inhaling smoke he said: ``I believe the real crisis is yet to unfold. What we see now is merely a spark. The harm is done, regardless of how the crisis will be ended.'' The garage man said, ``Saddam's mistake rests really with the enormity of his overblown reaction to Kuwait's economic affronts. Instead of pulling Kuwaiti ears he punched into their houses, raped their women, deflowered their daughters, and looted their jewelry.'' ``And I say the real crisis will unfold when the poor Arabs begin to demand financial help from the rich Arabs,'' said Ahmed, ``sometimes peacefully and sometimes by force.'' And Saddam? ``One eventuality envisions the Iraqi people brightening their image and getting rid of Saddam,'' said Ahmed. But he also spoke of an alternative that saw an ``anti-Iraq economic blockade persisting and Saddam's machinations succeeding in stirring the Arab masses against one government or another, thus giving him a broader popularity and support.'' Another posibility, he said, was that ``the Americans might provoke a fight and usher in the Israelis, which means Saddam would die and become an Arab martyr.'' The lawyer summed it up. ``I told you, the future is bleak,'' he said. ``There are several options, the sweetest of which is bitter.''

DOC.HEAD: Text of Saddam's Message To The Families of Stranded Westerners
DOC.TEXT: Following are excerpts of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's message Sunday to the families of Westerners stranded in Kuwait and Iraq. His remarks were carried by the official Iraqi media and translated by The Associated Press: Ladies and gentlemen; dear children: I know that you are pained because your relatives are not allowed to leave Iraq. I am just as pained as you are. I am fully convinced that the speaker and members of the Iraqi National Council are also pained and so are all Iraqis and Arabs. ... We are all sorry for what happened. It was not of our own making, but the outcome of the will of certain people who acted arbitrarily and deviated from the will and teachings of God. The responsibility for all this lies directly with U.S. administration and the British government. ... Gentlemen, you may not know that this country whose rulers concocted plots (Kuwait) was part of Iraq until 1913 and that Iraq did not recognize it until the 1960s; that the Iraqi prime minister issued a decision in 1961 annexing Kuwait, turning it once again into a district linked to Al-basrah, and appointing its sheikh as governor as was the case before World War I. ... Why do the U.S. president and the British prime minister want to starve the Iraqi people to death? Cursed be what they are doing. What have the Iraqi people done other than unite themselves and the families that were divided by circumstances in Iraq and Kuwait, defend themselves, and help oust the backward Kuwaiti sheikh, whose only concern was collecting money and women? Why are they imposing a siege on Iraq to kill the babies and elderly as well as those who cannot get food and medicine. ... Why are they massing naval fleets, squadrons of planes, and ground forces with which they want to attack Iraq?... As it is clear to you, our homeland is being threatened by America and Britain and those frustrated and humiliated ones involved with them. Our people are exposed to a grave danger. ... It has been decided that preventing the foreigners from traveling outside Iraq ... will open a deep dialogue with the peoples of those countries and those who represent them, and with the administrations of those countries, to find a peaceful solution and avert a catastrophe in the region, and maybe the whole world. ... The presence of the foreigners with the Iraqi families at vital targets might prevent an attack. ... We are seeking to deter the harm of death, murder, and starvation resulting from the U.S. policy. ... Preventing their departure is a service to humanity. ... I add, ladies and gentlemen, that many of Iraq's children and your children will become orphans, many of our women and your women will be widowed and many of our men and your men will die if war breaks out. ... To deprive an individual from seeing his homeland for some time is better for him and for humanity as a whole than depriving thousands of people of life. ... Let us cooperate to prevent these governments from committing major crimes and force them to withdraw their troops from the region, the presence of which may cause an intentional or unintentional spark that will result in an inferno and insurmountable flood of fire. In order to give everybody the opportunity to achieve peace; in order to disclose and expose those who want war and destruction; and in order to secure freedom for all, we put forward the following initiative: Firstly, the Security Council, with the consent of the United States, guarantees that U.S. forces will withdraw from the region under a fixed timetable, and within a period not exceeding the time it took to mobilize them. In addition, the Security Council reassures Saudi Arabia that it will undertake collective military action against Iraq if it attacks Saudi Arabia. At the same time, both Iraq and Saudi Arabia pledge that neither of them will commit an act of aggression against the other or harm the interests of the other. Secondly, the Security Council guarantees the security and stability in the entire region in accordance with the general basis contained in our previous initiative. ... This alternative, as we see it, is the option to achieve full and comprehensive peace and bring definite stability to the region and the world. Thirdly if either paragraph one or two above is accomplished, the foreigners shall be allowed to travel immediately as they choose. Fourthly, if the above is not to be fulfilled for any acceptable reason, then we will be content with a clear, unequivocal written commitment from the U.S. president that he withdraw his forces and those of his allies ... in accordance with a specific timetable and in a period that does not exceed the time to mobilize these forces; that he pledges not to use force against Iraq; that he declares his respect for international law and refrain from violating it; that he breaks the economic blockade on Iraq by all sides immediately; and that he deals with Iraq on the basis of mutual respect and reciprocal refraining from harming the interests of either party. For us, when the above mentioned items are met, we will use our constitutional powers to allow the foreigners concerned to travel out of Iraq, each according to his wish and decision. Fifthly, the issue of Kuwait should be left for the Arabs to tackle as an Arab issue, the same way they handled similar issues, such as that of the Sahara in the Arab Maghreb region between Morocco and the other parties concerned and the issue of Syria's occupation of Lebanon. Will the deaf hear? This is a question directed to the U.S. administration. A correct answer to this question will serve humanity. God's peace and blessings be upon you.

DOC.HEAD: Possible Terrorist Attacks Keep U.S. Forces on Edge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: The following is based on a pool dispatch.

The U.S. military, mindful of the toll taken by terrorists the last time American troops were on Middle East soil, is improving the security for its growing force in Saudi Arabia. Already strict security measures have been tightened even more in the past 72 hours, as Saudi officials expressed more concern over the possibility of terrorist attacks, a subject U.S. military officials refuse to discuss except in general terms. ``We are doing what we think is necessary to protect our people, equipment and installations,'' one senior American officer said here. ``But I'm not going to get into whether we feel there is more of a threat or less of a threat or things like that.'' A Saudi government official, however, said Saturday night that some concerns had been raised over the possibility that Iraqi or Iraqi-sponsored terrorists could have slipped into the Saudi kingdom with Kuwaitis fleeing their occupied country. ``We essentially have been allowing free crossing of the border and maybe at times we should have been more diligent,'' the Saudi official said. The official, like others quoted here, spoke only on condition of anonymity. American military officers here have, both publicly and privately, expressed concerns that American military personnel might be targeted for terrorist attacks as the stalemate with Iraqi troops just over the Saudi border in Kuwait drags on. American diplomatic posts around the world were urged to take security precautions in the days after President Bush committed U.S. troops to the defense of the Saudi kingdom and its oil fields. When asked about strict security measures here, U.S. officials repeatedly recall the devastating 1983 truck bombing of a Marine barracks in Lebanon. ``This a very dangerous part of the world,'' one U.S. military officer involved in security efforts said. ``History would tell us to be vigilant.'' Ground rules for the Pentagon pool operation prohibit disclosure of specific security steps being taken at U.S. military positions in Saudi Arabia. Officers also have been urging reporters not to disclose such details because of their value to Iraq. Visits in the past few days to several installations have provided glimpses of security precautions not in place during earlier visits. At one Army camp, guards kept M-16s aimed at a car filled with soldiers and journalists waiting outside a command post, even after the car had passed a series of elaborate security checks. ``It might make you nervous but they're doing their job and they're doing it right,'' the soldier driving the car said. The possibility of terrorism also is among reasons cited when U.S. military officials are asked why American troops are not yet allowed to take recreation breaks in Saudi cities. The Saudi army on Saturday was seen stopping and searching cars on a road not far from where some U.S. forces and equipment are deployed. ``It is better to take precautions than to suffer casualties,'' an adviser to the Saudi government said. Not that there haven't been security lapses. The Air Force included in one package of material it gave reporters a handout, printed for military personnel, that listed locations where airmen were staying and the times and pickup points of shuttles to base areas. Several hours later, after a reporter brought the document to the attention of military escorts, reporters were asked to return the handout so it would not fall into the wrong hands if discarded. And a Navy admiral opened a briefing this week by detailing the number and exact location of Marines and weapons recently arrived in Saudi Arabia, this despite specific written guidelines that such details not be discussed. A television reporter at the briefing instructed his crew not to feed that part of the tape back to the United States because it could have been broadcast or intercepted during satellite transmission. Not surprisingly, the Marines here appear most on edge about potential security lapses. A shotgun-toting Marine was standing guard outside one area where Marines are stationed, and refused to open the gate even after speaking with two Navy officers accompanying a small group of reporters. Photographers were clamoring to take a picture of a Marine tank flying an American flag, but the Marines refused to allow the shot because from the background it might have been possible to pinpoint their location. ``They will never forget Lebanon, nor should they,'' one of the Navy officers said. ``They have every right to be extra sensitive.''

DOC.HEAD: For Mountain Family, $25,000 Lottery Prize Means A Home With Running Water
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMS REPORT.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CN1 sent Aug. 19
DOC.TEXT: Carol Bowyer chose to play the lottery instead of eating lunch one day, and now her family has two used pickups, an electric stove and, finally, running water. Soon they'll have an indoor toilet. The Bowyers won $25,000 in the West Virginia Lottery in June, and though the money was soon spent, life on their mountain in the heart of Appalachia will never be the same. ``It's a dream for me,'' Mrs. Bowyer said. ``It's something I hadn't never really counted on ever. It's a dream come true.'' Mrs. Bowyer, 45, her husband, Walter, 46, a coal truck driver, and three sons live in a five-room house they are still building outside this mining community. Lightbulbs are bare and most interior walls show bare insulation between the studs. It started as one room. The house sits isolated, surrounded by sheds for chickens, goats and tools, against dense woods a few miles south of Beckley in southern West Virginia. ``I love it up here,'' she said. ``The only objection I ever had was water. When the kids hauled the water, it's OK. But when they're in school or something and I have to haul water, I didn't like it.'' The Bowyers, who occasionally had to go on welfare, had enough money for electricity and a telephone but not for a well, which costs about $2,000. Instead, the family hiked several hundred yards with buckets to a spring just off a dirt road, where they drew water for sponge baths. They got their cooking and drinking water from service stations. ``My husband tells me I'm camping out. Seven years of camping out. That's enough for anybody. ... We were planning on moving off the lot,'' she said. Then one day in June, Mrs. Bowyer walked more than four miles to the town of Beaver. ``I had a choice: I either eat or put $2 or $3 in the lottery, and that day I decided to play the lottery,'' she said. One of her $1 tickets was a $25,000 winner, less $5,000 withheld for federal income tax and $1,000 the Bowyers owed in back income tax. Bowyer bought a 1986 pickup and Walter III, 17, bought himself a 1963 pickup. Billy, 15, and Michael, 11, received a stereo and a remote control car. Then little was left after plumbing supplies, clothes, a few dinners out and a used electric stove Mrs. Bowyer bought from her mother-in-law for $50. So far, the Bowyers' indoor plumbing consists of just a pipe and spigot in the eldest son's room, soon to be the bathroom. A septic tank has been installed outside. ``We got water in the house so far and that's it. We've got everything ready to hook up, but he can't take off no more work,'' Mrs. Bowyer said. The family moved their mobile home to the mountain in 1983 after they couldn't afford to make monthly payments on a lot in Beckley. Here, they pay $300 a year. They eventually lost the mobile home, too. That's when they started to build, one room at a time. ``It was just a piece of land. This room here, we threw this room up and all five of us lived in this room for about six months,'' Mrs. Bowyer said as she pointed to her kitchen. ``Can you picture five people living in one room? It was kitchen, bedroom and everything for a while.'' She's proud of their new, 105-foot-deep well. ``When he pulled that water out of here it was real pretty and clear and I was really happy,'' she said. ``This is going to make me stay up here. Now I'm not ready to leave. I'm happy. I'm content. I'll stay here until I'm old and they have to roll me off and put me in a home.'' She still has dreams. ``That money only last me about a week,'' she said. ``I've got to win me the big lottery. That didn't last long enough.''

DOC.HEAD: Resistance Forces Continuing Guerrilla Attacks on Iraqi Invaders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Refugees fleeing occupied Kuwait say resistance fighters are staging desperate and daring attacks including suicide bombings, and that Iraq has been unable to wipe them out. In Jordan, escaping Arabs said Kuwaitis opposed to the Iraqi annexation have been clashing with pro-Iraqi Palestinians in Kuwait. One refugee said dozens of people had been killed. The small oil-rich emirate was overrun by the powerful Iraqi army on Aug. 2 and annexed six days later. Most communication with the outside world has gradually been cut by the invaders. Refugees arriving Sunday at the Saudi Arabian border crossing of Khafji said one Kuwaiti resistance fighter mounted a suicide car bomb attack Friday on an Iraqi position at a hospital in the Kuwait City suburb of Jabriyeh. The attack could not be independently confirmed, but the clandestine Kuwait radio also reported it, saying an unspecified number of Iraqi soldiers were killed or wounded. In an apparent reference to the same incident, the Kuwaiti newspaper Al-Anbaa, now publishing in Cairo, said Iraqi soldiers had been using the hospital as a headquarters. A similar attack Tuesday destroyed an Iraqi checkpoint near the entrance to Kuwait's harbor, the refugees said. Some refugees said they witnessed a brief attack Wednesday. Four Kuwaiti men armed with rifles fired on an Iraqi emplacement at the town of Jeleeb Al-Shuyoukh, nine miles southwest of the capital. The Iraqis conterattacked with machine guns and a tank, and the four resistance fighters took shelter in a nearby mosque. The tank fired at least three shells into the mosque, killing one of the attackers and injuring two. The other fled, according to the refugees. One Iraqi officer was sighted Wednesday dangling by the neck from a crane in downtown Kuwait, the refugees said, without elaborating. Most resistance attacks take place under cover of darkness, the refugees said. None could be independently confirmed. The guerrillas, who call their movement ``Humane Resistance,'' have also set up an informal organization to handle matters like distribution of goods, the refugees said. British journalist Victor Mallet, who was in Kuwait at the time of the invasion, said the resistance quickly developed into a guerrilla force mounting ambushes and sniper attacks, often with weapons taken from police stations. The Kuwaiti armed forces, numbering about 20,000, were quickly overwhelmed by Iraq's tank-led assault. Mallet, who eventuallly escaped across the desert to Saudi Arabia, quoted a member of the deposed ruling Al-Sabah family as saying that the resistance was developing an underground political and military structure and was in contact with the exiled goverment abroad. ``The plan was to encourage popular defiance and demoralize Iraqi troops already uncertain about their mission,'' Mallet, who writes for The Financial Times, reported last week from the the Saudi capital, Riyadh. One big problem for the resistance movement has been lack of coordination. Separate groups have formed in various parts of the country, Mallet said. The resistance groups are also beset by logistical problems and lack of weaponry, he said. Among the non-combat tasks being carried out by the resistance are care of the sick, the distribution of food and fuel and guarding against profiteers, the refugees here said in interviews. Egyptian refugee Sameh Al-Minyawi said his wife and daughter would travel on to Egypt, but that he himself would return to Kuwait and join the resistance because ``this is my duty to the country where I lived and worked seven years.'' ``I don't care what politicians may say or do, but these Nazis should be stopped at any cost,'' he said of the Iraqi invaders. The refugees described streams of Iraqis arriving in Kuwait by car to buy televisions, radios and other appliances. Kuwait is facing shortages of milk, sugar, rice and soap, they said. Electric appliances, which are scarce in Iraq, were being sold by Iraqi troops who looted them from houses, the refugees claimed. They said Iraqi officials appeared on Kuwaiti television Thursday with seven prisoners _ four Syrians, two Egyptians and a Kuwaiti _ and announced they would be executed for looting cash and gold from shops. At the Ruweishid border post in Jordan, Arabs arriving from Kuwait described nights shattered by gunfire as Kuwaitis opposed to the Iraqi annexation ought pro-Iraqi Palestinians. ``Kuwaitis are becoming very nervous and violent. They shoot and kill other Arab civilians for no reason,'' said Mohammad Ahmad al-Maarouf, a Tunisian merchant. He was one of thousands of Arabs who flooded through the desert border post Sunday as Iraq tightened its grip on Westerners in Kuwait and Iraq. A senior Jordanian security official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Iraqi authorities had notified Jordan's government that at least 350,000 Arabs will be crossing through Ruweishid this week. Maarouf and other evacuees said the shootouts in Kuwait followed violent political discussions. Mohammed Ali, an Egyptian, said Iraqi troops were ``trying desperately to stop the shootouts that have left tens of Palestinians dead.''

DOC.HEAD: Arafat In Tight Spot Over Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: PLO chief Yasser Arafat's support for Iraq has alienated him from key Arab patrons and set off a surge of radicalism in his own ranks that he may find hard to control. By backing Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, who invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, Arafat cut off an important source of revenue, the oil sheiks of the Persian Gulf. He also harmed relations with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, the leading Arab moderate who had championed Arafat's peace initiative. Whether these developments will jeopardize his leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization remains to be seen. Arafat has survived many challenges since he took over the movement in 1969. But with the PLO now threatened with a new schism as well as a funding squeeze, he is in a tight corner. In the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, Palestinians cheer Saddam, not Arafat, in daily demonstrations against the Americans and Saudis. Arafat faces a growing challenge in the territories, where a Palestinian uprising has raged for 2{ years, from militants of the Islamic Hamas movement. Hamas wants to escalate the stone-throwing riots against the Israelis into a full-blown guerrilla war. The passions unleashed by Saddam's actions work in their favor. They see Saddam's military might and willingness to challenge the West and Israel as their best hope of liberating the occupied lands after decades of despair and humiliation. In Syria, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine and the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine have called for a resumption of the armed campaign against Israel that was halted by the peace initiative Arafat launched in late 1988. They are the largest guerrilla factions in the PLO after Arafat's Fatah group. In Baghdad, the Palestine Liberation Front last week called on ``progressive Arab forces to confront the invading American aggressors.'' The group is led by Mohammed Abbas, or Abul Abbas, the mastermind of the Achille Lauro cruise liner hijack in October 1985, and the failed seaborne attack on Israel that led President Bush earlier this year to break off the U.S. dialogue with the PLO. Arab newspapers have reported that terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal plans to base himself in Iraq after a split with Libya, where he has had his headquarters for the last few years. But PLO officials interviewed in Tunis by telephone said they did not believe that Saddam would welcome Abu Nidal, who was based in Baghdad for seven years in the 1970s. Few Palestinians were dismayed when Saddam invaded Kuwait and touched off a potentially explosive confrontation with the the United States. They were increasingly frustrated by the Arab rulers' reluctance to use their oil wealth to force Israel to leave the occupied territories. Saddam played the Palestinian card shrewdly by linking any settlement of the Persian Gulf crisis to an Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank and Gaza, captured in 1967. He appealed to the Arab masses, over the heads of their governments, for support for his stand against Israel and the United States. He has succeeded to a large degree. Most Arabs see Washington as Israel's main protector and have long fumed at its failure to pressure the Jewish state into peace negotiations and a withdrawal from the occupied lands. The PLO was reluctant at first to back Saddam. Arafat shuttled between Arab capitals trying to find an ``Arab solution'' that would prevent foreign intervention. But ``he found the leaders far too divided to cooperate,'' said a PLO official who accompanied him. In recent days, PLO officials have been trying to put a better public face on their position. ``The PLO will never condone the occupation of any country by force when we ourselves are victims of such policies,'' said Salah Khalaf, Arafat's senior aide who uses the nom de guerre of Abu Iyad. But in an interview, he stressed Palestinian resentment at U.S. failure to force Israel to surrender the occupied territories after more than two decades. By contrast, he said, when Iraq seized Kuwait and the oil flow to the West was threatened, the United States and its allies acted ``like lightning.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Mona Ziade, based in Nicosia, has covered Palestinian affairs for The Associated Press since 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Croatian Villagers Feel Like Pawns in Political Game
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report. ^With PM-Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: Tonislav Maricic and his ethnic Croatian neighbors in this hillside village say they feel like victims of a campaign for a greater Serbia. While their Serbian neighbors were voting Sunday on regional autonomy in Knin, a city of 11,000 people a few miles down the hill, Maricic and friends gathered over coffee and fiery brandy to ponder their fate. ``We're pawns in a political game organized by (Serbian Communist President Slobodan) Milosevic with the aim of creating a greater Serbia,'' said Maricic, 63, a powerfully built retiree. While Maricic and his neighbors are among the majority in the western Yugoslav republic of Croatia, they are the minority in the Serbian-dominated southwest. The peace among residents of this Croatian village and the surrounding Serbian villages has not yet been disturbed by the Serbian drive for autonomy. But signs of tension are evident near Potkonje, this village of 60 brick homes scattered around a dirt trail built into rocky hills near the Adriatic coast. One of Potkonje's handful of ethnic Serbs has taken to irritating his neighbors by racing through the village with a Serbian flag in the back window of his pickup truck. Armed men from other villages around Knin blocked roads to prevent police from trying to stop the referendum. But Maricic, local head of Croatia's new center-right Croatian Democratic Union, said it is vital for Croatian President Franjo Tudjman to maintain a moderate policy toward the Serbian minority. ``The important thing is for Tudjman to keep a cool head and not give in to provocations,'' he said. The Serbs should be allowed to vent their frustrations, he added. ``It's better to let wine run out of a cask than to let it explode.'' He charged Serb extremists want bloodshed that could result in a call for the Serb-dominated army to come in and restore order. Potkonje residents oppose the Serbian demand for autonomy and say if it succeeds, they will seek to join a nearby Croatian county. They said their area, even though it is dominated now by Serbs, is traditionally Croatian, and that Croatian King Zvonimir was crowned nearby nine centuries ago. Though residents of the village do not expect trouble with their Serbian neighbors, they have started to take precautions, forming a village guard armed with handguns. Nikola Pozar, a 66-year-old former railroad worker, said, ``They hemmed us in, but we're not afraid because we haven't done anything. ... But if they attack, we will defend our homes with axes and pitchforks.''

DOC.HEAD: Casual Looting Where Bloodshed Began
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Carrying a bicycle and a lantern he had looted from the burning migrant worker hostel, the Xhosa man smiled as he walked back to his ramshackle squatter camp. A few dozen of his comrades casually climbed through windows of the barracks-like hostel, looking for anything of value abandoned by Zulus who fled savage tribal fighting. A week earlier, thousands of Zulus had filled the concrete and sheet-metal hostel, separated by a narrow dirt road from the squatter camp populated mostly by Xhosas. A 24-year-old Xhosa man called Bennett used a large hammer to smash a wall, block by block. He said he would tear down the entire hostel, which spread over several acres. He and his fellow Xhosas said they wanted to prevent the Zulus, their longtime foes, from ever returning. ``We cannot go on like this,'' said Theo, a Xhosa who gave his age as 30. ``They took us from the taxis and killed us! We cannot stand the pressure.'' Police with tear gas guns occasionally rode by in armored vehicles. The blacks scampered to their shacks, then returned when the police were gone. The Zulus and squatter camp residents began fighting on Aug. 12. The clashes sparked a week of violence in Tokoza, east of Johannesburg, and other nearby black townships. The death toll was more than 290. The fighting, mostly between war bands armed with crude spears, machetes and clubs, had political roots but appeared to have turned into tribal war. Most Zulus support the conservative Inkatha movement, while most Xhosas are loyal to the African National Congress. Inkatha and the ANC are the major black opposition groups opposed to the white-led government. Theo, an ANC supporter, said politics fueled the violence. He blamed Inkatha for trying to make it appear tribal-based. ``To make it confusing, they say they're attacking Xhosas,'' Theo said, holding a short iron bar in his hand. ``It started Sunday, when they killed a Xhosa.'' The Zulus then attacked the squatter camp on Monday, he said. ``They were trying several times to move us, but they couldn't make it.'' The Zulus left Wednesday for another hostel up the road, he said. At times, Zulus would stop taxis that transport blacks from the townships to and from their jobs in Johannesburg, Theo said. Pointing at his elbow, he said the Zulus would ask riders what it was. If the rider gave the Zulu word for elbow, he was safe, Theo said. But if he gave the Xhosa word, he was pulled out and killed. Bennett, tall and thin with large eyes, said he fought the Zulus on Monday night armed with a panga, or machete. He had rough scratches on the side of his throat. ``They tried to grab him,'' Theo said, putting his hand around the younger man's neck. ``He escaped.'' Behind him, people carried blankets, mattresses and chairs from the Zulu hostel across the windswept brown clearing to their shacks. One man had a stereo speaker _ but the squatter camp has no electricity.

DOC.HEAD: Man Plans International Kangaroo Trophy Business
DOC.TEXT: It may sound like sacrilege to some, but John Kreuger sees a booming market in kangaroo heads. The businessman in Townsville, on Australia's northeast coast, is about to start stuffing 2,000 to 3,000 kangaroo heads per year on tropies for sale to overseas tourists. They will sell for about $40 each. Krueger also is advertising in U.S. magazines and hopes to export 10,000 heads a year to the United States. ``Trophies are an accepted part of life overseas,'' Krueger said. ``The visitors come here and see part of a kangaroo and want to take it home with them. I think there's a huge market for the heads out there.'' Krueger has been stuffing kangaroo heads for 26 years, mostly for the market around Townsville. Until about six years ago, a few were sold in other areas, but protests by animal activists halted the practice. ``Now the greenies are more preoccupied with the forests and the greenhouse effect and what have you, so I figure it'll be OK,'' Krueger said. ``They'll be in Sydney shops within three to four months.'' Rick Humphries, national coordinator for Greenpace Australia, said he was ``disgusted'' with Krueger's plans.

DOC.HEAD: Courts Stay Rules to Restrict `Dial-a-Porn'
DOC.TEXT: Parents be warned: the government has been frustrated again in its lengthy fight to help you keep ``dial-a-porn'' messages away from innocent young ears. In a continuing battle pitting free speech against the government's right to protect kids, courts in New York and San Francisco last week temporarily stayed federal enforcement of new rules designed to make sure the $2 billion marketplace for phone sex remains an adults-only business. Testimony in the New York court had described some of the messages as ``re-creations of masturbation, simulated rape, sadomasochism and group sex.'' Homosexual rights groups had said such services were a form of safe sex in this era of the AIDS epidemic. Kendall Morrison, the owner of Dial Information Services and one of the plaintiffs in the New York case, told The New York Times that his company received 60,000 calls a day, costing the callers $1 on average. Until the courts decide on the constitutionality of the 1989 law that mandated the most recent Federal Communications Commission rules, enterprising kids still will be able to shock mom and dad with a mysterious charge on the family phone bill. ``Parents have our full support and our full sympathy,'' FCC Deputy General Counsel Renee Licht said in an interview last week. ``We are doing everything we possibly can to protect your children against indecent messages.'' But, she added, ``There isn't very much we can do until we have a final disposition'' of the court challenges. Parents still can ask phone companies to block access to phone sex services, where technically possible. But the New York judge who stayed FCC enforcement of the new rules said only 4 percent of New York's 4.6 million households had asked the phone company for blocking. Congress and the FCC since 1983 have been trying to erect technological barriers to ``indecent,'' for-pay phone material. Obscene material _ of a prurient, sexual nature and without redeeming value _ is banned outright on commercial phone, radio and television services. But the courts have held that adults have a right to hear indecency, which the FCC defines as ``patently offensive'' depictions or descriptions of sexual material. The courts also have said the government has a compelling public interest in keeping indecent material away from children. The big problem is how to do that without trampling on the free speech rights of phone sex providers _ and the adults who want to call them. In 1987, following two previous court defeats, the FCC implemented new rules that said phone sex providers would have a defense from prosecution for providing indecent material if they did one of the following: required up-front credit card payment; scrambled their messages or used access codes. The companies also were required to ask phone companies to identify the charges on customers' phone bills. Those rules were in effect for a short period until Congress, fearing that enterprising youths still could gain access to telephone sex messages, banned such services outright in April 1988. But the Supreme Court rejected the ban, saying only obscene material could be banned. Congress tried again in November 1989, a few months after the FCC fined a California company $600,000 for transmitting obscene phone messages. The mother of a 16-year-old boy complained that her son had placed more than 280 calls to various phone sex services in a 2{-month period in 1987. The 1989 law reinstated FCC regulation of indecency. But, under the prodding of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., Congress added a new wrinkle: phone companies, where possible, must block access to sex message services unless a customer asks in writing to receive them. Dial-a-porn services immediately labeled the Helms amendment a type of ``presubscription'' that would drive them out of business, and they sued the government. Several local Bell phone companies told the FCC it was not feasible to selectively block adult services. Despite these challenges, the FCC readopted the 1987 rules _ and the new ``reverse blocking'' dictum _ in June of this year. The rules had been scheduled to go into effect last Wednesday, but the courts stayed them pending further study. The New York federal judge, Robert P. Patterson, said the law was vague on what constituted indecency; it was not the least restrictive means available to accomplish the government's purposes; and it would allow prior censorship without adequate safeguards.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Army Spruces Up and Puts on Show for the Foreign Press
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Defense Ministry recently provided a rare tour of Soviet army bases. Here is a report.

``We always eat like this,'' insisted the crew-cut Soviet draftee, stuffing a hunk of black bread in his mouth as he gestured at white tablecloths, artfully arranged salad plates and hovering waiters in the ``ordinary'' soldiers' canteen. When a group of foreign journalists ventured out to the firing range of this 2nd Guards Artillery base outside Leningrad, four soldiers with their Kalashnikov rifles and their round metal `doughboy'-style helmets snapped to attention. It was the merest coincidence that all four were members of the Young Communist League. The army did not go so far as to paint the grass green for a rare tour to four army bases by foreign correspondents. But soldiers had been busy painting everything else. Organizers obviously took inspiration from a famous Russian field marshal, Prince Grigory Potemkin, who had fake villages erected overnight to greet Catherine the Great as she traveled through conquered territory. Still, it was a remarkable opening by the army, which for decades considered foreign journalists to be spies. Most of the area surrounding Moscow is still forbidden territory for non-Soviets because they might glimpse the fence of a military base. On the tour, reporters and television crews were offered a mock tank-and-helicopter battle, a session with Soviet grenade launchers and the greasy experience of crawling inside an armored personnel carrier and peering through tiny slits. Like the U.S. Army, the Soviets have discovered it is far cheaper to train on simulators than the real thing. The ``film-trainer'' for armored personnel carrier drivers captured the roaring and sheer difficulty of controlling one of these monsters as they lumber off-road. But the simulator had limitations. Its dashboard, with clunky meters and heavy manual buttons, looked like it belonged to the mid-1950s, not the age of high-tech warfare. Crews for the big guns practiced loading lightweight empty shell casings and pulling a string. All it lacked for theater was someone yelling, ``Bang!'' Draftees, stripped to the waist, lifted legs and arms in calisthenics more reminiscent of Jane Fonda than U.S. Marines. But their metal weights were not shiny barbells; they were worn-out tank treads. Most young soldiers were tongue-tied in the face of foreign journalists and high-ranking officers. But their shyness turned to rampant curiosity when they learned American recruits earn $670 a month to their 7 rubles. That's $12 per month at the very best exchange rate. The tour began on the hardly typical, pre-revolutionary base of the 2nd Guards, nestled among the splendrous gardens of the czarist palaces outside Leningrad. It even had its own church _ a crumbling, onion-domed beauty, boarded up so long that saplings grew from the crenellations. The soldiers were reluctant to discuss the army's most serious problems: hazing, language difficulties among recruits from Asian republics who cannot speak Russian, and a critical shortage of housing for Soviet troops withdrawing from Eastern Europe. Journalists hoping to see examples of the housing had to make do chatting with officers' wives at the Malorita base near Brest. They said they had no problems. While many units returning from Eastern Europe have nowhere to go, their husbands' paratrooper regiment took over an SS-20 missile base, abandoned by a larger unit under a U.S.-Soviet nuclear weapons treaty. ``We were lucky. Everybody has a place to live,'' said Marina Petrovna, a captain's wife. Soviet journalists goggled at the wives, whose youthful looks and Hungarian fashions contrasted with the appearance of the average Soviet woman. The political officers who ran the show borrowed a few tricks from Intourist, the government tourist agency _ packing the schedule with travel and ceremonies that left little time for mixing with ordinary people. As a result, the entourage was late for Gen. Boris Gromov's news conference and war-game show. Ten minutes into correspondents' questions, the Hero of the Soviet Union and former Soviet commander in Afghanistan was drowned out by his own artillery fire. Political officers looked on indulgently when the correspondents, many long-time residents who have picked up the Soviet habit of hoarding, cleared out the military shop's supply of paratrooper T-shirts, officers' caps and army watches. The hottest item was an army belt _ leather with a brass hammer-and-sickle buckle _ for $2.60.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Authorities Begin Annual Push on Marijuana Crops
LaserPhotos NY15,16
DOC.TEXT: From a helicopter, the neat patchwork of farms fades quickly to ragged, stone-fenced cornfields and the Sierra Madre del Sur, where a cash crop flourishes in the craggy wilderness. ``Pure marijuana, all marijuana,'' said Jesus Verjes, a director of the annual three-month government effort to destroy the crop. The helicopter flew over patch after patch of marijuana in southwestern Michoacan state. Michoacan's border with Guerrero is shaggy with wilderness, creased with cliffs and rimrock. There are no roads. It is only one of many parts of Mexico where marijuana grows, but is popular because of the soil, climate and isolation. Marijuana is a richer green than surrounding foliage and a trained spotter can pick out the ``plantios,'' or patches. Those in the open are sprayed from the air. If they are shielded, police are flown in to uproot and burn the plants. ``We are doing it now because the marijuana is about half grown,'' Verjes said. ``It is too young to harvest, but too late in the year for the growers to get another crop planted. We are trying to break the growing cycle.'' When the marijuana season ends in three months, the Federal Judicial Police will start their campaign against opium poppies, he said. Federal police have uprooted or sprayed about 3,000 acres of plants and confiscated 400 tons of dried marijuana so far this year, according to government statistics. How much of the drug will survive the eradication programs and get to market is nearly impossible to calculate because no consistent figures are available on the amount of marijuana planted or harvested each year. The U.S. National Narcotics Intelligence Consumer Committee, headed by the Drug Enforcement Administration, estimates more than 42,000 tons of Mexican marijuana finds its way into the United States each year, or about 79 percent of the country's total supply. Mexico has 114 planes and helicopters dedicated to drug eradication. The United States provides about $15 million a year for such programs. In a small glen on a mountainside, soldiers uprooted armloads of yard-high plants that had been sheltered by trees, and carried them to a bonfire. ``They used to plant these things in plots bigger than a hectare (about 2{ acres), but when we started picking them out from the air, they got smarter,'' Verjes said. ``Most plots now are much smaller.'' He said the plants were ``criollo,'' or market-grade, which grow easily and quickly and are fairly easy to spot from the air. Verjes said the low-bush cola de borrego, or ``sheep's tail,'' produces a more potent leaf, brings a better price and is easier to hide among other vegetation, but the yield is lower and it needs some special growing conditions. ``If we spot an area from the air that has maybe five plots, we send in police and usually find 15 or 20 other plots hidden away nearby,'' he said. Growers have taken to planting corn, giving it a start, then planting marijuana among it, giving an appearance from above of an innocent cornfield. If nobody lives nearby or there is a shack that appears abandoned, police often are sent in for a closer look. ``They have gotten smarter, but so have we,'' Verjes said. Police in helicopters had descended the day before on the camp used by workers tending the plants that were being burned. The 20 or so men had escaped quickly, abandoning hot food on the fire. There were seeding beds for starting the plants, a drying rack and enough rice, beans, sugar, tortilla flour and other supplies to last for weeks, possibly months. A pot of beans was on the dead fire of the camp, about 140 miles southwest of Mexico City. Clothes were scattered among crude bamboo beds on a dirt floor. If the crop had survived, Verjes said, it would have been compressed into bricks and taken to a buyer by burro. He said bus ticket stubs in the shelter indicated most of the workers were not from Michoacan, but had come from other poor agricultural states. Drug camps are heavily armed and 17 federal police assigned to drug eradication have been killed so far this year, usually at the outset of raids. Most of the plants in this plantio had been laid out in neat rows, perhaps from years of habit, making them easier to spot in the tangle of trees and bushes. The patches were scattered over about 40 acres, providing about five days' work for the men uprooting the marijuana, said Hector Salinas Almaguer, a lawyer and police agent who led the detail. ``From here, they will go down the mountain to some other patches we have found from the air,'' he said. Michoacan's isolation closed in. Aside from the fire's crackle and the tramp of boots, the only sounds were crickets, mosquitoes and the rustling of leaves in a light breeze.

DOC.HEAD: East German Ex-Wife of U.S. Army Deserter Returns to U.S.
DOC.TEXT: An Army deserter who spent 30 years in East Germany and was arrested when he returned home was reunited Sunday with the ex-wife and daughters he left behind. Arnold Kephart and about a dozen friends and relatives greeted his former wife, Brigitte, 30, and the couple's twin 9-year-old daughters, Karoline and Katharine, at Eppley Airfield late Sunday night. The reunion was delayed more than five hours because they missed a connecting flight. As Kephart and Brigitte hugged and kissed each other, the girls were given bouquets of flowers. Kephart's niece, Debbie Rolfe of nearby Council Bluffs, Iowa, gave the twins toy dolls. Brigitte and the twins are supposed to return to East Germany Sept. 9, but Kephart said he'll try to change that. ``We want her to stay. He needs a mother,'' he said, gesturing toward Frankie, Arnold and Brigitte's 13-year-old son who accompanied his father to this country earlier this year. Kephart and Brigitte were married in 1976 and divorced in 1988. They had been working on a reconciliation when Kephart left East Germany. He said Sunday he hopes they can remarry. Kephart, 53, was a U.S. Army private in West Germany in 1959 when he wrecked a Jeep and fled to East Germany because he feared punishment. Kephart remained for three decades in East Germany. He and Frankie were permitted to leave after the country's hard-line Communist government fell last fall after massive pro-democracy demonstrations forced officials to open the borders to the West. They returned to the United States in January. Kephart was arrested for desertion as soon as he stepped off the plane in Omaha. A week later, the Army granted him a discharge and he rejoined his relatives in Council Bluffs.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Tours Gulf; Navy Shadows Iraqi Shipping
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is seeking increased international support for the U.S. naval barricade of Iraqi shipping, as one key Persian Gulf state offers to host ``friendly'' forces on its territory. Cheney planned to leave this island nation today after conferring with its emir, Sheik Isa Al-Khalifa. He was to travel on to other friendly Arab nations in the Persian Gulf before returning to Saudi Arabia. One stop on his itinerary was the United Arab Emirates, which announced Sunday it has agreed to the deployment of Arab and ``friendly'' forces on its territory to help defend the Persian Gulf region. Diplomatic sources in Abu Dhabi said the announcement approved the deployment of U.S., Egyptian and Pakistani troops, but it was not immediately known if any of those nations planned to send forces. ``The United Arab Emirates has agreed to receive some Arab and friendly forces as a contribution to the Arab and international efforts being exerted to defend the region,'' said the Foreign Ministry statement released by the United Arab Emirates' official news agency. The statement did not name any countries or say how many forces would be involved. Cheney also was scheduled to visit Oman today before heading to Jiddah, Saudi Arabia. During a stop Sunday on the command ship of the U.S. naval task force in the Persian Gulf, Cheney vowed the United States would continue its effort to cripple Iraq's international commerce and use force if necessary. The ship was docked in Bahrain. He spoke as U.S. warships shadowed two Iraqi oil tankers after the vessels ignored U.S. warning shots Saturday and headed out of the gulf region. The shots were the first fired in an interdiction effort ordered by President Bush to halt goods leaving and entering Iraq. The United Nations previously ordered a trade embargo against Iraq involving all goods except food and medical shipments. ``Our forces are authorized to intercept shipping that they have reason to believe may in fact be violating the sanctions,'' Cheney told reporters traveling with him. ``We want to continue to work both by voluntary means and by naval means, if necessary, to see to it that the sanctions are enforced,'' he said. The Iraqi News Agency said Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz on Sunday called the U.S. shipping interdiction effort ``piracy and armed aggression'' and asked the international community to condemn it.
