Cheney would not speculate on any steps that might be taken against Iraqi tankers if they continued to refuse to stop. ``I wouldn't want to speculate on what happens next,'' he said. ``We obviously are prepared to see to it that the sanctions that the United Nations voted and the action that the legitimate government of Kuwait asked us to take are carried out.'' An administration official said the United States intended to go forward with its interdiction effort, even though no further action has been taken against the two Iraqi tankers. ``There's nothing pushing immediate action here,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We've stated our intent and many people are complying voluntarily.'' The official said the administration is looking toward further action in the United Nations on enforcement of its sanctions. The U.N. Security Council unanimously demanded Saturday that Iraq let all foreigners leave and that Baghdad ``take no action to jeopardize the safety, security or health of such nationals.'' Cheney refused to tie the outbreak of shooting in the area's tense waters to Iraq's refusal to allow more than 3,000 Americans and thousands of other Westerners to leave that nation or Kuwait, the tiny oil-rich kingdom that Iraq overran on Aug. 2. Cheney insisted ``the two are unrelated.'' On Sunday, Cheney was in Bahrain and Saudi Arabia, where he inspected U.S. troops at a desert air base. The United States is building forces in Saudi Arabia to deter an Iraqi invasion of the United States' largest supplier of oil. ``Should Saddam Hussein be foolish enough to launch an attack on Saudi Arabia, (American forces) would be able to do a very effective job of making him pay us a bit of a price for that,'' Cheney told reporters at the base. As U.S. and Saudi F-15 fighter jets screamed overhead, he viewed the mass of U.S. military equipment lined along one runway, visited with members of a Sheridan tank unit and was taken to a Patriot missile battery dug into the desert on the outskirts of the air base.

DOC.HEAD: Traffic at Saudi Border Post Is One-Way
DOC.TEXT: With Iraqi troops massed on the other side of the border in occupied Kuwait, the traffic is only one-way at this giant toll booth in the middle of the desert. The local branch of the Riyadh Bank is closed, big American-made sedans are parked willy-nilly, and Saudi customs agents are underemployed these days. In fact, the only people passing through this checkpoint are refugees who have fled Kuwait. To them, the Red Cross tents several hundred yards down the road and the Al Khafji Hotel, six miles away in the small oil town of Khafji, are oases. ``We're very crowded, very crowded,'' said Mursi Abu Bakr, whose family owns the hotel that fronts on the Persian Gulf with a view of some of the richest oil fields in the world. Abu Bakr said Kuwaitis _ desperate to stay near the border _ have filled his hotel since Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Some refugees like Kuwaiti air force Capt. Mohamed Al-Ajmi, 32, want to stay near the border so they can keep in contact with their families by car phone. Regular telephone lines have been cut so car phones must be used, he said. From his reports, Al-Ajmi said resistance by Kuwaitis to the Iraqi occupation is intensifying. Refugees arriving Sunday at the Khafji border crossing said one Kuwaiti resistance fighter mounted a suicide car bomb attack Friday on an Iraqi position at a hospital in the Kuwait City suburb of Jabriyeh. The attack could not be independently confirmed, but the clandestine Kuwait radio also reported it, saying an unspecified number of Iraqi soldiers were killed or wounded. Despite its proximity to the border, there are few signs that people in Khafji are worried about an Iraqi attack. Iraqi troops have dug in about 25 miles from the border, according to a Saudi official, and they are not visible. Khalid Al-Otaishan, the governor of the Khafji area, said Saudi troops were stationed nearby in the desert, but few could be seen in the city which resembled a ghost town as people sought relief from the intense mid-day sun. Saudi officials have said their goal is to keep troops out of the public eye to allow life to continue as normally as possible. Saudi tank carriers traveled along the paved road to Dhahran _ headquarters of the U.S. military operation, about 220 miles to the south. Handfuls of Saudi soldiers prayed alongside the road in accordance with Moslem ritual as goats and camels wandered nearby in the desert. Only one group of American soldiers was spotted during the day _ seven Army men sat in a parked station wagon at the border checkpoint. Al-Otaishan, 41, who was educated at the University of Southern California, said people are less worried than they were immediately after Iraqi troops occupied Kuwait. Some of the few hundred Khafji residents who fled in panic have come back because they think the situation has stablized, he said. Six Saudi tanks were parked in the desert several hundred yards from the building where the governor was interviewed. Abu Bakr, the hotelier, agreed people felt safer in part because of the presence of U.S. troops and warships. Asked if he was scared, he said: ``The first week we were. Now things are getting better and we work the best we can.'' Scott Scheid of Newport Beach, Calif., said Khafji was probably not the best place to be. ``I don't think you want to be here if something starts up,'' said Scheid, who works for an American oil company near Dhahran. Scheid's company has evacuated its 19 local employees from Khafji. ``There is a lot of tension in the air,'' said a co-worker, Albert Skiba, of Tucson, Ariz. The soul of Khafji is the Arabian Oil Co., which pumps about 300,000 barrels a day and dominates the area with its refinery and oil tank facilities. The company is 40 percent owned by the Japanese, with the Saudis and the Kuwaitis sharing the remainder.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Exports Growing, Commerce Secretary Says
DOC.TEXT: Regardless of the Middle East's impact on the world's oil bill, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher believes U.S. exports will continue to grow and keep the nation's economy out of recession this year. But he admitted in an interview that rising oil costs could ruin his prediction that the nation's merchandise trade deficit will come in under $100 billion this year for the first time since 1983. Mosbacher commented in his fifth floor office following his department's announcement Friday that exports in June reached a record $34.3 billion and helped drive the trade deficit that month to just $5.07 billion. That was the slimmest imbalance since the deficit dropped to $3.96 billion in June 1983. Assuming oil prices decline soon, he said, ``we're headed at close to a $90 billion trade deficit this year _ it could be $95 billion, under $100 billion is what I've been saying.'' That would be more than a one-third cut from the 1987 peak deficit of $152.12 billion. The imbalance has declined each year since then, falling to $109 billion last year. So far this year, Mosbacher said, the deficit has tumbled to $45.8 billion, the lowest six-month imbalance since the second half of 1983. But he admitted that continued high oil prices could add to the cost of imports which dropped to $39.37 billion in June and helped narrow the deficit. ``If the price of oil doesn't stay up very long, we'll still make it,'' he said. The price of oil on Friday was nearly twice the $14.64 a barrel that it averaged during June. Many analysts have said they believe skyrocketing oil prices will add to the cost of imports in the second half of the year, offsetting the effect of export growth on the deficit. The secretary contended that ``the price of oil is not as big relatively overseas as it is here'' and will not substantially cut into purchases of U.S. goods. ``So, I think we'll continue to have a good market,'' he said. ``You know, we're now in a trade surplus with Europe and I think we'll hold that.'' The surplus with Europe totaled $806.2 million in June, pushing the six-month total to $4.34 billion. At the same time, the deficit with Japan _ as usual, the biggest _ fell from $24.42 billion in the first half of 1989 to $19.59 billion from January through June of this year. ``We've had some real improvement'' with Japan, Mosbacher said. ``We're down from almost $50 billion last year to what looks like $40 billion this year, plus or minus.'' The commerce secretary attributed the export progress to the decline in the dollar, improved quality of U.S. goods and greater export expertise. ``U.S. goods are a lot cheaper overseas now for these customers,'' he said. ``Plus, our quality keeps improving and our knowledge of how to export ... keeps improving. And finally, the government's working with exporters.'' Thus far, he said, the rising exports ``shows American business is competitive around the world, it shows American business is beginning to realize it's a global marketplace, with the biggest potential area of growth and unsatisfied demand outside the U.S.''

DOC.HEAD: Hubble Mirror Maker Building More NASA Mirrors; Backlash Feared
DOC.TEXT: The company responsible for the Hubble Space Telescope's flawed mirror is building mirrors for another NASA observatory, a $1.4 billion instrument that will ``see'' X-rays from the cosmos. Hughes Danbury Optical Systems Inc., formerly Perkin-Elmer, has said it is confident it can provide quality mirrors for the Advanced X-Ray Astrophysics Facility, or AXAF. ``Based on technical considerations ... there's no reason whatsoever that the Hubble problems should have anything to do with AXAF,'' said Charles Pellerin Jr., NASA director of astrophysics. Even though the two space-based telescopes are worlds apart scientifically and have different optical systems, scientists fear the furor on Capitol Hill over the Hubble error may spread to the AXAF. ``The biggest concern is the negative reaction and the resulting delay in funding,'' said Stephen Murray of the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, a principal investigator for the X-ray telescope. The $1.5 billion Hubble was released from the shuttle Discovery in April to study stars almost as old as the universe. Two months later, embarrassed NASA officials reported Hubble's images were blurry and that its use would be limited until space-walking astronauts can install a new camera in 1993. A spacing error of 1.3 millimeters has been found in a measuring instrument used by Perkin-Elmer to grind the mirrors. NASA officials said Thursday thin washers in the device could have caused the error if improperly installed. Hughes Danbury is using a different polishing method for the X-ray mirrors because of their cylindrical shape, said company spokesman Tom Arconti. Hubble's mirrors were like saucers and built to reflect visible and ultraviolet light. ``It's a whole different set of challenges,'' Arconti said. The telescope will study sources of cosmic X-rays, including quasars, black holes and supernova remnants, to help scientists learn the size and age of the universe. Cosmic X-rays do not penetrate the atmosphere and can't be seen from Earth. The telescope is scheduled for a shuttle ride in 1997, and work is on schedule. The mirrors are expected to undergo rigorous testing at NASA. Still, there is no guarantee something won't go wrong, said NASA project scientist Martin Weisskopf. ``It has been our experience ... you put something up, it's a miracle if everything works perfectly,'' he said. ``You have to take risks.'' More than a third of the $145 million spent so far on AXAF has gone toward optics, said Fred Wojtalik, project manager for Hubble and AXAF. NASA is requesting $146 million from Congress for the upcoming fiscal year, $63 million of that for optics. In another botched project, mirrors for a $747 million series of weather satellites being built under NASA supervision have been found to warp in the temperature extremes of space. But agency officials said the problem has nothing to do with Hubble or AXAF. ITT Aerospace Communications Division supplied an inaccurate design to mirror maker Applied Optics Corp. of Sarasota, Fla., said ITT spokesman Donald Walters. Former NASA historian Alex Roland said such problems are examples of the space agency's budget-based decision making. ``There are supposed to be quality control safeguards built into that system, and my suspicion is some of those steps get cut out,'' said Roland, now a history professor at Duke University. ``NASA has an unrealistic agenda, and it's cutting corners on all its programs. The chances of repeating the problems we've had with Hubble are very high.'' AXAF will be the third in the Great Observatories series. Rounding out the planned fleet are the Gamma Ray Observatory and the Space Infrared Telescope Facility. The $550 million, mirrorless Gamma Ray Observatory is scheduled to be deployed from the shuttle Atlantis in the spring. The infrared telescope is still in the early planning stages, with launch targeted for 1999 or 2000. ``It would be terrible if the perceptions of the moment hurt the visions of the future,'' said NASA administrator Richard Truly.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Australian Cattle Producers Vie for Japanese Market
DOC.TEXT: Cattle producers in Australia and the United States are headed for a showdown at the old corral over who's going to be top gun in the lucrative Japanese beef market. Australia, traditionally a producer of grass-fattened cattle, has dominated the limited Japanese beef market. But recent trade liberalization has brought greater access and prospects of further growth. The United States, with its vast cattle herds and experience in producing grain-fed cattle, also has enjoyed sharp growth in sales to Japan. In 1983, for example, Australia supplied 37,505 metric tons of beef to Japan, while U.S. shipments were only 1,231 tons. By 1986, when the Australian shipments rose to 43,987 tons, the U.S. beef sales increased to 2,213 tons. But the Agriculture Department says that last year, following Japan's beef trade agreement in 1988, Australia's share was 93,693 tons and the U.S. total was 22,807 tons. Meanwhile, according to a report by the department's Economic Research Service, Australia has stepped up its own capacity to produce grain-fed cattle to compete in the emerging Japanese demand for top-quality beef. At once, Australia has served notice that it will not be content to continue providing Japan with lower-quality beef from grass-fattened cattle while U.S. feedlot operators walk off with the more expensive prizes. The Australian cattle feedlot industry for producing grain-fattened cattle is less than 10 percent the size of the U.S. giant. But it's an important competitor. ``It is large enough to have an impact on the grain-fed beef trade today and a greater impact in the future if present industry expansion plans materialize,'' the report said. ``Australia has all the resources needed to be a strong competitor in the grain-fed beef market in Japan and in other countries importing grain-fed beef.'' The agency's report was written by economists William D. Gorman of New Mexico State University, Las Cruces, and Hiroshi Mori of Senshu University, Kawasaki, Japan. Australia began a small-scale feedlot industry in the 1960s, but the expansion ended in 1974 when cattle prices plummeted and the Japanese market was closed, the report said. A number of those early feedlots were built with Japanese capital. ``This early foray into (feedlot) cattle on a large scale ended in disaster _ not because Australia didn't have the cattle, feed grains and technical knowledge to make it work, but because Australia did not have a market for grain-fed cattle,'' the report said. As of early 1990, Australian feedlots had a one-time capacity of approximately 600,000 head, and plans call for expanding to at least 1 million head by 1992. Japanese investment once again is part of the scene. Australia produces large quantities of feed-quality wheat and barley, and smaller amounts of sorghum and corn, the report said. And the country has the capacity to boost production if demand increases. One of the factors in lining up the Japanese beef trade is ``an unbelievably wide range'' in the beef quality offered to consumers, the report said. At the top of the Japanese quality list of beef cattle is Waygu, the domestic beef breed, which may be three or four years old at the time of slaughter. They may have been fed on grain for as long as 36 months. Special imported ``long-grain-fed'' beef is from Australian and U.S. cattle two to three years old at slaughter. These were fed grain for 10 to 13 months. Next in line are the U.S. choice and prime grades of beef from cattle 1{ to 2 years old that have been fed grain for four to eight months. This is the top-of-the-line beef most commonly available to American consumers. Below these qualities are several grades of Australian beef that has been produced on grass or grain, or combinations thereof. ``Marbling (streaks of fat) and related characteristics are very important factors in Japanese beef quality,'' the report said. ``In general, the greater the marbling, the higher the price.'' The report noted that the current Japanese system of controlling imports through quotas will be eliminated as of April 1, 1991, when a new tariff system goes into effect. At that point, the current U.S. practice of shipping quality beef to Japan by air freight, a much more expensive method than by ocean freight used by Australia, will run into problems. The tariff for beef imported by Japan will rise next April 1 to 75 percent from the current 25 percent. The tariff is scheduled to drop to 60 percent in 1992 and 50 percent in 1993. Air freight to Japan typically ranges from 70 cents to 90 cents per pound, compared with 17 cents to 20 cents for ocean freight. ``It will probably not be financially practical to continue air freighting most beef products after the new tariff rates take effect,'' the report said. ``Hence, the U.S. beef packing industry must be able to ship fresh chilled beef by ocean freight to remain competitive with Australia.''

DOC.HEAD: 22 Drug Suspects Extradited During First Year of New Policy
DOC.TEXT: A year after Colombia resurrected extradition as a weapon in his country's fight against drug traffickers, the South American government has sent 22 people to the United States for trial. Although none of them were on the 12 ``most wanted'' list, most who have stood trial have been convicted and sentenced _ albeit it not to particularly long prison terms. Only one has received the maximum 30-year prison term allowed by the extradition decree issued last August by Colombia's then-President Virgilio Barco. Of the 22, three were convicted of U.S. charges, eight pleaded guilty and one was acquitted. Ten still await trial. It was the Aug. 18, 1989 assassination by traffickers of Colombian presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan, an outspoken foe of the drug trade, that spurred Barco to crack down on the traffickers. Barco's state of siege included resumption of extraditions, even though the Colombian Supreme Court had tossed out the extradition treaty several years earlier as its members faced threats from drug traffickers. John Walters, chief of staff to U.S. drug control policy director William Bennett, said in a recent interview that the extradition policy ``allowed an opportunity to bring to justice people who might not have been brought to justice otherwise given the disruption of the judicial system (in Colombia) that had occurred as a result of trafficker violence and intimidation.'' The Medellin drug cartel's leaders, whose missives to the Colombian government have been signed, ``The Extraditables,'' recently said they will maintain a cease-fire they declared in July despite the killing of one of the cartel members earlier this month in a shootout with authorities. It is believed they want to convince newly inaugurated Colombian President Cesar Gaviria to stop the extraditions. In his inaugural address, Gaviria swore he would make no concessions to the traffickers, although he said extradition cannot be the only weapon used. Fifteen people are awaiting extradition. The most recent extraditions occurred Aug. 3, a few days before Gaviria took office. The only person extradited who has gotten the maximum 30-year sentence is Jose Rafael Abello Silva, a reputed high-ranking member of the Medellin cartel. Abello was convicted in Tulsa, Okla., of two counts of conspiring to import cocaine and marijuana into the United States over a seven-year period. He was sentenced to two concurrent 30-year prison terms and fined $5 million. Barco's 1989 decree said no Colombian national could be extradited unless the requesting state guaranteed it would not impose a prison sentence exceeding 30 years, eliminating the possibility of life terms or death penalties allowable under some U.S. laws. Several other Colombians have received 15-year terms: _Bernardo Pelaez Roldan, convicted in absentia in 1984 in Detroit on a charge of conspiracy with intent to distribute cocaine. _Guillermo Juan Bueno-Delgado, also known as Willy Bueno, pleaded guilty to two counts of conspiracy, one in San Francisco and one in Tallahassee, Fla. His two 15-year terms are to run concurrently. _Victor Eduardo Mero-Mosquero, convicted in absentia in the early 1980s on a drug conspiracy charge in New York. He also faces a cocaine conspiracy charge in Florida, but he is fighting extradition. Of the other defendants sentenced: one got 12{ years in prison, one got eight, one got seven and two got three years each. Nelson Cuevas Ramirez was acquitted in New York City of a charge of conspiracy to distribute cocaine. Ten others await trial including the first person extradited, Eduardo Martinez Romero, who arrived in the United States last Sept. 6. He faces federal charges in Atlanta of conspiracy to possess cocaine with intent to distribute and conspiracy to launder proceeds of drug trafficking, part of an immense money-laundering arrangement uncovered by the government's Operation Polar Cap.

DOC.HEAD: National Observatory Asks Americans' Help in `Moonwatch'
DOC.TEXT: Here's your chance to be the first person on Earth to spot the new moon when it makes its appearance Tuesday night. Your efforts won't be on a par with the discovery of a new planet, but it will help science all the same. Scientists know the position of the moon at any given time precisely enough to send six spaceships across 250,000 miles of space and land on the exact lunar spot they chose. But they can't predict the exact time or geographic location at which the young crescent moon will first be spotted. And that's where you come in. The U.S. Naval Observatory asks participants in the Moonwatch to be outside where there's a clear, flat western horizon and to watch from about a half hour to an hour after sunset. ``Please do not use binoculars or telescope,'' the observatory says. ``A good horizon is essential since the moon will be best visible when it is roughly 2 degrees to 5 degrees above the true horizon.'' Astronomers will compare the Moonwatch observations with their theoretical calculations to improve their ability to predict the time and location when the moon first becomes visible. Write to the observatory at 34th and Massachusetts Ave. NW, Washington, D.C. 20392, about what you saw and when you saw it. A sketch showing the position of the crescent with respect to the horizon will be welcome, the observatory says. The Naval Observatory had a Moonwatch in 1988 and got information from more than 2,000 observers, ranging in age from 4 to 92 years. Some groups turned the occasion into family outings. Their findings were published in the magazine Sky and Telescope. Be warned. The new moon usually does not appear until the second evening but it can be visible under certain conditions. There are no prizes, but poets through the ages have praised the benefits of being showered by moonbeams. ``The moon is nothing but a circumambulatory aphrodisiac divinely subsidized to provoke the world into a rising birthrate,'' wrote Christopher Fry. The Naval Observatory didn't wax that poetic. It offered only this hope: ``May your sky be clear!''

DOC.HEAD: Quebec Resort Town Shaken By Armed Standoff With Mohawks
DOC.TEXT: This resort town nestled between pine forests and the St. Lawrence River has been turned into an armed camp, and it may take a long time for the wounds to heal from the standoff between Mohawks and police. The lives of almost everyone here have been changed by the July 11 shootout between Mohawks from the adjacent Kanesatake reserve and provincial police, who stormed barricades set up by the Indians. One policeman was killed, although it is unclear which side fired the fatal shot. The Mohawks were protesting the village's plan to expand its nine-hole golf course onto land the Indians claim contains a sacred burial ground. Villagers saw their peaceful existence explode that day. Property values have plummeted, incomes have dropped and trust between Mohawks and the mostly French Canadian local residents has evaporated. Now this community of 1,800 _ a summer tourist resort and retirement home for many in the Montreal area _ has been turned into a police camp. Two-thirds of the people have fled their homes, either living with relatives or in hotels in the region, while awaiting the outcome of negotiations between the Mohawks and federal and provincial officials. ``I think there will be long-term (psychological) effects,'' said Louis Bricault, a psychologist hired by the municipality to help residents deal with their problems. ``They are suffering from feelings of anxiety, unhappiness, hostility, impotence and defeat. There are some people for whom these reactions have become very intense.'' Even when the crisis is over, it is unlikely life can ever be the same. ``We have to find a way to live together,'' said Yvan Patry, mayor of Oka Parish, the larger community that surrounds both Oka village and the Kanesatake reserve. Patry said the problem must be solved because the Mohawks are not going to leave Oka, and neither are the non-Indians. ``My greatest wish is that it returns to the way it was before. We were here together before, we'll be here together afterward.'' The economic losses have yet to be calculated. There are small businessmen like variety store owner R. Lauzon, who will be stuck with his summer stock, laid in for the usual influx of tourists. He looked at a rack full of unsold fishing poles. ``I'm friends with everybody, but I'm still losing one-third of my business. There are others who are worse off, some with 50-75 percent losses.'' One of those is Michel Beaulnes, proprietor of the highly rated Clementine restaurant, which has shut down completely. The troubles drove away his upscale Montreal clientele, who once flocked to the riverfront restaurant for stuffed rabbit back, sweetbreads in port sauce or pheasant breast with black current sauce. Oka feels like a ghost town, not deserted but too quiet. With negotiations in progress between the Mohawks and the provincial and federal governments, an uneasy calm has returned. On the barricades, an old man and two young cohorts sat in a pickup truck, guarding the hilltop Mohawk barrier. The military-type bunkers to the side appeared unmanned. Below, only three squad cars were at the police barricade. But police are omnipresent everywhere else. Every third vehicle is a police car, snack bars are full of uniformed men gnawing on hot dogs and the cheese-french fries concoction known as poutine. Patry blames the problems here on a combination of Kanasatake Mohawks who are unable to solve their leadership problems and the federal government whose attempts at negotiation have been less than serious. The golf course problem is solved. The federal government announced it would buy the land and turn it over to the Indians. But the matter of Indian land claims goes far beyond Oka. ``Are we trying to solve the problems of Alberta and Manitoba here?'' Patry asked. ``It's sad it all had to happen here, in this peaceful little town.'' ``People are angry at the Mohawks, but it's not the Mohawks, it's the Warriors,'' said resident Isidore Arsonault, referring to the militant Warrior Society. Arsonault, however, said he was hopeful that ``in one week it will be over.'' Minutes after he made his prediction, a car with two Indians in it approached the barricade. ``Go back where you belong,'' shouted one angry man, thumping on the hood and waving his half-empty beer bottle. ``Do you speak French? You don't even speak French. Get out of here.'' He did not find much support among 100 people at the scene, but neither did he receive condemnation.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Visits Troops, Wishes Them `Good Luck'
With PM-Cheney-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's naval barricade of Iraq, in response to that country's invasion of Kuwait, has gone multilingual. The shotgun-toting U.S. sailors who have been specially trained to board ships heading to and from Iraq have been issued more than radios, guns and grappling hooks. They also carry laminated yellow cards in French, Arabic and English. Besides telling crews that their ships are being inspected for cargo intended for Iraq or Kuwait, the cards tell them: ``Remain calm; avoid confrontation. ... If fighting starts in your area, drop to the deck with your hands outstretched and remain silent. ... Follow all instructions. You will be taken to a safe place. Cooperate and no harm will come to you.''

Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was flown from the carrier Eisenhower in the Red Sea to the destroyer USS Scott, which had just come off interdiction duty near the mouth of the Gulf of Aqaba. He was ushered into the wood-paneled stateroom that usually serves as the commanding officer's suite but had been transformed into the ship's ``war room.'' The officers papered the wall with shipping charts of the Red Sea and Persian Gulf, filling the map's waterways with small slips of paper indicating U.S. warships' positions. U.S. ground troops were marked with red dots. The northeastern region of Saudi Arabia _ a possible Iraqi invasion route into the Saudi oil fields _ had been transformed into a near-solid glob of red.

Below decks on the USS Scott, the defense secretary made a point of spending some time with the cooks, machine toolers and engineers who made the ship both a home and a finely tuned war machine. As the secretary walked through the narrow corridors, a few adventurous sailors came forward and asked that their pictures be taken with them. Cheney, wearing a navy blue USS Scott cap, eagerly complied over and over. One sailor had a particular mission, because he and the defense secretary had names that are pronounced alike, even though they are spelled differently. Cheney chatted with the food service worker for a time, shook his hand and then autographed a photo of the ship. Asked what the secretary scribbled, the seaman broke out in a big smile and replied, ``He wrote, `Good Luck.' And boy, that's the right thing to wish us now.''

The Scott's captain, Cmdr. Tom Corcoran, said the first alert for the vessel to get from the Mediterranean to the Red Sea led to a frenzy of activity, of loading supplies and fuel on his guided missile destroyer and transferring missiles at sea from the Eisenhower. Other officers on board the ship reported that Corcoran remained at his post on the bridge guiding the rush of activity for 18 hours straight. ``We've had the most incredible ten days of my life,'' the commander said. ``Everyone's responded and nobody's tired.'' Upon hearing that, a lieutenant and several sailors standing behind the commander broke out in loud guffaws, and Corcoran sheepishly joined in.

The men of the Eisenhower battle group had begun to think they'd be home soon, since their six months at sea were nearly up. They'd even begun writing letters to their wives and families that they'd be back in their home port of Norfolk, Va., in early September. But as it often does, trouble intervened. ``I last talked with my wife on Aug. 5, when I thought I'd be home in September,'' said Lt.j.g. Paul Drennan, a propulsion officer on the Scott. ``The next day, we were heading into the Red Sea, and I don't know when I'll talk to her _ let alone see her _ now.''

Cheney's visit to combat troops at a windswept and sweltering air base in Saudi Arabia posed a particularly interesting problem for defense specialists. As Cheney moved swiftly from camouflaged tent to tank to command center, several dozen reporters, television cameramen and photographers raced after him, jumping over tent wires, ammunition boxes _ anything and everyone, no matter how lethally armed _ in their attempt to glean a word or picture of the secretary's visit with the troops. It took some time before the military officers restored any semblance of order, leaving the impression that defending Cheney from the queries of news-hungry journalists might be akin to defending Saudi Arabia from Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Midwest Corn a Candidate to Replace Middle East Oil
DOC.TEXT: Midwest corn fields are getting a chance to pinch hit for Middle East oil fields. The U.S. Energy Department has recommended stepped-up production of ethanol, a corn-based moonshine that is blended with gasoline to make cleaner-burning gasohol. The call for more ethanol is part of a scramble to ease the loss of Middle East oil arising from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait this month. Gasohol is approved for use in most vehicles, and proponents say its time has come. ``There's no question in my mind it's the logical thing to do,'' said Wayne Ryan, who raises corn near Wapello, in southeastern Iowa. Since ethanol was introduced in 1978, more than 800 million miles have been traveled using ethanol blends, according to the Iowa Corn Promotion Board. Gasohol is 10 percent ethanol. ``Every year there's a new crop, but every time you take a barrel of oil out of a domestic oil well it is closer to running dry,'' said Marty Andreas, a vice president at Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. ADM of Decatur, Ill., the nation's largest ethanol processor. A bushel of corn produces about 2{ gallons of ethanol. Last year, about 1 billion gallons of ethanol were produced nationwide from more than 360 million bushels of corn. The government estimates U.S. farmers will harvest 7.85 billion bushels of corn this fall. One out of every five bushels will come from Iowa, the nation's leading corn producer. ``It's renewable, it's domestic and ethanol is benign,'' Andreas said. He said the Energy Department on Wednesday asked ethanol industry officials how much idle capacity could be brought into production and was told that an additional 150 million to 175 million gallons could be produced each year. Despite the increase in gasohol interest, some warn that ethanol cannot shoulder the nation's fuel burden. The 1 billion gallons of ethanol produced last year compares with 115 billion gallons of gasoline consumed in the United States, said David Zinanon, vice president of Petroleum Industries Research Associates, a New York consulting firm. Even if ethanol production rises substantially in the years ahead, it will remain only a small part of the U.S. energy picture, he said. Still, ethanol has a strong cadre of supporters, who list its benefits: _ Increased reliance on domestic fuels would help shrink the nation's trade deficit and its dependence on foreign suppliers. The United States imports more than half its oil. In the first five months of 1990, Iraq accounted for 7.4 percent of U.S. oil imports, according to the American Petroleum Institute. _ With 10 percent ethanol, gasoline burns cleaner, reducing hazardous emissions of carbon monoxide, the government said. Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico and Nevada have programs that rely on ethanol blends to reduce pollution. _ A major byproduct of ethanol production is corn gluten feed, a protein supplement for livestock feed that is in demand at home and abroad. Andreas said the industry needs an extension in federal tax subsidies to maintain what has been a marginally profitable business. The tax break forgives 6 cents of a 9-cent federal excise tax on each gallon of ethanol sold by an oil company. The subsidy is set to expire in three years. R.G. Ensz, a spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, said ethanol production is not profitable without the tax break. He added that studies disagree on whether ethanol production is energy-efficient. He said the energy used in transporting and processing the fuel, together with the fuel used by tractors and other equipment in working the corn fields, ``can use up as much energy as you make.'' But Ryan said he uses 23 gallons of diesel and some petroleum in nitrogen fertilizer to cultivate and harvest each acre, which brings enough corn to produce 250 to 300 gallons of ethanol.

DOC.HEAD: Rolling Stones Delight Fans In Prague
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th pvs, `While the ...' to CORRECT song title. Pickup 7th pvs, `Shortly before...'
DOC.TEXT: Rock fans of all generations climbed a Prague hill and ignored a pouring rain Sunday to hear the Rolling Stones, a band once vilified by the Communist government as a capitalist money-making machine. ``What's a little acid rain between friends,'' quipped lead singer Mick Jagger when the summer rain began falling on the crowd of 110,000 during the Saturday night show. He used his newly acquired Czech to occassionally address the crowd between songs. Several teen-age girls had to be carried away on stretchers after fainting during the six-hour wait for the group at Strahov Stadium. Shortly before midnight, an anonymous caller told the event's organizers that a bomb had been planted in the stadium. While the group played ``Jumpin' Jack Flash,'' about 100 policemen searched the gigantic stage structure but found no evidence of explosives. Shortly before the performance, the Rolling Stones were received by President Vaclav Havel at Hradcany castle. The former dissident playwright became president in December after a peaceful revolution toppled the country's hard-line Communist leaders. ``In the conversation with Mick Jagger and other members of the band, the president expressed his joy over the fact that the concert is taking place and spoke of the role rock music played in the events leading to the November revolution and the revolution itself,'' the Czechoslovak news agency CTK reported. Proceeds from the concert are to go to the Czechoslovak Children's Foundation set up by Olga Havlova, the president's wife. ``I have listened to their music very often ... songs like `Satisfaction' are hard to forget, and if their show is at least half as good as people say, I can't wait to see them live with my very own eyes,'' Havel told Rock & Pop magazine earlier. The playwright-turned president is a well-known supporter of the arts. One of his close advisers, Michael Kocab, a former rock star, was also present at the meeting. ``I told Mick I used to do rock 'n' roll too, but now I am more into heavy metal,'' said Kocab, a parliamentary deputy who is overseeing the withdrawal of Soviet tanks from Czechoslovakia. Another parliamentary deputy, veteran rock singer Vladimir Misik, opened the concert with his band, ETC. In the early 1980s, the band was banned from performing in Czechoslovakia. ``It borders on science fiction out there, we all started shaking only after the show,'' Misik said, as he popped open a bottle of champagne, a gift from the Rolling Stones to his band. Listening to ETC backstage, Bobby Keyes, a saxophone player currently playing with the Rolling Stones, said: ``It's very good stuff, considering those guys had to work in such terrible conditions all their lives.'' Chuck Leavell, a keyboard player, added: ``The people seem to understand what rock 'n' roll is about.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: After Three Months, Budget Summit Gets Nowhere
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Bill Frenzel always seems disgruntled. It's just the nature of the senior Minnesota Republican. So when Frenzel released his recent recap of this year's budget talks, it was no surprise to see it titled, ``Diary of a Disgruntled Summiteer.'' But glancing through his notes and comments would make most citizens disgruntled too. Seen as a whole, the three-month old budget summit is clearly less than the sum of the hot rhetoric that has surrounded it. Frenzel, the senior Republican on the House Budget Committee, recalls back in early May how President Bush issued his ``no preconditions'' statement _ the first hint that Bush was abandoning his pledge not to raise taxes. ``Now things should move,'' Frenzel says. But, of course, they didn't. The diary is loaded with recitations of the daily crises that seem ridiculous in retrospect but which, at every turn, threatened to derail the negotiations. ``Perhaps both sides can settle down to serious bargaining ... Looking for a jump start ... It is an opening bid to get things moving ... A sign of progress,'' he writes at various points. As the talks got older, the two sides seemed to meet more and accomplish less. ``Closed summit meeting produces hot words and no discernible progress,'' Frenzel notes for July 19. Sometimes the debate takes on an almost absurd quality. For example, in meetings on May 22 and May 24, the negotiators ``decide NOT to decide on a $50 billion (deficit reduction) target for this year's package and $500 billion over five years.'' Two months later, on July 24 _ ``Whoopee'' _ the group decides those goals are okay. What happened in the intervening weeks? The budget situation got worse, of course. New administration estimates show red ink in fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1, will be near $170 billion _ not including the cost of the savings and loan bailout. The $50 billion deficit-reduction goal for next year seems modest indeed. But does that drive the negotiators closer to a solution? ``No meetings, no progress,'' Frenzel says of the last days before Congress departed for its summer recess. Curmudgeonly and partisan, Frenzel naturally blames the Democrats for most of the problems in the talks. And the central message of his diary isn't really news. Even a casual follower of Washington's ways knows that the budget summit has been a flop. The Frenzel diary could easily be discounted as yet another GOP attempt to set the foundation for pinning the eventual failure of the talks on the Democrats who control Congress. Bush has made several clumsy attempts, and the Democrats have, of course, tried to return the favor. But what's truly disheartening about the diary is what isn't in there. At no point does Frenzel mention any pressure from the public on the negotiators to get their job done. If anything, it alludes to lawmakers' reactions to public demands not to raise taxes and not to cut their benefits. That's been the formula for stalemate for years. The negotiators will resume their efforts next month, possibly with a private retreat away from the pressures of inquiring reporters, lobbyists, and others who might distract from the task at hand. But after three months of relatively little public pressure, why would further insulating the negotiators make an agreement more likely? Frenzel is stepping off the treadmill, retiring from the seat he first won in 1970, so his political future doesn't ride much on the outcome of the talks. He's been mentioned as a possible future secretary of commerce because of his expertise in trade as a member of the Ways and Means Committee. With no re-election campaign at stake, Frenzel's frustration may actually stem from his desire to get something done about the deficit before leaving Congress. Taking readings on his disgruntlement may be one way to monitor the progress of the talks ahead.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Steven Komarow covers Congress for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Spokeswoman: No Release Date Discussed for Atwater
DOC.TEXT: Physicians treating Lee Atwater have not decided when to release the Republican National Committee chairman from the hospital, a spokeswoman says. ``There is no release date and ... I have heard no discussion of that,'' Leslie Goodman, the RNC spokeswoman, said on Sunday. Atwater has been undergoing radiation therapy at a Washington hospital since Wednesday for brain tumor ``progression.'' Published reports had indicated that physicians found a new tumor in the brain of the 39-year-old South Carolinian. But Goodman has said doctors were not specific about whether Atwater was afflicted with a new tumor or the recurrence of a previous one. Atwater, who gained prominence in national political circles when he directed President Bush's 1988 campaign, underwent brain tumor surgery on April 3. He has since been in and out of the hospital repeatedly for treatment of ailments ranging from a blood clot in his leg to a nagging fever. Atwater was described as alert and said to be receiving visitors following therapy. Goodman said Sunday that his condition was ``unchanged.''
DOC.HEAD: NAACP, Other Groups To Fight Social Problems
DOC.TEXT: The NAACP and more than 100 other organizations ranging from law enforcement to religious groups have formed a coalition to battle nagging social ills in black communities. The group, calling itself the National Association of Black Organizations, grew out of a three-day ``Summit Conference of Black Organizations'' in Washington assembled by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Coalition members, which include groups as varied as the National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives and the Progressive National Baptist Convention, will focus their efforts on such problems as teen-age pregnancy, school dropouts and other social problems. NAACP Executive Director Benjamin Hooks said the coalition is designed to enhance the ``continuing struggle of African Americans to gain a fair share of the American dream.'' The organization's plans call for establishment of a communications network to share information, development of a brain trust to research and make recommendations on social and economic concerns affecting blacks, spreading of effective self-help initiatives, and development of strategies to strengthen support for black institutions. The NAACP moves in a new direction with the formation of the coalition. The nation's preeminent civil rights organization has traditionally focused on legislation and litigation. ``What we have accomplished here is but a beginning,'' Hooks said. ``It marks the start of a new approach, where the visible payoff is farther down the road.'' Hooks said the NAACP does not intend to turn from its historical focus. But he said the 81-year-old group also realizes the need for black organizations to address problems facing blacks. ``We as black people are stepping up to the bat and saying we are taking responsibility for our own destiny,'' Hooks said. He said the coalition's nine-member executive committee would meet within two weeks to work out further details. The conference concluded Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: 14 Killed, 8 Wounded in Market Attack
DOC.TEXT: Members of one family fired at a rival clan in a town market, killing 14 people and wounding eight, the military says. A military report Sunday said the incident, which involved the two feuding Moslem families of Pangilan and Jafani, occurred in the town of Parang in Sulu province, 600 miles south of Manila. The report said Pangilan men apparently attacked to avenge the killing of their relatives in October by the other group. The casualties of Friday's rampage included an undetermined number of bystanders besides Jafani family members, the report said. Clan clashes, kidnappings and attacks from Moslem separatists and Communist guerrillas are rampant in several parts of Mindanao island, including Sulu.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Reported Hijacked in Soviet Union, Bound for India
DOC.TEXT: An airliner was reported hijacked Monday from Tashkent in the Soviet Union and was heading to New Delhi, an airport official said. ``We have started our emergency drill,'' said an official in the airport manager's office who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said the airport had received messages that an airliner was hijacked from Tashkent and would be landing in New Delhi, the Indian capital. He said he had no further information. A Soviet Embassy spokesman said he was unaware of the report.

DOC.HEAD: Shipping Radios Crackling With U.S. Warship Challenges
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Shipping radios crackled today with the sound of U.S. warships challenging almost every commercial vessel in the southern Persian Gulf, shipping executives reported. But at midday, there were no Iraqi vessels in the area. ``Even the two Iraqi freighters that were anchored there for days are no longer around,'' said one of the executives, referring to the Al-Abid and Al-Baya. The shipping executives said they believed that Baghdad ordered Iraqi shipping away from the area while U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was visiting the United Arab Emirates, where he arrived early today from Bahrain. Two Iraqi freighters last week were refused entry by United Arab Emirates ports on the gulf, while two Iraqi tankers were refused entry by Saudi Arabia on the Red Sea, on the other side of the Arabian Peninsula. The four vessels were anchored in international waters off both coasts. The shipping standoff escalated with the first warning shots fired Saturday by U.S. warships at two Iraqi tankers that refused to stop for inspection as they were sailing out the Strait of Hormuz at the mouth of the Persian Gulf. The two tankers, the 36,397-ton Baba Gurgur and the 35,338-ton Khanaqin, were empty. ``Saddam Hussein must have just sent them sailing down to test the U.S. reaction after (U.S. President) George Bush's order to use force if necessary in the so-called interdiction,'' said one of the shipping sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. The U.S.-led interdiction effort is an outgrowth of the U.N. trade embargo imposed on Iraq after its Aug. 2 invasion and subsequent annexation of Kuwait. ``This is U.S. Navy warship, this is U.S. Navy warship,'' one of the warships was overheard to radio today on the VHF channel that was being monitored. Then it asked for last port of call and destination. ``They are calling every vessel, every tanker,'' said one of the shipping executives. ``It's all going on normally, with all the ships cooperating.'' He said the only problem was when sailors could not understand English. In those cases, they would call the captain to continue the exchange in English, the international maritime language. Most vessels contacted were tankers sailing to and from the Saudi Arabian oil terminal of Ras Tanura, and other Saudi ports. ``Thank you for your cooperation,'' the U.S. warships were invariably responding as they ended one radio challenge to turn to the other. The shipping executives said the radio contacts were begun this morning by the British warships, allies of the United States in the interdiction effort. Then the Americans took over later in the day.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors in Jogger Case Say Mood Was Often Tense, But Panel Not Racially Split
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in the Central Park jogger case said the mood in the jury room was often tense, but they were never split along racial lines. ``The first thing we did in the jury room was to decide whether or not this case had racial overtones and we all decided it did not. That cleared the air,'' jury foreman Earle Fisher said. Over the next 10 days, the panel _ made up of four blacks, four whites, three Hispanics and one Asian _ considered the charges against three of six youths charged with brutally attacking a female jogger who was raped, beaten and left for dead. The verdicts were announced Saturday evening. Yusef Salaam, 16, Antron McCray, 16, and Raymond Santana, 15, were convicted of rape, assault, robbery and riot, but acquitted of attempted murder and sodomy. Sentencing was set for Sept. 11. They will be sentenced as juvenile offenders and face a maximum of up to 10 years in prison. All three defense attorneys promised to appeal. Three other defendants, Kharey Wise, 18, Kevin Richardson, 15, and Steven Lopez, 16, go on trial next month. Juror Rafael Miranda said the mood in the jury room was often tense, with ``a lot of screaming, and a lot of names called.'' But Miranda said the jury never divided along racial lines during the deliberations. For the final three days, one juror held out against convicting McCray. Juror Ron Gold told The New York Times he felt ``terrible'' when he finally went along with the others and convicted McCray of rape and assault. The anonymous victim became a national figure as she recovered from the savage assault by a rampaging youth gang during her nightly run on April 19, 1989. She took the stand during the trial, testifying that she did not remember the attack but describing the lingering physical problems, inluding impaired vision and balane, and the loss of her sense of smell. ``We noticed that she had trouble walking, we noticed that she had trouble speaking,'' said juror Migdalia Fuentes. ``We knew that she would never be the same, that she would never enjoy life in the same way.'' Fuentes said the jogger's appearance on the stand ``showed a lot of courage.'' Jurors said the acquitted the youths of attempted murder because they did not think the youths intended to kill the jogger. Juror Charles Nestorick said the attempted murder charges ``gave us a lot of difficulty because she had really been beaten.'' But he said the jurors felt the teens didn't realize how badly they had hurt her. ``Youths that age are not well versed in how many blows it takes to kill someone,'' he said. After three days of deliberating on nothing but the attempted murder charges, ``we saw that we couldn't prove intent,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister Quits, Social Democrats Bolt Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with de Maiziere saying he will also act as foreign minister. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `De Maiziere...'
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's embattled prime minister said today he will also act as foreign minister following the resignation of the country's top diplomat. Lothar de Maiziere told a news conference in East Berlin he was taking the action to keep the process of German unification on track. Foreign Minister Markus Meckel quit earlier today after his political party bolted from the broad governing coalition formed to lead the nation to unity with West Germany. Meckel, a top-ranking member of the left-leaning Social Democrats, is the fifth minister to leave the coalition in a week. De Maiziere previously dismissed four other ministers in a political dispute that led to the Social Democrats' decision to leave the coalition formed after the nation's first free elections on March 18. The Social Democrats, the second-biggest party in Parliament, voted on Sunday to leave the government and vowed to speed the process of German unity. The party said it would seek a vote in Parliament on Wednesday to advance the date for German unification to mid-September. ``There is hardly another alternative,'' said the Social Democrats' deputy chairman, Karl-August Kamilli. The Social Democrats were the second-largest party in the coalition led by de Maiziere's conservative Christian Democrats. Pressure has been building in East Germany to unify quickly with West Germany so the richer country can deal directly with the former Communist country's difficult transition to the free market. The Social Democrats in both Germanys also want unification to take place much sooner than elections so West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl can be held accountable at the voting booth for the costs of bailing out East Germany. East Germany can invoke a clause in the West German constitution and unite with West Germany at any time. De Maiziere and Kohl have been trying to keep the election date and the unification date close together. German unification is now tentatively set for Oct. 14, with all-German elections to be held on Dec. 2. The East German Social Democrats had been threatening to leave the coalition for weeks. A smaller Liberal alliance left the government earlier this month. The bickering peaked last week when de Maiziere unilaterally fired four ministers in his Cabinet, three of whom dealt with the nation's crumbling economy. The Social Democrats accused de Maiziere of firing the ministers to protect his party politically when voters in both nations choose which party will lead a united Germany. The Social Democrats are closely allied with the West German Social Democrats, the main opposition to Kohl. Kohl, like de Maiziere, is a Christian Democrat. The departure of the Social Democrats will not derail the process of merging the two Germanys. But it does solidify the party's role as an opposition force in East Germany. All major East German parties are committed to unification but they differ sharply on a timetable and on the details of a state treaty that is to mesh the laws of the two Germanys. The collapse of the broad, politically diverse coalition chosen after East Germany's first free elections on March 18 is yet another psychological blow to a nation already reeling from a hemorrhaging economy. Joblessness and prices has skyrocketed ever since the nation shed four decades of socialism for the free market on July 1 by merging its economy with West Germany's. The Social Democrats rebuffed de Maiziere's last-minute offer to discuss their differences. The prime minister said he made the offer ``because we in the interests of the people of East Germany must solve our difficult problems together.'' He called the Social Democrats' decision a ``flight from responsibility.' With the loss of the Social Democrats, de Maiziere will lack the guaranteed two-thirds majority in Parliament needed to approve the unification treaty with West Germany. Kohl's government has warned that that could mean that West German laws would be imposed unilaterally on East Germany. The treaty being negotiated now seeks to preserve some East German laws. The country, for example, has tougher drunken driving rules and more liberal abortion laws.

DOC.HEAD: Girl in Baby Swap Case Meets Biological Parents and Siblings
DOC.TEXT: An 11-year-old girl at the center of a hospital baby-swap case has met the couple proven through genetic tests to be her parents. But Kimberly Mays is still confused by the legal tug-of-war and all the attention from a family she never knew, her grandmother told the St. Petersburg Times in an article published Saturday. The long-awaited meeting between the Sarasota girl and her biological parents, Ernest and Regina Twigg, took place quietly last spring at a miniature golf course in Sarasota. The Twiggs and Robert Mays, who raised Kimberly as his daughter, decided to keep the visit secret to avoid the crush of reporters and photographers who have followed thi? h?
????oughq-L,

????????n at a tiny rural hospital in central Florida, went 4???????bx????ho died of cancer in 1981. The girl born to the Mayses, whom the Twiggs named Arlena, died`of a heart defect two years ago. During an initial rendezvous and two subsequent meetings, Kimberly also was introduced to her seven brothers and sisters. ``??|???ly with the kids it went very good. But when you ask about the parents, she just puts her hands up in the air and shakes them,'' said Velma Coker, one of Kimberly's grandmothers. ``She's still mixed-up,'' Mrs. Coker said. The Twiggs learned through a blood test that Arlena couldn't be their daughter shortly before she died. Searching for their biological daughter, the Twiggs learned that Mrs. Mays had delivered a daughter within a couple of days of Arlena's birth at the same hospital, Hardee Memorial in Wauchula. The babies were the only two white girls born about the time at the hospital. It wasn't until genetic tests last fall that it was confirmed that the families had raised each other's daughters. Mays agreed to the tests after the Twiggs promised they wouldn't seek custody no matter what the tests showed. Mays has since joined the Twiggs in a lawsuit against Hardee Memorial Hospital. Efforts to reach Mays and the Twiggs over the weekend for further comment were unsuccessful; both families have unlisted telephone numbers.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Says Not Enough Support to Hold Emergency Meeting
DOC.TEXT: OPEC said today there was not enough support among its members to call an emergency meeting to consider Saudi Arabia's request to boost oil production. A brief statement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said its president, Algerian Mines Minister Sadek Boussena, would meet with some other oil ministers before the end of the month to discuss the situation. It did not elaborate. Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Hisham Nazer, said Saturday his country would boost oil production by as much as 2 million barrels a day with or without the support of OPEC. He had urged the cartel to hold a special session to try to take measures to bring down oil prices, which have soared because of the Middle East crisis. But the statement issued by OPEC's headquarters in Vienna said that ``an extraordinary meeting of the OPEC conference has not been able to secure the necessary support'' of seven of the group's 13 members. ``An extraordinary meeting of the OPEC conference will, consequently, not be held,'' the statement said. Saudi Arabia's pledge to increase its production by as much as 2 million barrels a day would make up about half of the crude lost to world markets because of the international embargo on oil shipments from Iraq and Kuwait. The kingdom, the world's No. 1 oil exporter, was pumping about 5.3 million barrels of oil a day at the end of July, according to the International Energy Agency.

DOC.HEAD: Wire Company Executives on Trial For Alleged Worker Injuries
DOC.TEXT: A suburban Chicago wire manufacturer criminally exposed 43 workers to toxic chemicals, say prosecutors trying the case in Cook County Court. Chicago Magnet Wire Co. employees suffered severe headaches, dizziness, vomiting, kidney problems, memory loss and impotence after working at the plant, prosecutors charge. Temperatures reached 120 degrees and ventilation was poor, they say. Chicago Magnet of northwest suburban Elk Grove Village is the second company in Illinois history to be charged with criminal responsibility for alleged job-related injuries sustained by its workers. But defense attorneys contend conditions at the wire coating plant were safe and complied with federal standards. ``We don't think they have a case,'' said Harvey Silets, one of five defense attorneys. ``We don't think anyone was really injured. The facility operated within the standards set by the federal government.'' Five current or former top-level managers are charged with aggravated battery, reckless conduct and conspiracy. Prosecutors allege they lied about potential hazards to employees, many of whom spoke only Spanish, and failed to provide protective gear. On the first day of testimony last week, six years after charges were filed, assistant state's attorney Frank Parkerson called working conditions at the plant ``slow torture.'' He argued that company officials are guilty of violence akin to street crimes, except in this case, the offenders were ``individuals wearing ties.'' Defense attorney Patrick Tuite said plant inspections in 1983 by the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration and an insurance company failed to find unhealthful conditions. Prosecutors allege that plant officials had been told of the OSHA inspection two weeks in advance and were able to hide or correct hazardous conditions. On trial in Cook County Criminal Court are Anthony Jordan, the company's former president; former plant manager Kevin Keane; Frank Asta, who was head of maintenance; Allan Simon, then a plant engineer; and Gerald Colby, then in charge of quality control, maintenance and engineering. Asta and Colby are the only defendants who still work at the plant. The case is being heard by Criminal Court Judge Earl Strayhorn, who dismissed the charges in 1985. They were reinstated by the state Supreme Court in February 1989. In the first such case in Illinois, three executives of Film Recovery Systems Inc. were convicted of murder in the cyanide poisoning death of a worker. The Illinois Appellate Court reversed the verdict on a technicality in January and ordered a retrial. No trial date has been set.

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Seabrook Nuclear Plant Begins Regular Operation
DOC.TEXT: The Seabrook nuclear power plant has ended five months of reactor tests and has begun regular operation to supply electricity to New England, a spokesman said today. The tests ended Friday night, and after a review Saturday determined that the final round of tests had been successful, regular operation began at 12:01 a.m. Sunday, spokesman Ron Sher said. The tests began March 20, and the plant has been operating at 100 percent during the past few weeks of final testing. It has been generating power for New England residents since first connected to the region's electrical power grid on May 29, as its systems were tested. The $6.5 billion plant, whose constrution was bitterly protested by anti-nulear activists, is producing 1,150 megawatts of electricity, enough to supply 1 million homes and eliminate the need for about 1.5 million barrels of oil a month, plant operator New Hampshire Yankee says. New Hampshire Yankee Senior Vice President Ted Feigenbaum said Iraq's invasion of oil-rich Kuwait makes it ``painfully clear that New England must immediately begin vigorous development of alternative domestic energy sources that are not dependent opon events halfway around the world.'' Sher said it will be up to each of the plant's utility owners and utility regulators in their states to decide how Seabrook's power will be reflected in power bills. Critics of the plant, located near the Massachusetts border, said it should not have been built because the area around the plant could not be evacuated quickly enough in the event of an accident.

DOC.HEAD: Evacuations Begun After High Water Threatens to Break Indiana Dam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with rain falling, but only intermittently, other detail. Picks up 5th graf pvs: `Early Sunday...'. ADDS 4 grafs at end with similar dam situation in Wisconsin. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Officials kept a wary eye on the sky and on a leaking dam after workers laboring under emergency lights sandbagged a leaky dam early today to protect homes from a rain-swollen lake. Heavy rain and the threat of a dam break forced the evacuation of a hospital and apartments for the elderly Sunday, and residents in the sparsely populated area below the dam were advised to leave or get ready to evacuate. A flash flood watch was posted today for the northern third of Indiana, including the Rochester area. But as of midmorning, the rain was intermittent. ``The dam is holding its own right now,'' said Lisa Carr, a dispatcher with the Fulton County Sheriff's Department. ``At this point, we're just keeping our fingers crossed.'' ``If we don't get any more rain, we'll be all right,'' Mayor Philip Thompson had said earlier. Workers Sunday night and early today at Lake Manitou hauled sandbags and rock to shore up the 5-foot-high earth and concrete dam, then called it quits, leaving volunteers and state officials to watch for signs of deterioration. Carr said sandbagging efforts had not resumed as of midmorning, but added: ``If anything should happen, we'll be out there again.'' Early Sunday, 50 to 75 people were evacuated from the Waterhaven Apartments, and 26 of the 28 patients at Woodlawn Hospital were moved to a nursing home and a gym. Lake Manitou is about 12 feet above Mill Creek, which flows along the eastern edge of Rochester, a town of 5,000 in north-central Indiana. A complete failure of the 42-year-old dam could raise Mill Creek by 6 feet, the weather service said. It would crest in Rochester within a half hour. ``The biggest problem it would affect would be our hospital. If the dam was to go out, a large quantity of water would hit it,'' said Robert Bryant, Fulton County chief jailer. At least 1,000 people, including volunteers, fire crews, civil defense officials and groups from two Rochester High School class reunions, filled sandbags and laid about 13,000 along the dam early Sunday, Bryant said. An elderly woman suffered an apparent heart attack during the sandbagging, authorities said. Her condition was not immediately available. Three workers were treated for heat exhaustion. Thompson said two channels were cut to divert lake water and ease pressure on the 150-yard stretch of dam and earthen levee. Bruce C. Murray of the Army Corps of Engineers said Sunday that he believed the dam would hold. Earlier in the weekend, a similar threat faced the west-central Wisconsin town of Tomah. About 1,500 people evacuated their houses when high water threatened to rupture the Lake Tomah Dam on the Lemonweir River. About 700 people stayed out of their homes during the night but were able to return Sunday. Tomah got about 8 inches of rain in three hours late Friday. The dam was reinforced with about 20,000 sandbags and its reservoir dropped eight inches by Saturday night after the floodgates were opened, said Tomah Fire Chief Tom Flock.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.TEXT: President Bush declared today that ``America will not be intimidated'' by an Iraqi regime that imperils international order _ and has trapped about 3,000 U.S. citizens in Kuwait and Iraq. Denouncing the invasion of Kuwait, Bush said a country that uses ``citizens as pawns'' will face the scorn and condemnation of the entire world. He said his message to Iraq is to ``release all foreigners now, give them the right to come and go as they wish.'' MORE

DOC.HEAD: Marines Confident of Coping With Whatever Desert Deployment Brings
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Marines here are confident they can cope with whatever problems they face, despite punishing conditions and logistical challenges, a commanding general said today. ``We are ready to do whatever we need to do,'' said Maj. Gen. John Hopkins, head of the 7th Marine Expeditionary Brigade based in Twentynine Palms, Calif. The brigade has deployed in a commercial port and surrounding desert in the eastern province of Saudi Arabia. For security reasons, the Defense Department has barred reporters from disclosing specific information such as the number of Marines in Saudi Arabia, their location and the number of weapons they carrying. So far about 90 percent of the equipment the brigade needs has flowed into Saudi Arabia, Hopkins told reporters. ``We're not battle-ready right this moment, but we'll be ready pretty shortly,'' he said. Although the brigade trained in the Mojave Desert, Hopkins said even he was overwhelmed by the vastness of the Arabian desert, where tempertures routinely soar to 130 degrees. ``We are going through growing pains, and all the troops are getting acclimatized,'' he said, adding he feels ``damn confident.'' The equipment the Marines brought with them will enable them to fight on land in the air. The brigade has carried weapons for every conceivable wartime situation including: M-60 tanks, high utility multipurpose vehicles; Howitzers; TOW missiles; 40 milimeter grenade launchers; Harrier jets; Cobra helicopters equipped with sidewinder missiles and TOWs; Huey helicopters for command and control; CH-46 _ so-called Sea Knights _ to transport people, and wide-bellied C-150 transport planes. All told, five cargo ships _ some were based in the Pacific Island of Diego Garcia _ will unload materiel for the brigade. Most of the equipment, including the helicopters, has to be reasembled on the ground. It is the first time since formation of the preposition program in 1979 that it has been used in a contingency situation, officials said. But a brigade typically has about 16,500 men. Pentagon officials have said as many as 45,000 Marines could end up in the desert kingdom. Expeditionary units are designed to become combat-capable in 10 days and sustain itself for 30 days without resupply. The ground combat Marines have been sent to the desert, where they have set up tents covered by camoflauge netting to escape the sun and avoid detection from above. Aviators and maintenance crews are working 16 hours to 18 hours a day to ready their craft and learn the terrain. Despite harsh conditions, Lt. Col. M.M. Kurth said there was a ``sense of excitement'' among Marines, who are eager to try out what they've learned in real life. ``Morale is very high,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Food Stamp and Welfare Rolls Rising Dramatically
DOC.TEXT: A large jump in the number of people eligible for food stamps and welfare benefits this year is costing states and the federal government billions of dollars, a published report said today. At least 44 states have reported increases in enrollment, with some rising up to 50 percent, according to an Agriculture Department report quoted in The New York Times. The number of people receiving food stamps rose by 1.3 million from May 1989 to May 1990, when it topped 20 million for the first time since 1985, found a report submitted to Congress by the Agriculture Department. The department, which administers the food stamp program, noted that food stamp rolls have risen 16 percent in the last year in Texas, 19 percent in Florida, 26 percent in Nevada, 54 percent in New Hampshire, 12 percent each in Georgia and Massachusetts, 7 percent each in New York State and California, and 21 percent in Connecticut. Congress appropriated $14.8 billion, but that proved inadequate and it had to provide an additional $1.2 billion in May. It then directed the Agriculture Department to investigate the causes. The department report said that ``44 states and the District of Columbia experienced a growth in participation'' in the food stamp program over the last year, while the nation's unemployment rate was relatively stable. It also said, ``Many states are showing signs of economic slowdown that are not reflected in national economic indicators.'' The Times said Michigan even blamed the increase in welfare caseload on a state ban on Medicaid-financed abortions. F. Charles Peller, a spokesman for the state's Department of Social Services, reported ``a startling increase'' in the number of Aid to Families with Dependent Children program cases about a year after the ban took effect. The newspaper said federal and state authorities also believe tne numbers of welfare and food stamp recipients rose after Congress made changes in the Medicaid program which made the welfare system more accessible to some women. And authorities also note that some states such as Texas are aggressively trying to make social welfare benefits and services more available by simplifying application forms and allowing potential participants to apply for multiple programs at a single site. In addition, federal officials say some increase in food stamp rolls may have resulted from the immigration law under which thousands of illegal aliens have gained legal status since 1987.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Central Park Jogger, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0452,0899
DOC.HEAD: Jogger Case Touches Raw Nerve in New York City
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 5th graf pvs, `A jury...', to UPDATE with firm issuing jogger's `no-comment', quote attributed to her by newspaper. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Calvin O. ...'.
DOC.TEXT: The Central Park jogger case touched raw nerves among New Yorkers from the time the victim was found close to death in a puddle of mud and blood until the jury pronounced its verdict. People were horrified by the viciousness of the attack in April. New Yorkers were inspired by the victim's recovery and cheered by reports of her high-fiving a nurse. ``As a woman, I can't tell you how much my heart goes out to her,'' Gina Smith, a 33-year-old neighbor, said at the time. ``I just hope God does his best for her.'' Feelings of horror about the crime soon turned to deep anger, much of it toward the suspects. And because the victim was a white investment banker and the suspects were black youngsters, there were charges that the media and criminal justice system had found them guilty even before they appeared in court. A jury on Saturday found three teen-agers guilty of rape and assault but innocent of the most serious charge, attempted murder. In a statement today on behalf of the jogger, Salomon Brothers spokeswoman Lisa Barowitz said, ``She has no comment as there are still other legal proceedings pending.'' The jogger is a vice president at Salomon Brothers. Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer, who prosecuted the case, also refused to discuss the jogger's reaction to the verdict, saying, ``I respect her privacy.'' The New York Post today quoted an unidentified source as saying the jogger said, ``Thank God this is over'' when she heard the news. ``She was thrilled. She was relieved. She was grateful to the jurors,'' the newspaper quoted the source as saying. ``She called them `wonderful people.''' The trial raised issues of race, sex and class, and the difficulty of maintaining a presumption of innocence in the wake of intense publicity. Calvin O. Butts III, a prominent black minister, said during deliberations that in the days and weeks just after the attack, ``So convincing was the coverage that everyone assumed guilt.'' ``Ninety percent of the people I talked to _ black and white _ thought they were guilty. It was an outrage over the crime,'' he said. ``Only recently ... people began to realize there was some reasonable doubt.'' A week after the attack, Barbara Campbell, a writer on children's issues, said, ``My first reaction had been one of horror that young people had hurt someone so badly. But shortly thereafter I read the news reports that portrayed the children as bestial, with the implication that they were not human, they were animals, and I became angry about that.'' All the elements were there for a big story: The class difference between the victim and the alleged attackers. The brutality and randomness of the attack. Its location in Central Park, the heart of the city. The victim's miraculous recovery and return to work at Salomon Brothers. The young age of the alleged attackers. Others argued that it became headline news simply because the victim was white and the suspects were black. ``There was a feeding frenzy on the part of the white press, electronic as well as print, to bring somebody, anybody to justice,'' said Wilbert Tatum, editor in chief of the Amsterdam News, a major black newspaper in the city. ``It was because of the nature of the profile of the woman who had been attacked and because they were tough black boys rather than young white boys.'' Edwin Diamond, media critic for New York magazine, said coverage of the case, especially by local news stations, was sensational, shallow and unclear _ but not because the media are biased against blacks. ``I believe, had this victim been a black or Hispanic Wellesley-Yale- Salomon Brothers investment banker, it would have been a bigger story,'' he said. ``I don't believe the media is racist but classist and melodramatic.'' The sock-'em-hard headline and soundbite only stir things up and do nothing to clarify a highly charged story like the jogger case, Diamond said.
