The board reversed itself last month and agreed to immediate construction after U.S. Ambassador William Brown sent a note to Communications Minister Rafael Pinhasi, stressing the importance Washington attaches to the project. Justice Ministry spokeswoman Eti Eshed said a three-judge panel of the Supreme Court issued the injunction and ordered the government to respond within 45 days on why the project should be allowed to proceed. The relay station is to transmit VOA broadcasts to Eastern Europe and Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Humor is Respite for Residents of Jittery Persian Gulf Region
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis has frayed nerves, strained alliances and caused gnawing worries about the future. It has also spawned a lot of jokes about Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader who started it all. The humor helps take the edge off the fear. In a Bahrain cafe, an Egyptian pulled up a chair and made the habitual gestures of looking left and right to make sure no secret police were around. Then he poked fun at the Iraqi president's reputation for ruthlessness. ``The other night Saddam reprimanded his son for his poor English. He asked if the boy neaded a private tutor, and the boy named one,'' he began. ``Saddam picked up the phone and issued the order: `Bring along that English language teacher, Ibrahim Ramadan.' Ten hours later, Saddam phoned again and yelled, `Where is that teacher? I ordered you to get him!' ``The intelligence chief replied: `We did, Mr. President. The man confessed and we executed him.'' Large numbers of Egyptians work in the Persian Gulf region, drawn by its oil wealth. The crisis sparked by Saddam's Aug. 2 conquest of Kuwait has given them a chance to indulge in a favorite pastime _ making acid jokes about petty tyrants. Their gibes at Saddam circulate fast in the banking and business center of Bahrain, an island state of 400,000 people. For the Egyptians in the region, the jokes can help them forget their own country's risky role in the crisis. Their president, Hosni Mubarak, led Arab efforts to settle the crisis without outside intervention. When Saddam spurned his efforts, Mubarak sent troops to join the multinational force arrayed against Iraq in Saudi Arabia. Saddam, who took power in 1979, rules Iraq with an iron hand, with a powerful security apparatus to keep his citizens in check. The 54-year-old leader is also at the center of a pervasive personality cult. Iraqi newspapers, television and radio constantly sing his praises. Even children's nursery rhymes hail Saddam. In the small oil-rich states of the gulf _ states not so different from Kuwait _ Saddam is also looming large these days. Cafe patrons have stopped playing backgammon and dominoes. Instead, they huddle around transistor radios and listen to newscasts, smoking their water pipes and sipping heavy desert coffee. The Egyptian cafe-goer bent over a group of Arabs and said in a serious tone: ``Have you heard the latest?'' His audience tensed up, waiting to hear about a fresh political or military development in the crisis. ``The U.N. delegates from Egypt, Sudan and Iraq were asked what was their opinion about eating meat,'' said the storyteller. ``The Egyptian asked `What's meat?' The Sudanese asked `What's eating?' and the Iraqi asked `What is opinion?'' There was a burst of laughter, prompting others to walk up and demand a repeat. No repeats, said the Egyptian. A joke is good only at the first hearing. ``Please sit down, I'll buy you a cup of tea,'' an Arab in a flowing dishdasha gown and kaffiyeh headgear entreated him. ``Let's have more.''

DOC.HEAD: Administration Wants to Require Controversial Treadmill Test
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people with heart problems might no longer qualify for federal disability pay under a Bush administration proposal to expand the use of a controversial exercise test. Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., and New York state officials contend the tests, which require pedaling a bicycle or walking on a treadmill, could be unfairly used to exclude deserving applicants. ``There can be no question that in this day of mammoth federal deficits, even minimal savings are appreciated,'' Heinz said. ``But to create savings by distorting congressional intent is unacceptable and a blatant disregard for the public interest.'' The government estimates it will save $30 million in the plan's first year, and $220 million a year by 1995. Plans for the testing program are still being finalized and would be subject to public comment. The Social Security Administration receives 195,000 disability applications a year based on heart problems. If the proposal went into effect, the agency said, cardiovascular benefits would drop as much as 5 percent and thousands of people would lose eligibility if the tests showed the applicants weren't sufficiently disabled. SSA already uses the procedure in many cases to gauge the severity of heart disorders, but the proposed regulations would require a treadmill test for every disability benefit applicant with heart disease who could safely undergo one. Under the proposal, applicants would qualify for Social Security disability payments averaging $560 a month only if the ailment is deemed serious enough to prevent them from working. Heinz, ranking Republican on the Special Committee on Aging, told SSA in a letter last month that the proposal violated individuals' rights to have their cases fully heard. New York Attorney General Robert Abrams said in a prepared statement he was concerned that ``the federal government will continue to place predominant emphasis on the treadmill test in the face of other reliable medical evidence.'' The test would be the ``primary, though not exclusive basis'' for evaluating whether people with heart problems can work, SSA Commissioner Gwendolyn King said in a February memorandum to Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. SSA wants the change despite a federal appeals court ruling in June that upheld a New York federal court ruling forbidding the agency from denying benefits based solely on the treadmill test when other evidence was available. The 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said the test often fails to detect one of the most common cardiovascular disorders, known as ischemia. Evidence showed that the treadmill test resulted in misdiagnosis of ischemic heart disease more than one-third of the time, the court said. ``An individual who does not show signs of heart disease during a treadmill test may still be severely disabled from ischemia,'' the court said. ``False assessments may occur because treadmill testing does not consider the full range of stresses and exertions that arise at the workplace or in daily living.'' More than 5 million Americans have the disorder, which accounts for 60 percent of all heart ailments and is characterized by narrowing of the arteries and chest pain. The administration may ask the court to reconsider, said SSA spokesman Phil Gambino. ``We disagree with the court's decision because we believe that even currently we won't use the test in exclusion of other medical evidence,'' Gambino said in an interview last week. People already receiving benefits would be affected only if a treadmill test demonstrated that their condition had improved since their initial claim.

DOC.HEAD: Worker Videotapes All of Florida's Roads
DOC.TEXT: Doug Gauss' office is a Dodge van with a camera and microphone mounted on the dash. His mission is to produce a video inventory of Florida's entire road system _ all 23,000 miles. ``Actually it's 11,500 miles, but I drive it in both directions,'' said Gauss, who takes three years to log every mile of every road maintained by the state. And when he's done, it's time to start again. Videotaping roads is Gauss' full-time job with the Florida Department of Transportation's Roadway Characteristics Inventory Section. His work is housed in Tallahassee, where it serves as a reference library for road scholars. Engineers and planners check out videos to inspect a stretch of pavement without ever leaving their offices. Department lawyers can take a tape to court to support their cases. The county roads, city roads, expressways, interstates and all of the Florida Turnpike add up to a viewing time of 600 hours. That's a 25-day trip without leaving the couch. Viewer discretion is advised. ``Don't bother burning the popcorn,'' said Steve Homan, a spokesman in the department's DeLand office. ``They are perhaps the most boring things you'll ever see in your life.'' But it's a work of love for Gauss, who became the video logger in 1987. ``I always wanted this job,'' he said last week while taping the Orange Blossom Trail in Orlando. His annual salary is not much more than the total mileage he racks up every three years, and he earns it the hard way: on the road five days a week, 26 weeks a year, driving and taping, taping and narrating, up one side of a road and down the other, all by his lonesome. He hates offices and calls the entire state ``my hometown.'' One regret is the 100 nights a year he spends in motels, away from his Tallahassee home and his wife of eight years. ``That's the downside,'' he said, ``but she knows how miserable I am in the office.'' He expects to complete his second tour of Florida roads in March. After that, he is intrigued by a proposal to tape Florida's rail lines. ``I think I'd like to see rails,'' Gauss said. ``It would be a nice change.''

DOC.HEAD: B.F. Skinner Recalled as Brilliant Thinker, Warm Friend
DOC.TEXT: Psychology pioneer B.F. Skinner applied his theories of behavior modification to his own life, a friend recalled Monday as tributes poured in for the man who died last weekend. Skinner invented a reward system for himself to speed his learning of French grammar, said Ted Blau. He would study the verbs on an exercise treadmill, and give himself a break when he got something right. ``Fred was never a man to let things go to waste,'' said Blau. Blau, a clinical psychologist in Tampa, Fla., became friends with Skinner after meeting him in 1973. Skinner, the father of behavioral psychology and a professor emeritus at Harvard University, died Saturday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge after battling leukemia. He was 86. His theories bore the cold, clinical edge of laboratory tests, but friends and colleagues remembered him as a warm and gentle man who believed that human beings are just another organism shaped by their environment. Critics say many of Skinner's ideas were inhumane, but supporters point out that he left his mark on treatment methods to improve the lives of the mentally ill, drug addicts and others. His death elicited emotional responses from friends and supporters. ``I was kind of teary all day yesterday,'' said Jack Michael, who teaches psychology at Western Michigan University. ``It's just kind of the end of a period that was important to all of us.'' Skinner experimented with pigeons and rats to show that systems of rewards and punishment could shape animal behavior. He taught pigeons to play ping pong by reinforcing behavior patterns. The practical application of Skinner's theories can be seen in popular programs to help people lose weight, stop smoking and toilet train children. ``Skinner for many of us is a person of the same status, who has the same impact on the understanding of behavior that Darwin had in the area of biology or that Newton had in the area of physics,'' Michael said. Charles Darwin postulated the modern theory of evolution, and Sir Isaac Newton formulated the laws of gravity and motion. Fred Keller, 91, a psychologist retired from Columbia University, first met Skinner in 1928 when they were graduate students at Harvard. ``I first thought he was just a brilliant student whom I liked,'' said Keller, who lives in Chapel Hill, N.C. ``He was widely read,'' Keller said. ``He was clearly a highly intellectual and highly intelligent young man, and that was apparent from the first. I think all of his classmates at Harvard recognized that he was an outstanding scientist.'' William McKeachie, professor of psychology at University of Michigan, said he exchanged many letters with Skinner and sharply disagreed with his views. ``But we were friends,'' McKeachie said. ``He asked me to review one of his last manuscripts.'' Skinner's theories have had a major effect on education and the running of mental hospitals and prisons, he said. Skinner developed ``token economies,'' in which people in institutions could earn rewards by good behavior and meeting goals. Teachers learned to pay more attention to classroom techniques, which could affect how students behave and learn. Skinner was honored one week ago for his lifetime of achievement by the American Psychological Association at their convention in Boston. He was nominated many times to be president of the APA, but turned it down, said Blau, a former APA president. ``He did not believe that psychologists serious about their work should be distracted by political ins and outs.''

DOC.HEAD: Selma Students Return to School Ignoring Protesters
DOC.TEXT: High school students ignored black protesters and ``KKK'' painted on a front door Monday as they began another school year in the city's racially troubled school system. The schools were closed five days last spring because of protests over the firing of the district's first black superintendent. Protesters also criticized the white-majority school board, the mayor and the placement of students. Police made no arrests Monday. James Carter, acting school superintendent, said the school year got off to a peaceful start despite the overnight vandalism and the protest at Selma High School. About 30 blacks chanted outside the school as students arrived and two carried stuffed effigies of black children marked with slogans such as ``I'm Not Of Lesser Intelligence'' and ``Just Give Me An Equal Chance.'' Rose Sanders, a black lawyer and leader of the protest, contends poor students _ black and white _ are funneled into lower-level classes designed to perpetuate underachievement and are not encouraged to take college preparatory classes, such as chemistry, biology and foreign languages. Carter, who is black, said there was ``no tracking'' of students in their course assignments. He said students are ``grouped'' in some subjects, based on performance. For the system's 11 schools, officials reported enrollment Monday at 5,012 students _ 3,983 black and 1,029 white. After protests began in December, about 300 students _ mostly white _ left the public school system to enroll in private schools or moved, leaving between 5,700 and 5,800 students at the end of the school year, Carter said. Karen Felts, a white senior, said the attention attracted by the protests is ``an embarrassment.'' Miss Felts said the long-running protest ``has changed the spirit of the people'' at the school. ``I'm just going to try to get through it the best I can,'' she said. ``School is what you make it.''

DOC.HEAD: Longtime Washington Journalist Dies
DOC.TEXT: Richard L. Strout, who reported on Washington during 12 administrations and skewered the mighty as a liberal columnist, has died. He was 92. Strout died Sunday night at Georgetown University Medical Center. Godfrey Sperling, his longtime colleague at the Christian Science Monitor, said Strout was hospitalized after an Aug. 8 fall. Strout reported for the Monitor from 1922 to 1984, for the first couple of years at the newspaper's home office in Boston and then in its Washington bureau. He wrote about presidents from Warren G. Harding to Ronald Reagan. From 1943 to 1983, he wrote the political column ``TRB from Washington'' in the New Republic magazine. The column was also syndicated to newspapers. As a columnist, Strout described the Eisenhower administration as ``government by sedative,'' likened Sen. Joseph R. McCarthy, R-Wis., to ``a mist that carries lethal contagion'' and said then-Vice President Richard Nixon was ``out for the kill and the scalp at any cost.'' As a reporter, he covered presidential political campaigns and conventions, the Teapot Dome scandal that rocked the Harding administration, Franklin D. Roosevelt and his New Deal, and the D-Day invasion of Normandy in 1944. The TRB column was written anonymously for years, by Kenneth Crawford and others and then by Strout. It is currently written by Michael Kinsley, a senior editor of the magazine, and carries his byline. When Strout gave up the column, the editors of the magazine wrote: ``You don't get out of Strout's church without hearing the sermon, but the hymns are lovely. ... He looks and listens, and tells you what he has seen and heard in vivid, simple words.'' The column's name was coined by Bruce Bliven, an editor of the New Republic before it moved from New York to Washington. Bliven carried copy to the office by subway and said the initials were those of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit in reverse. After Strout's retirement, his name remained on the magazine's masthead as a contributing editor. In 1978, Strout was given a special citation by the Pulitzer Prize committee for his lifetime achievement. Strout also won the George Polk Memorial Award in 1958 and the National Press Club's Fourth Estate Award in 1975, among others. Strout was born in Cohoes, N.Y., and raised in Brooklyn. His father was an English teacher who wrote poetry. His parents both lived into their 90s. After graduating from Harvard in 1919, he worked his way across the Atlantic on a grain ship and served an apprenticeship as a reporter and copy editor for English newspapers. After returning to the United States in 1921, he worked briefly as a reporter for the Boston Post before joining the Monitor. He was the author of ``TRB: Views and Perspectives on the Presidency,'' a collection of columns published in 1979, and co-author with E.B. White of a book-length essay on the Ford Model T automobile, published in 1936. Strout is survived by his wife, Ernestine; their two children, Elizabeth Zimmerman of Minneapolis and Mary Rubeiz of Geneva, Switzerland; and three children from a previous marriage, Alan Mayne Strout of Weston, Mass., Phyllis Norris of Santa Cruz, Calif., and Nancy Dulaney of Washington. Survivors also include 11 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Strout's first wife, Edith Mayne, died in 1932. A private funeral is planned.

DOC.HEAD: Families Already Knew What Bush Concedes: Their Relatives Are Hostages
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday made official what the Rev. Edwin Davis and his wife, Irene, have sensed for nearly three weeks. Their daughter, and thousands of other Americans, are hostages. ``What happens if there's a shooting war?'' asked the retired minister from Koran, La. ``I'd like to be over there with them ... hold my daughter's hand.'' But the 68-year-old diabetic can't join ``the military soldier boys'' digging in for a long Persian Gulf standoff. Neither can he do anything to drive away the images haunting him and families around the nation. At night, while he tries to rest, Davis feels the heat he imagines his daughter, Kuwaiti son-in-law and their two teen-age children feel. He hears the helicopters that buzzed in the background the last time she called home, the night Iraqi troops rumbled into Kuwait. Since the Aug. 2 invasion, scant news has reached the relatives of about 3,000 Americans caught in Iraq's tightening grip. State Department officials have contacted some U.S. families. Others are still awaiting word. Jean Pryor is among the luckier relatives. Through a circuitous route, a message from her daughter in Kuwait made it home to Pelham, Ala. It said, simply: ``I'm fine. I don't think I'm in danger. They have moved me from the city to another province.'' Pryor, who isn't sure who ``they'' are, said the brief reassurance came ``at just the right time ... was an answer to the prayers that have gone out.'' But that message is now nearly a week old. Tensions have escalated. Iraq's official news agency said Monday that Western detainees had been moved to vital military targets, apparently to be used as human shields against a potential American attack. The government also has warned that those who hide foreigners will face the ``severest punishment.'' ``We have been reluctant to use the term hostage,'' Bush told the Veterans of Foreign Wars in Baltimore. ``But when Saddam Hussein specifically offers to trade the freedom of those citizens of many nations he holds against their will in return for concessions, there can be little doubt that ... they are in fact hostages.'' ``That's what I've said for two weeks,'' said Marjorie Walterscheid of Jacksboro, Texas. Her husband, Rainard, 52, is among a group of 35 U.S. citizens transferred from a Baghdad hotel to an undisclosed location. ``I've felt all the time they were hostages.'' Semantics mean little to Scott Gerard of New Harmony, Ind. All he knows is that his sister-in-law could lose her baby. Joan Khaja, who is seven months pregant, suffered complications before she traveled to Kuwait in late July to visit her husband's relatives. Now family members fear her body may not tolerate the dueling stresses of 100-degree desert heat and chilling uncertainty. ``It seems like (officials) have been so cautious not to use the term `hostage' all along,'' Gerard said. ``But ... I don't think it makes any difference at all.'' ``I don't think there's anything we can do ... (but) hope that there won't be another war, that our loved ones won't die in vain,'' said Palma Sharpan, whose nephew worked for American Telephone & Telegraph Co. in Kuwait for the past 15 years. The prospect of war holds anxious relatives hostage. In a windowless room at the State Department in Washington, D.C., consular officers take about 4,000 calls a day from people trying to locate missing family members. ``We live by the TV now,'' said Lynda Parker of Vidor, Texas. ``I live with a telephone in one hand and the remote control in the other.'' Her husband, Bobby, 49, is a Kuwait Petroleum Co. worker missing since the invasion. ``It's with me all the time,'' said Pryor, whose daughter has had two children since she moved from Alabama to Kuwait three years ago. ``I get up very early in the mornings so that by the time the news goes off at night, my body goes to sleep,'' she said Monday. ``But my heart is still awake. It never sleeps.''

DOC.HEAD: All But One Business Hooked Up Again in Downtown Manhattan
DOC.TEXT: Electricity has been restored to all but one business a week after a fire destroyed an electrical substation and knocked out power to 1,600 customers, utility officials said Monday. The outage blackened a 30-block area surrounding the South Street Seaport in downtown Manhattan Aug. 13, initially trapping thousands of people in elevators and offices in Wall Street skyscrapers. Buildings affected included the World Trade Center and the World Financial Center. Power was restored to them late that day. Consolidated Edison said the last 25 percent of the affected customers had their power turned back on sometime Sunday or early Monday. The lone business customer who was not yet connected was operating on a backup generator and had asked the utility to delay switching the power on until after the business day.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Years Later, Convict Admits to Racial Slayings
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted in the fatal shootings of two black joggers 10 years ago Monday has finally admitted his guilt. Joseph Paul Franklin, an avowed racist, admitted in a television interview he killed the two men in a city park Aug. 20, 1980. Ted Fields, 20, and David Martin, 18, were felled in a sniper attack as they ran with two white girls. The gunman was hidden in a field nearby. In an interview with KUTV from the federal prison in Marion, Ill., Franklin initially refused to answer questions about the murders. An hour into the interview, which was broadcast Sunday night, Franklin was asked again about the murders. ``The answer is yes. I won't discuss it any further other than to say yes,'' he said. Pressed to supply the one answer sought by Martin's mother, Franklin added a short time later, ``Just for her, just to answer her question, I'll say that it was just because they were race mixing. Had they not been race mixing, you know, it would have been a totally different story.'' Franklin, 39, a drifter from Mobile, Ala., and a past member of the Ku Klux Klan and American Nazi Party, is serving four life terms for the slayings of Martin and Fields _ two state murder convictions and two federal convictions for violating the victims' civil rights. He had blamed the convictions on the Mormon Church and government officials, who he charged were offended by his blunt racial statements. His name later was linked to 13 slayings across the United States, as well as the shootings of National Urban League President Vernon Jordan and Hustler magazine publisher Larry Flynt. He was acquitted in the Jordan shooting in 1982 and was indicted but never tried in the Flynt case. In 1984, he was convicted of bombing a synagogue in Chattanooga, Tenn., and in 1986 received two more life sentences for murdering an interracial couple in Madison, Wis. Though he claims to spend most of his time in prison reading the Bible and praying, Franklin expresses no remorse for the Utah murders. ``No, I don't regret that. Not to say there are not actions that I've done that I don't regret. I've sinned a lot in my life. Any sins that I've done I've repented of,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Confident in Face of Desert Hardship
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Marines are ``damn confident'' they can cope with any situation here, despite the punishing conditions and logistical challenges, a commanding general said Monday. ``We are ready to do whatever we need to do,'' Maj. Gen. John Hopkins, head of the 7th Marine Expeditionary Brigade based in Twentynine Palms, Calif., said in an interview with reporters. So far, about 90 percent of the equipment the brigade needs has arrived in Saudi Arabia, he said. ``We're not battle-ready right this moment, but we'll be ready pretty shortly,'' Hopkins said. Although the brigade trained in the Mojave Desert, Hopkins said even he was overwhelmed by the Arabian desert conditions, where temperatures routinely hit 130 degrees. ``We are going through growing pains, and all the troops are getting acclimatized,'' he said. Even so, he said: ``We feel damn confident.'' The equipment the brigade has brought with it will enable the Marines to fight on land and in the air. The brigade has carried weapons for every wartime situation, including: M-60 tanks, high utility multipurpose vehicles; howitzers; TOW missiles; 40mm grenade launchers; Harrier jets; Cobra helicopters equipped with sidewinder missiles and TOWs; Huey helicopters for command and control; CH-46 _ so-called Sea Knights _ to transport people, and wide-bellied C-150 transport planes. All told, five cargo ships _ some based in the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia _ will unload material for the brigade. Most of the equipment, including the helicopters, has to be reasembled on the ground. The brigade _ a so-called maritime preposition brigade _ has deployed in a commercial port and surrounding desert in the eastern province of Saudi Arabia. For security reasons, the Defense Department has barred reporters from disclosing specific information such as the number of Marines in Saudi Arabia, their location and the number of weapons they carrying. But a brigade typically has about 16,500 men. Pentagon officials have said as many as 45,000 Marines could end up in the desert kingdom. Expeditionary units are designed to become combat-capable in 10 days and sustain itself for 30 days without resupply. The ground combat Marines have been sent to the desert where they have set up tents covered by camoflauged nettings to escape the sun and avoid detection from above. Aviators and maintenance crews are working 16 hours to 18 hours a day to ready their craft learn the terrain.

DOC.HEAD: Don't Give Smokey Bear a Middle Name, New Ad Campaign Says
DOC.TEXT: It's neither Santa the Claus nor Easter the bunny, and after four decades of being misidentified, another cultural icon wants it known that he, too, has no middle name. It's simply Smokey Bear, said the Ad Council, which helped create the ursine forest ranger in 1944. The council has launched a national advertising campaign to eliminate the ``the'' that's usually attached to the name of the bear best known for reminding that ``only you can prevent forest fires.'' The Ad Council has added a reminder about the bear's name to a new $1.6 million fire prevention campaign. In a 60-second radio spot made available nationwide last month, a boy teaches the bear's name to a man who says he's said Smokey the Bear his whole life. ``You wouldn't call the Easter bunny `Easter `the' bunny, would you?'' the boy responds. Smokey was born after the U.S. Forest Service sought help from the Ad Council in designing a fire prevention campaign. The national council is a non-profit organization that helps develop public service advertising. The first Smokey Bear was a human dressed in a costume. In 1950, a bear cub saved from a New Mexico forest fire was named Smokey and exhibited at the National Zoo in Washington, D.C. He died in 1976, and was replaced by Smokey II, another forest-fire orphan who died earlier this month of liver cancer.

DOC.HEAD: Foreigners In the Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
About 3 million foreigners were in Kuwait and Iraq when Saddam Hussein invaded Aug. 2. Many have been allowed to leave or have escaped to Saudi Arabia and Jordan. Several thousand, including American, British and French nationals, have been detained by the Iraqis.
Here is a breakdown of the foreign nationals believed to be in Kuwait and Iraq:
United States: 2,500 in Kuwait, 500 in Iraq Canada: 522 in Kuwait, 200 in Iraq Brazil: Kuwait unknown, 450 in Iraq
Europe: Britain: 4,000 in Kuwait, 500 in Iraq France: 270 in Kuwait, 290 in Iraq Ireland: 50 in Kuwait, 300 in Iraq West Germany: 290 in Kuwait, 450 in Iraq Italy: 138 in Kuwait, 150 in Iraq Greece: 47 in Kuwait, 200 in Iraq Netherlands: 80 in Kuwait, 100 in Iraq Spain: 184 in Kuwait and Iraq combined Turkey: 2,500 in Kuwait, 4,000 in Iraq Poland: 1,000 in Kuwait, 3,000 in Iraq Czechoslovakia: 120 in Kuwait, 350 in Iraq
Asia, Pacific: India: 175,000 in Kuwait, 10,000 in Iraq Japan: 280 in Kuwait, 230 in Iraq South Korea: 900 in Kuwait and Iraq combined Pakistan: 90,000 in Kuwait, 10,000 in Iraq Philippines: 90,000 in Kuwait, 3,000 in Iraq New Zealand: 24 in Kuwait, 12 in Iraq Australia: 127 Iraq and Kuwait combined Bangladesh: 70,000 in Kuwait, 40,000 in Iraq Sri Lanka: 100,000 in Kuwait, Iraq unknown Taiwan: 140-160 in Kuwait, Iraq unknown Hong Kong: 16 in Kuwait and Iraq combined
Middle East: (Large numbers of Iranians and Arab nationals have fled Iraq and Kuwait. These figures represent those nationals in the two countries when Iraq invaded Kuwait): Egypt: 150,000 in Kuwait, 1.6 million in Iraq Morocco: 6,000 in Kuwait, 30,000 in Iraq Tunisia: 2,000 in Kuwait, 2,000 in Iraq Palestinians: 300,000 in Kuwait, 170,000 in Iraq Iran: 60,000 in Kuwait, Iraq unknown
Iraq has said the following nationals can leave:
Sweden: 160 in Kuwait and Iraq combined Finland: 26 in Kuwait, 22 in Iraq Switzerland: 97 in Kuwait, 56 in Iraq Austria: 140 in Kuwait and Iraq combined Portugal: 100 in Kuwait and Iraq combined Soviet Union: 880 in Kuwait, 9,000 in Iraq China: 3,000 in Kuwait, Iraq unknown Yugoslavia: 300 in Kuwait, 10,000 in Iraq Malaysia: 298 in Kuwait, 82 in Iraq

DOC.HEAD: Iran Says It Will Abide By U.N. Sanctions
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iran on Monday said it will abide by U.N. sanctions against Iraq, despite the newly established peace between the two neighboring Persian Gulf states. The official Islamic Republic News Agency, in a report monitored in Nicosia, said Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati informed U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the decision in a letter sent Monday. ``Iran, as a member of the United Nations, will honor Resolution 661 issued by the U.N. Security Council within the capacities stipulated by the U.N. Charter,'' IRNA quoted Velayati as telling the U.N. chief. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein announced last week that he had accepted Iran's terms for a settlement of the decade-old conflict, pacifying his eastern neighbor as his confrontation escalated with U.S.-led forces in Saudi Arabia and the gulf region. He began withdrawing troops from occupied Iranian territories on Friday, and the two sides have since exchanged thousands of prisoners captured in the 1980-88 war. Saddam's peace initiative raised speculation Iran would violate the mandatory sanctions called by the U.N. Security Council after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 and the subsequent annexation of the small gulf emirate. The foreign ministers of Turkey and Pakistan, both staunch allies of the West, traveled to Iran last weekend, seeking commitment from Velayati to the sanctions. Iran has condemned the invasion and called for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. But it said it was equally opposed to the deployment of U.S.-led multinational forces in Saudi Arabia. It called for the withdrawal of these forces, which assembled in the kingdom to thwart a possible Iraqi attack from the north, saying developments in Kuwait were best solved by countries of the region.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Lands Plane After Husband Suffers Fatal Heart Attack
DOC.TEXT: A woman safely landed a private plane after her husband, the pilot, died at the controls. Joan S. Bailey, of Trotwood, Ohio, radioed the Delaware County Airport on Sunday afternoon that her husband had collapsed. All runways were closed and radio traffic controllers talked her through the safe landing. ``She did a wonderful job,'' said Fire Chief Tommy Crawford. ``It was hard for us to believe. She looked like she just set it down in a field of cotton.'' Mrs. Bailey's husband, Robert E. Bailey, 48, apparently suffered a heart attack, officials said. He was pronounced dead at Ball Memorial Hospital. The Baileys were en route from Dayton, Ohio, to Muncie in a single-engine Grumman American Tiger. Mrs. Bailey, whose age wasn't available, told investigators she did not know how to fly the plane.

DOC.HEAD: Rebuffed By Bush, Hussein Struggles For Survival
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: At odds with President Bush and half the Arab world, King Hussein is persevering in his attempts to be a peacemaker in the Persian Gulf, but his position is precarious. Since Hussein assumed the throne in 1952 at age 16, he has managed to endure, despite being at the vortex of the political upheavals that have plagued the Middle East. But his support for Iraq's president following the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has left Hussein vulnerable. The crisis threatens Jordan's ``very social and political stability,'' leading economist Fahed Fanek wrote in the English-language Jordan Times newspaper on Sunday. The king has refused to join Egypt, Syria and other Arab states that have sent troops _ even if they are primarily token contingents _ to join the Western buildup in Saudi Arabia against Iraq. Hussein says he cannot participate if he is to pursue his efforts for a settlement ``within an Arab context without outside intervention.'' Western diplomats in Amman said Hussein has shown a genuine desire to avert a potentially catastrophic military showdown in the gulf. But if he joins the forces against Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein, he risks the wrath of his powerful neighbor. He also faces an internal threat. Jordan's 3 million people have rallied behind Saddam, whom many Arabs consider the only leader willing to stand up to Israel and the United States. More than 100,000 Jordanians have registered as volunteers to fight for Iraq if war breaks out, according to the Jordanian Committee for the Support of Iraq. But if Hussein supports the Iraqi leader, he is certain to face the Jewish state's military might and the revulsion of the international community. Dan Shueftan, a researcher at Israel's Hebrew University, said the king ``is walking between the devil and the deep blue sea.'' Another Israeli, Ron Ben-Ishai, military commentator for the daily Yediot Ahronot, justified Hussein's concern over Israeli intentions. ``They're worried about a possible Israeli preemptive strike,'' he said. Jordan is Saddam's main avenue for confronting Israel on the ground. Israel's hard-line government has warned it will attack if the Iraqis enter Jordan. Hussein has expressed discouragement over what he sees as the failure of the West, especially the United States, to get Israel to the negotiating table. He told Jordanian newspaper editors over the weekend: ``Jordan will pursue its efforts with all its powers on the Arab and international level to de-escalate the gulf crisis.'' Bush said after meeting with Hussein on Thursday in Kennebunkport, Maine, that he had ``not come away with any feeling of hope'' that Iraq will withdraw from Kuwait, despite intensifying international pressure. The king painted an equally grim picture. ``This is the most crucial stage ever in Arab history,'' he told the editors. The Arabs could either survive ``with a place under the sun among other nations, or, God forbid, live in darkness losing everything they have,'' he warned. Hussein has declared he still recognizes Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al Sabah, the emir of Kuwait overthrown by Saddam's invasion. He has said he will abide by the U.N. economic sanctions imposed against Iraq to force its withdrawal from Kuwait. But he has not implemented them. Jordan's economy, burdened with an $8 billion debt, is heavily dependent on trade with Iraq. Nearly all its oil comes from there. Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba remains Baghdad's economic lifeline. The European Community has discussed compensating Jordan for joining the blockade of Iraq. But Fanek, the economist, said ``all the compensation in the world'' would not make up for the ``far-reaching'' economic and political losses Jordan would suffer, which ``threaten not only the national income, but also national security.''

DOC.HEAD: Wyoming Voters Decide on Gubernatorial Candidates Tuesday
DOC.TEXT: Two women are vying for the Republican gubernatorial nomination in Tuesday's primary election, and the winner most likely will face Democratic Gov. Mike Sullivan. The GOP candidates are Mary Mead, daughter of former Gov. and U.S. Sen. Cliff Hansen, and state Rep. Nyla Murphy. Mead, a Teton County rancher, and Murphy, a 12-year state representative from Casper, seemed to agree on issues more often than not during the primary campaign. Both support abortion rights, oppose other states dumping garbage in Wyoming, and favor the death penalty. Where they differ is on Mead's call for a cut in minerals taxes to spur exploration. Murphy believes the current tax system is adequate and that the economy will improve under the state's diversification efforts. Sullivan is seeking his second term. His opponent for the Democratic nomination is Ron ``Suds'' Clingman, a Rock Springs motorcycle repairman who believes his stances on lowering the drinking age back to 18, legalizing gambling, and cutting the salaries of public officials are popular. U.S. Sen. Alan Simpson, the Senate Minority Whip, is seeking a third term, and U.S. Rep. Craig Thomas is pursuing his first full term in office. Simpson faces two political unknowns in the GOP primary, while six unheralded Democrats are seeking their party's nomination for the seat. Thomas was appointed to fill Dick Cheney's unexpired term in office when he was appointed defense secretary last year. Thomas is unopposed in the primary as is his Democratic opponent, Pete Maxfield.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Talks Still Need $105 Billion; Bush Says Stakes High
DOC.TEXT: The White House said anew Monday that federal programs could face more than $105 billion in spending cuts barring deficit-reduction action by the end of the fiscal year. President Bush appealed for cooperation from Democrats ``because our country is at stake.'' Bush's Office of Management and Budget released its new report under a timetable mandated by the deficit-fighting Gramm-Rudman law. The reductions the report described are preliminary now, but both military and civilian programs could face cuts in excess of 40 percent on Oct. 1 unless Bush and Congress reach a budget agreement before then. However, one of the few things the budget negotiators have agreed upon is that they can't agree on $105 billion in either spending cuts or new taxes to meet the Gramm-Rudman goal. They've set their sights on about $50 billion in deficit reduction next year, with the assumption that if they can strike that deal they can then change the law to prevent any deeper cutbacks. The president met with his budget negotiators Monday in preparation for the resumption of the bipartisan talks early next month. Later, in comments at a Republican fund-raising gathering in Rhode Island and on his plane on the way there, Bush said that ``cooperation is still possible'' with the Democrats and that he has been pleased with the way some Democratic leaders have approached the problem. ``There has been some good faith effort in terms of negotiations. But it is essential now when the Congress comes back that this cooperation be renewed ... because our country is at stake.'' In a more partisan attack, Bush said of bills under consideration in the Democratic-controlled Congress: ``I will veto every single spending bill that busts the budget. ... We're in that tough a shape, so they can mark it down and put it in the bank.'' The remark drew loud applause from the GOP audience. In earlier comments, in a speech to the Veterans of Foreign Wars in Baltimore, he appealed anew for Congress not to cut military spending. He cited the Persian Gulf situation as an example of a need to retain military readiness despite reduced tensions in Eastern Europe. The budget office report followed the lines of predictions it made last month when the administration released its mid-year economic review. Under Gramm-Rudman, the federal deficit must be reduced to $64 billion for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 or automatic, across-the-board spending cuts are ordered. The administration estimates that the deficit will exceed the Gramm-Rudman limit by $105.7 billion, and come that close only if the $50 billion or more needed for the savings and loan bailout isn't counted. Social Security and other entitlement programs are exempt from the cutbacks and Bush has exercised his option of exempting military payrolls also. According to the OMB calculations, the remaining military and domestic programs would likely face cutbacks of 43.6 percent and 40.7 percent respectively. For many agencies, the only way to achieve such reductions would be to lay off workers, cut off benefit programs, or virtually close down. ``Our preferred course remains the negotiation of a budget summit agreement that provides for continued economic growth and responsible deficit reduction,'' said OMB Director Richard Darman in his letter accompanying the report. If not, the cuts ``will go into effect _ as required by law,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Under Way as Second Trial Looms
DOC.TEXT: With a second trial looming in the gang rape of a Central Park jogger, a lawyer who was involved in previous racially charged cases joined the appeal Monday of one of the young men already convicted. The victim, who recovered from near-fatal injuries she suffered during the gang rape and resumed her career as an investment banker, said through intermediaries she won't comment on the weekend conviction of three youths. A hearing was scheduled for Sept. 10 in state court on jury selection in the trial of the three other defendants, Kharey Wise, 18, Steven Lopez, 16, and Kevin Richardson, 15. The six are accused of being among a larger gang of blacks and Hispanics that rampaged through the park the night of April 19, 1989, accosting and threatening joggers and others. The white woman who has become known as the Central Park jogger was raped, beaten with a brick and left for dead in a pool of blood and mud. Yusef Salaam, 16, Antron McCray, 16, and Raymond Santana, 15, were convicted Saturday of rape, assault, robbery and riot, but acquitted of attempted murder and sodomy. They were immediately ordered jailed by Justice Thomas Galligan. They are to be sentenced Sept. 11 as juvenile offenders and face a maximum of up to 10 years in prison. Lawyers for all three have promised appeals. And on Monday, the office of activist attorney C. Vernon Mason announced that he would handle McCray's appeal. Mason represented victims in the Howard Beach trial, in which three whites were convicted of manslaughter for their part in chasing a black man to his death on a highway in 1986. He also advised Tawana Brawley, a black teen-ager whose claim she was raped by whites drew widespread attention, but eventually was rejected by a grand jury. Mason's legal secretary, Lenita Jones, also said that Louis Farrakhan, leader of the Nation of Islam, would take part in a nationwide support campaign. The Central Park jogger, whose name has been withheld by most media, kept to herself in the aftermath of the verdict. ``She has no comment as there are still other legal proceedings pending,'' said Lisa Barowitz, a spokeswoman for Salomon Brothers, her employer. Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer, who prosecuted the case, also refused to discuss the jogger's reaction to the verdict. ``I respect her privacy,'' the prosecutor said. The New York Post quoted an unidentified source as reporting that the jogger said, ``Thank God this is over'' when she heard of the verdict. ``She was thrilled. She was relieved. She was grateful to the jurors,'' the source was quoted as saying. ``She called them `wonderful people.''' Wise, Lopez and Richardson face 13 charges each, including attempted murder, rape, robbery, assault, sodomy and riot. Lopez and Richardson face the same penalties if convicted on the top counts: up to 10 years in prison. But Wise, because he was 16 when the crime occurred, can be punished as an adult and sentenced to up to 25 years. The three teen-agers signed written statements and gave videotaped statements to police and prosecutors. As in the first trial, the statements appear to be the prosecution's crucial evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Gonzalez Calls For Congress To Assert Its Role In War
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's response to the Middle East crisis has won solid endorsement from members of Congress, but one Democrat said Monday the time has come for the lawmakers to get into the act. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, wrote House Speaker Thomas S. Foley urging that Congress be called into special session ``to exercise its authority and responsibility in this time of national crisis.'' ``What happened to the checks and balances established by the United States Constitution and the constitutional power invested in Congress to declare war?'' Gonzalez wrote. ``The president has committed our country to a full-scale war under the guise of a multinational effort, when anyone who is watching what is happening realizes that it is virtually an exclusive American military operation which is risking only the lives of American soldiers,'' Gonzalez wrote. Foley's office said he was out of town and unavailable to comment on the letter.

DOC.HEAD: Dam-Burst Threat Eases, Patients Returned to Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Volunteers filled sandbags and monitored a leaking dam Monday, but officials said water levels had been lowered and the threat of a dam break had diminished. Heavy rain and the leak prompted the evacuation of some patients from Woodlawn Hospital in this north-central Indiana town. The patients returned to the hospital Monday. ``Everything's back in operating condition and we have our eye to the sky,'' said Karen Ewen, the hospital's vice president of nursing services. Forecasts called for more storms across the region later Monday. A flood watch was posted for the entire northern third of Indiana through Monday. But John Curran of the National Weather Service in Indianapolis said the stronger storms were expected to be south and north of the Rochester area. Workers on Sunday night and early Monday hauled sandbags and rock to shore up the 5-foot-high earth and concrete dam at Lake Manitou. Pumps and drainage trenches brought the water level down 3.5 inches by midday Monday. ``As long as we can control the levels within the reservoir as new rains may occur, we're out of danger of losing the structure,'' said Bruce Murray, chief of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers in Louisville, Ky. Lake Manitou is about 12 feet above Mill Creek, which flows along the eastern edge of Rochester, a town of 5,000 residents. The threat of more rain made some emergency workers wary. About 70 volunteers continued to fill sandbags Monday, just in case they were needed, said Sgt. Earl Vance with the Fulton County Sheriff's Department. Volunteers were monitoring the dam around the clock from an emergency command post nearby, Vance said. Twenty-eight patients were evacuated early Sunday from the hospital. Many of those patients went home; two were transported to a South Bend hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Libya's Gadhafi Criticizes Iraq, U.S. for Mideast Actions
DOC.TEXT: Col. Moammar Gadhafi on Monday criticized both Iraq and the United States for provocative actions in the Mideast and threatened to withdraw Libya from the United Nations. The Libyan leader also urged the U.N. Security Council to pass a resolution calling for military measures against Iraq, which invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The United Nations has backed the use of economic sanctions in its effort to get Iraq to withdraw occupation forces from Kuwait. At a news conference in the Bab-aziziya barracks outside the capital of Tripoli, Gadhafi said he opposed Iraq's holding of foreigners, including Americans and British citizens, as hostages: ``We are against the use of hostages as bargaining chips. This is our fixed priciple.'' Gadhafi's news conference, attended by about 150 news people, was conducted in a tent-like structure lined with bright green, red and white canvas. The Libyan leader was surrounded by reporters shouting questions at him. When at one point the translator said, ``the United States'' instead of ``the U.N.,'' Gadhafi said, ``He's right. Now there is no difference between the United States and the United Nations.'' He also said, ``The U.N. Security Council has so far taken steps within the U.N. charter, recommending the international community impose economic sanctions on Iraq ... but the United States has ignored this resolution ...'' The United States, which has decided to stop vessels suspected of carrying goods to Iraq, has stationed warships in and around the Persian Gulf and in the Red Sea. ``The U.N. Security Council must now condemn the United States and its allies the same way it has condemned Iraq,'' Gadhafi said. He condemned Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait, and the military response by the United States, saying, ``Unless the U.N Security Council moves quickly, I am thinking of withdrawing from the U.N., and my nation will think of that too.'' Asked if he had any time frame in mind for such a move, Gadhafi only said ``if the United Nations cannot keep peace, there is no point in maintaining membership.'' The Libyan leader, dressed in a gray suit and a black-and-white striped shirt, also said his country would be ready to send troops if it was asked to in order to ensure an economic blockade of Iraq. He did not elaborate. Asked if he could use his influence with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, Gadhafi said he had been unable to contact him because communications with Iraq remain cut. Libya called news agencies and networks a day earlier to announce Gadhafi's news conference and arranged for charter flights to carry the press to Tripoli.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms And Flooding In Indiana
DOC.TEXT: Rain and thunderstorms were scattered over much of the eastern half of the nation Monday, causing flooding in northwestern Indiana, and rain also was scattered over parts of the West. Showers and occasional thunderstorms during the afternoon extended from eastern South Dakota across southern Minnesota, Iowa, southern Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana, southern Lower Michigan and northwestern Ohio. Thunderstorm wind gusts damaged power lines and tree limbs near Indianapolis. Several roads in northwestern Indiana were flooded, the National Weather Service said. Also in northern Indiana, the Tippecanoe River at Monterey had risen above its former record flood level, set in March 1982, the weather service said. The Kankakee River reached its highest level since February 1985. In Wisconsin, the Pecatonica River crested at Darlington during the night and fell to near flood stage by midday, the weather service said. The crest was expected to reach Martintown on Tuesday at about 4 feet over flood stage. To the east, showers and thunderstorms reached from southeastern Pennsylvania across New Jersey, Maryland, Delaware, eastern Virginia, southeastern New York state and southern New England. In the South, showers and storms extended along the South Carolina coast, and over Florida, northeastern Alabama, the upper Texas Gulf Coast, southwestern Louisiana, Arkansas and southeastern Missouri. In the West, rain and storms were scattered from the Oklahoma Panhandle across the northern Texas Panhandle, northern New Mexico and southwestern Colorado, and over east-central and north-central Nevada, Idaho and western Wyoming. Hail an inch in diameter fell at Follett, Texas, the weather service reported. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 34 at Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 54 at Winnemucca, Nev., to 102 at Meridian Naval Air Station, Miss.

DOC.HEAD: Plastic Decals on Baby Walker Pose Choking Hazard
DOC.TEXT: Delta Enterprise Corp. asked consumers to remove and discard plastic labels and decals from its Delta Luv Pop-Corn Baby Walker because they pose a choking hazard. The walkers have been associated with five incidents of choking, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Monday. All occurred when children pulled off the decals on plastic toy dials on the walker trays and placed them in their mouths. The six colorful round decals, which measure about 1{ inches in diameter, should be removed immediately if they can be easily dislodged, the commission said. Labels that are firmly stuck should be checked periodically and removed if they become loose, the commission said. Adults should also remove the plastic-coated ``Delta Luv'' label with surrounding stripes found on the front of the tray, although no complaints have been received about these labels, the commission said. The paper warning label located under the tray should not be removed. Approximately 100,000 of the walkers have been sold nationwide since 1984. Owners with questions may write to Delta Enterprise Corp., 49 Junius St., Brooklyn, N.Y. 11212. The company can also be reached by phone at 718-385-1000 between 8 a.m. and midnight EDT.

DOC.HEAD: Government Sues Toys R Us, six other toy distributors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with two graf INSERT after 4th graf, bgng ``In a'' to include reaction from Toys R Us official; pick up 5th graf, bgng ``The lawsuits.'' ^By JAMES ROWLEY
DOC.TEXT: Seven major toy distributors were sued Monday by the Justice Department and the Consumer Product Safety Commission for selling imported toys the government contended violated federal safety standards. The suits against Toys R Us and six other companies charge that the toys are unsafe because they contain excessive amounts of lead paint or have small parts that could choke small children. The agencies said they were unaware of any injuries or deaths resulting from the toys, some of which were seized from store shelves by government investigators. In a statement, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh called the lawsuits ``an important step toward preventing even a single dangerous toy from reaching innocent children.'' However, Michael Goldstein, executive vice president of Toys R Us, said ``the suit is without merit. Our safety record is excellent. ``We believe we will prevail in the legal action and we believe it's a waste of the taxpayers' money,'' said Goldstein, who was named as a defendant in the suit against Toys R Us. The lawsuits seek injunctions barring the companies from importing or selling the toys that contain too much lead paint or are considered unsafe for children under age three. The lawsuits described a variety of rattles and toy airplanes or stuffed animals that violated the safety regulations. Many of the toys cited were labeled for use by children over age three, but the CPSC contended in court papers that the items were, in fact, intended to be used by small children who could choke on small parts. CPSC spokesman Dan Rumelt said the toys were mostly imported from Taiwan but also were made in Hong Kong, China and South Korea. Besides Toys R Us, which is headquartered in Paramus, N.J., the government also sued Child World Inc., of Avon, Mass.; Lionel Leisure Inc., of Philadelphia; Value Merchants Inc. of Milwaukee; Illco Toy Company, USA, Inc., of New York; Beachcombers International Inc. of Fort Meyers, Fla.; and Division Sales Inc. of Itasca, Ill. Chief executives of the companies were also named as defendants in the civil suits. The complaints also named the chief executives of the companies as defendants in the civil suits. The court papers said each of the companies had been previously notified that the toys violated safety regulations. Some of the toys have been recalled by distributors, the CPSC said. A woman who answered the telephone at Lionel Leisure declined to comment, saying she was unaware of the lawsuit. ``Until we receive legal service, as far as we're concerned we haven't been sued by anybody,'' said the woman, who refused to identify herself. An official of Division Sales, who also refused to identify himself, declined to comment, saying he ``didn't know anything about it.'' Mike Mervis, a spokesman for Value Merchants, said the company had recalled all nine items CPSC cited as unsafe. Value Merchants purchased the items thinking they met government standards but ``the product bought and the product that was shipped may have been different things,'' he said. Value Merchants is continuing to negotiate with the government to reach a consent decree to settle the case, Mervis said. But the spokesman blamed inadequate inspection of foreign goods by the U.S. Customs Service for the recurring problem. ``There is no foolproof way to control this without much stronger federal intervention and some means of controlling the inspection process'' in factories overseas, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Official Proposes Blessing of German Unity be Advanced A Month
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher proposed Monday that the official granting of international approval to German unity be moved up a month, to October. Current plans call for the results of talks on international aspects of German unification to be presented to a November meeting in Paris of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE). Member nations of the CSCE include the United States, Canada, the Soviet Union and all European countries except for Albania. The four World War II allies and the two Germanys have reached basic agreement on how to iron out international complexities of German unity. Probably the greatest obstacle was Moscow's insistence that a united Germany cannot be a NATO member. The Soviets have since reversed their position in an agreement that will allow Red Army troops to remain in what is now East Germany during a transition phase. The six nations that were involved in those talks _ the United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union, and the two Germanys _ are working on a final document that will cover the results of the negotiations. Genscher said Monday that document should be presented to a meeting of CSCE foreign ministers in New York City on Oct. 1-2 rather than at the Paris gathering. During the early stages of the six-nation talks, it looked like German unity would not happen before the end of the year. But the unification process has sped up quickly, and the merger now looks likely to occur Oct. 14 at latest.

DOC.HEAD: India Places Troops on Alert After Reported Border Clashes
DOC.TEXT: India placed its troops on alert across its northern border with Pakistan on Monday after clashes were reported with Pakistani troops in a remote area of the disputed Kashmir territory. Describing the clashes as ``a major border incident,'' United News of India said that according to unconfirmed reports at least 10 Pakistani soldiers were killed and five wounded in the clashes. There was no official confirmation on casualties. ``It is very difficult to say if there were casualties. We are, however, checking,'' said an Indian government spokesman, Ram Mohan Rao. The clashes reportedly occurred in the Kupwara sector of the disputed frontier, about 60 miles northeast of the Srinagar, the capital of India's Jammu-Kashmir state. Earlier, Pakistani troops fired heavy artillery with explosive and incendiary shells at Indian border posts in Jammu-Kashmir state, Rao said. ``Exchange of small arms fire is a frequent occurrence on the border, but use of heavy artillery and incendiary ammunition is something new,'' Rao said. In Islamabad, a Pakistani defense ministry spokesman denied the reported incident. ``There is absolutely no truth in the report of Pakistanis firing (at) Indian troops,'' said the spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. But in New Delhi, an Indian defense ministry official, requesting anonymity, said all troops were put on alert along the border after the incident. Indian defense officials in Srinagar called the incident ``serious.'' The officials, who also asked not to be identified, said some of the Pakistani shells landed a half-mile inside Indian territory. Rao said the Indian government was waiting to receive more details about the border incident. ``Probably Pakistan wants to make a little more noise, but we have taken appropriate defensive measures,'' Rao said. He refused to elaborate on the measures. A week ago, Pakistan accused Indian troops of using heavy artillery, anti-tank guns and mortars in an attempt to capture a border outpost in Pakistan-controlled Kashmir. At the time, India denied the claim. India and Pakistan have fought three wars since gaining independence from Britain in 1947. Two of the wars were fought over Kashmir, a former principality claimed by both countries. The present border is a cease-fire line drawn in 1972 that separates Jammu-Kashmir, India's only Moslem-majority state, from Pakistan's Azad (Free) Kashmir region. In another sign of escalating tension, the prime minister of Pakistan-held Azad Kashmir on Monday ordered mandatory military training for all males. ``India wants to attack. ... Responsibility for the whole of the Kashmir nation is on my shoulders,'' the prime minister, Mumtaz Rathore, told about 3,000 cheering supporters in the Azad Kashmir capital of Muzzaffarabad. ``From this day onward my mission will be the liberation of Kashmir,'' he said. A senior aide to Rathore, requesting anonymity, said military training would also be given to Moslem militants spearheading the secessionist uprising in India's Jammu-Kashmir state. The aide said Rathore sought no prior approval from the national governmet in Islamabad before announcing the compulsory military training. Pakistan-held Azad Kashmir is relatively autonomous, but the federal government is responsible for the region's defense, diplomacy and finances. Analysts say Rathore's plans to provide military training for Kashmiris could cause a confrontation with the new right-wing government that succeeded ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. India has accused Pakistan of providing arms and training to Moslem militants in Jammu-Kashmir. Pakistan, an Islamic state, has denied the allegation, but says it supports the Kashmiri people's right to self-determination. At least 1,034 people have been killed in Jammu-Kashmir since New Delhi launched a crackdown on the Moslem secessionist movement on Jan. 20. In May, both countries massed their armies along the cease-fire line in Kashmir as war fears escalated. The crisis was averted largely due to diplomatic intervention by the United States and the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Trade Bill Affecting Northwest Logging, Duty-Free Imports
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed a trade bill Monday restricting state and federal log exports in an effort to save thousands of timber jobs affected by automation and federal protection of the northern spotted owl. Bush said there was ``no doubt that high levels of export of unprocessed timber have contributed to the decline in habitat'' that caused the northern spotted owl to be listed as threatened. ``While I am supporting this provision because it assists in the preservation of critical habitat, I also note that it will ease the economic transition in areas affected by the listing of the spotted owl,'' Bush said. The log measure is intended to preserve the Pacific Northwest's dwindling timber supply for domestic mills along with enough old-growth stands to save the northern spotted owl from extinction. The bill makes permanent what had been a year-to-year ban on the export of raw logs from federal land and imposes a new ban on state lands in California and Oregon. Exports from state-owned land in Washington would be reduced but not halted. Log exports from privately owned lands would still be allowed, but the timber industry generally would be prohibited from substituting them for logs from federal lands as a way to escape the ban. The legislation, passed by Congress earlier this month, also permanently extends the duty-free status of $4 billion in imports from 24 Caribbean and Central American nations, including Nicaragua and Panama. ``America's security and prosperity depend in large measure on continued progress toward democracy and economic development in the Caribbean basin,'' Bush said in a written statement. The legislation did not expand the trade benefits to cover imports of textiles, shoes, sugar and methanol, commodities that could threaten U.S. farmers and jobs. It did, however, expand the program to give duty free status to articles processed in Caribbean countries from U.S. materials and to certain leather products. President Reagan's 1983 Caribbean Basin Initiative was intended to lift the region's depressed economy through direct aid and an elimination of tariffs and other trade barriers to spur export-oriented businesses. Critics say the initiative has failed to large degree because the direct government-to-government aid fell victim to U.S. budget deficits and drastically reduced imports of oil, petroleum products and sugar from the region. The log export prohibitions will have the biggest impact in Washington, Oregon and Northern California, where dramatic harvest cutbacks are beginning to materialize in government plans for old-growth forests inhabited by the threatened owl. ``Our mills need the logs and Oregon millworkers need the jobs,'' said Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., who estimated the law will save 5,000 to 7,000 jobs in his state alone. ``What we've done with this legislation is say we want to keep jobs at home instead of shipping them overseas,'' said Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash. The shift in U.S. trade policy is due primarily to the plight of the owl, said Rep. John Miller, R-Wash. ``There are other factors, but clearly the owl focused everybody's energy on this problem and the owl spurred the state delegations and the administration to look at all sorts of options for addressing the timber shortage at the mills,'' he said in a telephone interview.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Embassy Driver Shot to Death by Police
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese driver for the U.S. Embassy in Beijing was shot to death by police after he drove an embassy vehicle through a roadblock, authorities said Monday. Ma Ji, 32, who was off-duty and driving the embassy's Toyota van without permission, was shot in the neck and died instantly, Beijing police said. His wife, Zhou Yue, also an embassy employee, was slightly injured when the van slammed into a parked truck, said an officer at the Foreigners Section of the Beijing Public Security Bureau. He refused to give his name. The incident last Wednesday night began with a double murder in which two people were shot to death during a romantic dispute, police said. The suspect fled, and police in Fengtai, a suburb in southwest Beijing, were ordered to set up roadblocks. At 11:45 p.m., Ma left his mother-in-law's home in Fengtai, where he had gone to pick up his wife. Police said he was speeding when he came to the roadblock at an overpass just south of his mother-in-law's home, and ignored a police officer who motioned him to stop. According to police, the officer did not see that the van had diplomatic license plates. The police also said the officer was aiming at the lower right side of the van when he fired, but hit the rear windshield instead because the vehicle was going downhill. Police said the case was under investigation. U.S. Embassy spokesman Sherry Bell said, ``We regret the loss of life _ a tragic event. (But) it's certainly not an event that's going to affect Sino-U.S. relations.'' He said Ma, one of several dispatchers at the embassy, had worked there almost 10 years. Bell said he was unaware of previous problems with Ma. Many foreigners in Beijing who employ drivers complain that the drivers often take the vehicles for personal use. The double-murder suspect was later shot to death in the port of Tianjin, about 161 miles south of Beijing. Police said he shot and wounded two police officers who tried to arrest him, and they returned fire, killing him.

DOC.HEAD: Government Cites UPS for Job Safety Violations
DOC.TEXT: The government proposed $280,000 in fines Monday against United Parcel Service, accusing the company of willfully violating federal safety laws requiring that job-related deaths and injuries be reported. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration said the alleged violations took place at the company's Watertown, Conn., facility. UPS, the nation's largest package delivery company, was cited for failing to notify OSHA about a job-related death and failing to record more than 100 other injuries and illnesses. The company also failed to record the number of lost workdays caused by the injuries, the agency said. John Flick, a spokesman for the company based in Greenwich, Conn., said there would be no immediate comment because lawyers had not reviewed the allegations, which were issued late in the day. Last April, OSHA proposed a $625,000 fine against UPS for alleged record keeping violations that occurred at the company's Uniondale, N.Y., office. OSHA launched the Watertown inspection after UPS failed to notify the Labor Department that a worker had been killed by a moving vehicle while crossing a street. The probe was widened to include a review of all accidents and worker-safety problems at the facility. UPS also was cited for allegedly not giving workers in Watertown training on how to handle spills or providing them with breathing equipment while they clean up spills. Willful violations are those committed with an intentional disregard of, or plain indifference to, federal job safety laws. UPS has 15 workdays to appeal the government's allegations to an independent review commission.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Sets Columbia Launch for Sept. 1
DOC.TEXT: NASA said Monday it will try to launch the newly repaired Columbia on Sept. 1, more than three months after a hydrogen leak grounded the shuttle. Columbia will carry the Astro observatory, and the mission will be the first shuttle flight in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. It also will be the first shuttle flight since April, when Discovery carried the flawed Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. Columbia's fuel leak, followed by discovery of a similar problem with Atlantis, prompted the space agency to temporarily ground the entire shuttle fleet in June. Columbia will carry seven astronauts, four of whom are astronomers and will operate the $150 million Astro observatory. Three of the observatory's scientific instruments will study ultraviolet light emitted by stars and other objects. The fourth instrument will examine cosmic sources of X-rays. Liftoff is scheduled for 1:17 a.m. EDT, NASA announced. Columbia was to have blasted off May 30 on a 9- to 10-day astronomy mission, but a leak of explosive hydrogen was detected during fueling and the flight was called off. The leaky plumbing was replaced with components from the new shuttle Endeavour, under construction in California. Atlantis' leak, in a different spot than Columbia's, was discovered in late June. Atlantis was rolled back to the hangar for repair 1{ weeks ago, and Columbia took its place at the launch pad. Atlantis' classified military mission has been rescheduled for November.

DOC.HEAD: HHS Official Disputes Report That White House Thwarted Study
DOC.TEXT: A top federal health official on Monday disputed a congressional report that concluded the Reagan White House obstructed a government study of Vietnam veterans exposed to Agent Orange. Dr. James Mason, assistant secretary for health in the Department of Health and Human Services, said the study was canceled for scientific reasons, not pressure from the White House. He issued a four-page statement detailing what he said were factual errors in the Aug. 9 report by the House Government Operations Committee. ``The bias ... is clear,'' Mason said of the report. The study said the White House ordered the study canceled after the federal Centers for Disease Control said it was scientifically impossible to use military records to identify veterans who had been exposed to the defoliant. The committee said the CDC, then headed by Mason, did not document that exposure could not be assessed and disregarded alternate methods of measuring exposure. Mason said ``there was no White House or any other interference'' in any of the initial studies conducted to determine feasibility of exposure assessments. White House officials were not privy to the results of these studies before they were released publicly, he said. He also said the studies found no accurate way to assess exposure. ``Each time a new method was proposed, testing showed it not to be accurate,'' Mason said. ``It was not possible to differentiate between the exposed and the nonexposed veterans based on military records.'' Agent Orange was a herbicide used to destroy ground cover during the Vietnam war. Veterans groups claim that exposure to Agent Orange has been linked to 19 cancers and other health problems, including birth defects.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Freighter with Tank Bridgelayers Heading for Iraq
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi freighter is heading to Jordan with 17 armored bridgelayers that enable tanks to cross difficult terrain, Jane's Defense Weekly reported Monday night. Jane's publisher Paul Beaver said it was a clear indication the Iraqis were trying to obtain offensive military equipment by gaining access to the East German BLG-60 tracked vehicles. The vehicles have scissor-like bridges that are capable of spanning a gap of 66 feet. Iraq received seven in a deal last year with the former Communist East German regime, the magazine said. Seventeen more were reported to have left the Polish harbor of Gdynia on July 31, en route for the Jordanian port of Aqaba after making several other stops, the magazine said. The new East German regime only became aware of the latest delivery Aug. 10 and requested the four allied powers _ the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union _ to stop the vessel, according to the report. Its whereabouts are not known, Jane's said. The Foreign Office said Monday night it was aware of the vessel. The Ministry of Defense said it would take any necessary action to enforce the United Nations embargo against Iraq. Jane's also reported that the U.S. government may restrict foreign sales of the Bell 206 LongRanger helicopter because of concern it could be modified as a helicopter gunship and sold to Iraq. A modification program on the Bell 206 is being funded by Chile's Cardoen Industries, which has a long history of selling arms to Iraq, Jane's said. The Chilean company, which would buy and modify used aircraft, is trying to gain U.S. Federal Aviation Administration certification to operate the two-crew helicopter as a single-pilot aircraft, it said. U.S. officials are concerned the aircraft will be delivered to Baghdad configured as helicopter gunships and may add it to the U.S. Munitions List administered by the U.S. State Department, the magazine said. This would require all U.S. owners to clear foreign sales. U.S. State Department officials were quoted by the magazine as saying Iraq seeks as many as 150-200 modified LongRangers from Cardoen Industries.

DOC.HEAD: Four Sentenced to Prison in IRA Plot
DOC.TEXT: Three Americans and an Irishman were sentenced to prison terms Monday for plotting to send weapons, including anti-helicopter missiles, to the Irish Republican Army. In ordering the sentences, U.S. District Judge David A. Mazzone called their crimes ``flat out terrorism'' that could have killed innocent people. He sentenced Richard C. Johnson, 41, of Nashua, N.H., to 10 years in prison, and Martin Quigley, 27, of Dundalk, Ireland, to eight years. Christina Reid, 25, of Sunnyvale, Calif., was sentenced to three years and five months in prison, and Gerald Hoy, 40, of Easton, Pa., was sentenced to two years. All four were ordered to serve three years probation after completing their prison sentences. Johnson, Quigley and Reid were convicted by a federal jury in June on various charges, including conspiracy to violate the federal Arms Export Act and to injure or destroy property belonging to the United Kingdom, possessing property to aid foreign insurgents, and aiding an insurgent group in violation of U.S. laws. Hoy pleaded guilty earlier. Prosecutors claimed the four planned to ship arms, including anti-helicopter missiles, to the IRA, which is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland. Defense attorneys had claimed their clients merely shared an interest in high-technology electronics. At Monday's sentencing, Johnson thanked his supporters and told the judge, ``God will be watching what you do.'' Quigley, who may be deported, was placed in the custody of U.S. marshals. The others remain free on bail until they begin serving their sentences Sept. 10, said Susan Spurlock, a spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office.

DOC.HEAD: President's Use of `Hostage' Term Could Set Stage for Military Strike
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 6th graf, A handful, to update with up to 14 Americans taken from two hotels
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush crossed a critical line Monday in finally describing Americans and other foreigners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait as hostages. It may mean he is closer to sending some of the troops now massing in Saudi Arabia into Iraq in a rescue operation or even an outright attack on Baghdad. Or Bush merely may have been acknowledging the obvious. He held off for more than two weeks, emphasizing diplomacy and appeals to Iraq's Saddam Hussein to observe international norms.
