Hours before the president spoke to the Veterans of Foreign Wars in Baltimore his spokesman had told reporters concerning the term: ``We would not use that word.'' The plight of the foreigners seemed to worsen through the weekend. There were threats to use them as human shields _ placed in strategic locations to deter U.S. attack. A handful of Americans managed last week to cross the border to freedom, but evidently none from Kuwait over the weekend. Thirty-five removed from a hotel in Baghdad have not resurfaced. At least a dozen, possibly 14, others were taken from two hotels in Kuwait City _ destination not certain. So Bush revised the speech prepared for him for the VFW national convention to inject that ``there can be little doubt, whatever these innocent people are called they are, indeed, hostages.'' And he warned Iraq and everyone else not to underestimate U.S. resolve. The president took that decisive step after meeting with Brent Scowcroft, his assistant for national security, and with Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger. With the assertion, Bush could be trying to establish a legal justification for an attack, although it was not immediately clear that the status of the Americans had changed under international law. The president also may be preparing the American public psychologically for the support he needs to escalate from economic pressure on Iraq to combat _ with grave risk to the lives of U.S. troops and bomber crews. But above all, Bush's description of the Americans as hostages helps him develop a rationale for using force to try to rescue innocent U.S. citizens who by no stretch of the imagination could be considered combatants. Saddam's quickly rejected proposal to free the foreigners in exchange for a U.S. military pullout from the Persian Gulf region set political conditions for their freedom, Richard Boucher, a State Department spokesman, noted. ``It dramatizes the circumstances under which these people are being held,'' Boucher said. Last Friday, in a subtle shift, Boucher said he did not want to speculate about whether the Americans might be described as hostages. And then, over the weekend, Thomas Pickering, the U.S. envoy to the United Nations, called them hostages _ a description White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater challenged. Until the situation darkened, U.S. officials insisted reporters should not use the term. State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler repeatedly stressed the Americans were not being held at gunpoint, they were not being mistreated and efforts were under way to secure their departure fromPIraq and Kuwait. From the days of the 19th century Barbary pirates, the United States and its leaders have rallied to the aid of Americans detained abroad against their will. But the risk of all-out war dictates trying diplomacy first. President Jimmy Carter exhausted all available means after Iranian fundamentalists overran the U.S. Embassy in Tehran in 1979 and seized the Embassy staff and Marine guards. He tried a military rescue operation that failed in a desert north of the capital, but never pulled the trigger to fire on Tehran. The American television audience, in the meantime, was bombarded nightly with the message that the United States itself was being ``held hostage.'' Ronald Reagan, campaigning against Carter, capitalized on the frustrating situation and won the White House in 1980. The 52 remaining American hostages finally were released through Carter administration diplomacy. But they were not liberated until Reagan's inaugural, and after 444 days of miserable detention. Reagan, in his two terms, did not succeed in freeing a number of other Americans held hostage in Lebanon by pro-Iranian factions. Secret U.S. arms shipments to Iran may have been instrumental in the release of a couple, but the other Americans remained captive and at least two were murdered. Now it is Bush's turn to grapple with hostage-holders. The Iraq crisis looms as his toughest political challenge. Declaring the Americans in Iraq and Kuwait to be hostages may expose him to a fate similar to Carter's. He runs the risk of being branded a failure if the 530 or so in Iraq and 2,500 in Kuwait are not freed soon. Direct military action to liberate them _ or at least to punish Iraq _ could help or hurt the president, depending on the results. His delay in calling them hostages minimized the political risk for a while. But Monday Bush crossed that line _ to an uncertain outcome.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid is the AP's chief diplomatic writer.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 12 in Kuwait and 35 in Iraq Taken to Unknown Locations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with State Department saying as many as 14 Americans taken from hotels, U.S. officials again being denied access to Americans and ADD number of Americans in Jordan. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: At least 12 Americans, possibly 14, were taken from hotels in Kuwait's capital and moved to an undisclosed location, the State Department said Monday. U.S. diplomats in Kuwait and Iraq protested the action, but the whereabouts of the Americans remain unknown, said spokesman Richard Boucher. Other foreign nationals also were taken from hotels, the department said. The Americans were staying at the Hyatt Regency and the Kuwait International. They are among an estimated 2,500 Americans in the Persian Gulf country overrun by Iraqi forces three weeks ago. President Bush, in a speech Monday, referred to the Americans as hostages for the first time. A U.S. official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the 12 or 14 Americans included men and women as well as at least one family. He said he did not know if any children were among them. ``They may be going to Baghdad,'' the official said. ``That's something we presume.'' But he said he didn't have any solid information. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has threatened to use Americans as a human shield in the event of a U.S. military attack. Bush told the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention in Baltimore that the Americans trapped in the two countries were hostages and warned Iraq not to underestimate U.S. resolve. Securing the safety of the 2,500 Americans in Kuwait and another 530 or so in Iraq is ``the prime concern'' of the Bush administration, Boucher said. ``We continue to do everything we can to obtain the release of these people,'' Boucher said, adding that the United States is telling family members that ``the prime concern of our people in Baghdad and in Kuwait has become the safety and welfare of Americans.'' Another 35 Americans who were taken earlier from Kuwait to the Rashid hotel in Baghdad were removed last week. Boucher said they remain unaccounted for despite repeated U.S. inquiries. U.S. diplomats in Baghdad called again Monday at the Iraqi foreign ministry and again were barred from going to another hotel, the Melia-Mansour, to see if the Americans had been moved there, Boucher said. The Melia-Mansour is where British nationals were taken last week. American diplomats in Kuwait are in touch with ``as many Americans as possible'' through visits, by telephone and via Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Co., Boucher said. ``We continue to push for the release of all people held against their will,'' he said. Despite reports Americans have been leaving Kuwait in small numbers, the State Department can't confirm that any escaped over the weekend, Boucher said. Meanwhile, Bush dismissed as unacceptable an Iraqi demand that the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait City be closed by Friday. As the situation for Americans in the area worsened, the State Department said non-essential diplomats and dependents were leaving Jordan, which borders Iraq. The department says there are about 5,000 Americans in Jordan, 4,700 of them private citizens and the remainder U.S. officials. Americans there were advised to consider leaving. Similar instructions were issued for Yemen, which lies far beyond Iraq on the Arabian Sea. ``I can't cite for you the specific security factors in each country that might have led to that determination,'' Boucher said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Debate How Court Can Consider Sexually Explicit Pictures
DOC.TEXT: A courtroom became an arena of artistic debate Monday over whether five sexually explicit photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe should be judged separately or as part of an entire 175-picture exhibit. Defense lawyers for the Contemporary Arts Center and its director, Dennis Barrie, argued for dismissal of a misdemeanor charge of pandering obscenity. He said the exhibition as a whole wasn't legally obscene. Both the director and the gallery were charged when they showed the photos by the late artist, which previously had drawn the anger of U.S. Sen Jesse Helms and helped prompt Congressional action to restrict funding of work deemed obscene. In addition to that defense motion, Municipal Judge David J. Albanese considered a prosecution request to consider just the five pictures identified in the indictment in judging whether obscenity laws were violated. Albanese did not rule on either request. Judith Reisman, a communications consultant who said she has studied sexually explicit photographs for the Justice Department and the American Family Association, testified that individual photographs would have affected visitors. Defense lawyer H. Louis Sirkin countered: ``But I go in to see the exhibit as a whole, don't I?'' ``Absolutely not, absolutely not,'' Ms. Reisman said. ``There are people who walked in and saw one picture and left.'' Martin Friedman, of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, testified for the defense that every picture in the six-week exhibit had to be considered as part of the entire show. He noted that the Contemporary Arts Center's contract to show the pictures required it to show all of them. ``The whole purpose of an exhibition is to set up context,'' Friedman said. ``An exhibition must be all the pictures. You can't isolate some of the pictures and talk about the exhibition.'' The judge took over the questioning at several points during the 3{-hour hearing, asking defense witnesses if sexually graphic pictures were required as part of a survey of the career of the late Mapplethorpe. The judge asked Evan Turner, director of the Cleveland Museum of Art: ``Is there some danger ... if the (gallery's) direction of the theme was just a vehicle for exhibiting erotic photographs for people who wanted to see erotic photographs?'' ``I don't think any of the photographs in this exhibition fits that definition,'' Turner said. The five photographs identified in one count of a two-count indictment against Barrie and the gallery depict homoerotic acts. ``They are difficult images, but they are important to understanding the artist's approach,'' Friedman said. The judge earlier ordered Barrie and the gallery to stand trial Sept. 24 on another charge of using children in material involving nudity. One picture in the exhibition included a boy with his genitals exposed; another showed a girl with her genitals exposed. The charges of pandering obscenity and using children in material involving nudity each would carry a maximum penalty of six months in jail and a $1,000 fine for Barrie. The gallery could be fined $5,000 on each charge. The Mapplethorpe exhibition closed in Cincinnati on May 26. It opened in Boston on Aug. 2, provoking demonstrations for and against the Institute for Contemporary Art, which is displaying it. Authorities in Boston have not filed criminal charges.

DOC.HEAD: Britain's Front Line Fighters on Alert in Saudi Arabia
EDITOR'S NOTE _ The following dispatch is from pool reporters for The Associated Press, Reuters and Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency.
DOC.TEXT: Britain's sole front-line fighter squadron at Dhahran in northeastern Saudi Arabia went on alert Monday night for a possible Palestinian terrorist attack, according to a news report. Ian Bruce of the Glasgow Herald said the warning was given after touchdown at King Abdul Aziz airbase of a Royal Air Force VC10 transport aircraft loaded with spare parts for the 12 Tornado F3 interceptors and chemical warfare suits for the ground support crews. Bruce gave no source for his information, though thousands of Palestinian workers live in Saudi Arabia. Charles Miller of the domestic British news agency Press Association said the crew of the DC-10 aircraft that took journalists into Dhahran carefully examined the plane after receiving an intelligence warning about the possible attack by the Palestine Liberation Organization. Miller did not specify the source of his information. The PLO was one of the Arab organizations that opposed moves to send a pan-Arab force to protect Saudi Arabia from Iraqi attack when they were agreed at the Arab summit in Cairo Aug. 10. It refused to join in the condemnation of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Bruce and Miller are part of a pool flown to the Persian Gulf by the British Ministry of Defense. RAF Tornadoes and U.S. warplanes were taking off and landing at regular intervals, transport aircraft carrying supplies and weapons were being unloaded, Miller said. The scale of Britain's deployment of 12 Tornado F3 fighters is dwarfed by the U.S. presence, which is in the thousands. But the Tornadoes are flying regular training missions close to the border with Kuwait, where 120,000 of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's troops are dug in, Miller said. Britain has about 1,700 airmen and engineers as its land contribution to the growing allied force in the area. This includes the Tornadoes at Dhahran and a Jaguar ground attack squadron in nearby Oman. Squadron leader Ted Threapleton, 38, a navigator with the Tornado group, said Monday night, ``We are doing the job for which we have trained, and humor and morale is high.'' The standard of accommodation for the British forces is comparatively high. They have Portakabin-style buildings with air conditioning and some British television channels are available. The Americans, however, are living in tents.

DOC.HEAD: Czech Minister Suffers Heart Attack During Visit to Brazil
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak Minister of Foreign Trade Slavomir Stracar was hospitalized Monday after suffering a heart attack during an official visit to Brazil, a Foreign Minstry spokesman said. Jose Vicente Pimentel said Stracar, who is heading a Czech delegation, fell ill during a lunch at the Foreign Minstry on the first day of the visit. Stracar was rushed to the Armed Forces Hospital where he was diagnosed as having suffered a heart attack and interned in the intensive care ward, Pimentel said. Neither the hospital nor the Czech embassy was able to provide further information about Stracar's status.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Indicted in Serial Killing Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf to CORRECT spelling to Chandra sted Sandra; SUBS 12th graf to CORRECT that lawyer is charged with three counts of conspiracy to possess cocaine sted two counts involving cocaine and one involving heroin.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX7
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer who for weeks has publicly defended himself against reports he was a suspect in a serial killing investigation was charged Monday him with one of the nine slayings. Kenneth C. Ponte, 40, who now lives in Port Richey, Fla., entered a plea in court that he was ``absolutely not guilty.'' Bail was set at $500,000 surety or $50,000 cash, and Ponte was released after his mother posted her home. The indictment charging Ponte with murder was filed last week but was sealed to give authorities time to notify victims' relatives. It accused Ponte of the beating death of Rochelle Clifford Dopierla, and said she was beaten and died on April 27, 1988. She is one of nine women whose bodies were found near this southeastern Massachusetts community between July 1988 and April 1989. Two other women are missing and presumed to be victims. All had histories of drug use and some were prostitutes. Bristol County District Attorney Ronald Pina declined to say if Ponte was a suspect in the other slayings. But court documents show that authorities believe he had a personal relationship with at least three victims. Several relatives of victims were in court when Ponte entered his plea. One of them, Chandra Greenlaw, the daughter of a victim, said later of Ponte: ``I want to see him hung.'' Ponte's attorney, Kevin Reddington, complained of the negative publicity Ponte has lived under while his name has been in circulation as a suspect. ``This man has been under more intense pressure for the past six months than anyone I can imagine,'' said Reddington. Ponte remained silent for months, but in recent weeks has given several lengthy interviews to reporters, insisting he is the victim of a witch hunt. ``Mr. Ponte welcomes a trial,'' Reddington said. ``He needs a trial to clear his name.'' Ponte also is awaiting trial on other indictments. Earlier this year, he was charged with three counts of conspiracy to possess cocaine. Last year, he was charged with assault with a dangerous weapon in connection with a 1988 fight with a man. Pina told Superior Court Judge George Hurd that Ponte ``crossed the line from the legal community and became a member of the drug community.'' ``This man went into a drug world, he recruited women, he used them to purchase his drugs, he brought them into his home,'' Pina said. Dopierla was one such woman and she was planning to expose Ponte's drug activities, Pina said. ``The motive was to get rid of a witness,'' he said. After the hearing, Ponte echoed the comments of his attorney. ``I just want to say it's been a two-year-long nightmare for me so far,'' said Ponte. He said his indictment was ``simply political showmanship on the part of Ron Pina,'' who is up for re-election this year. Pina, seeking his fourth term, faces a Sept. 18 Democratic primary challenge by New Bedford lawyer Paul F. Walsh Jr., who has accused Pina of political motivation in his handling of the case. Pina denied any political motive in the timing of the indictments, saying of the grand jury: ``They don't work for me.'' The 21-member panel began meeting in March 1989. It was Pina who, in 1984, prosecuted the widely publicized ``Big Dan's'' rape trial, involving a 1983 gang rape at a tavern of that name in New Bedford. Four were convicted; two were acquitted charges they cheered during the attack. The story was later made into a movie. Pina defended the length of the investigation, saying the case involved complex events in New Bedford's drug community. ``The drug community is not a member of the chamber of commerce,'' Pina said. Investigators have reported that Dopierla's mother told them her daughter once gave her Ponte's home telephone if her mother wanted to reach her in New Bedford. Ponte has said his only contact with Dopierla was in April 1988 when he, as a lawyer, helped her with a man whom she accused of raping her.

DOC.BYLINE: Peace Talks Stuck on Issue of Armed Forces ^By DOUGLAS GRANT MINE
DOC.TEXT: Peace talks between Salvadoran government and guerrilla negotiators have bogged down over rebel demands that the army be abolished and officers be punished for politically motivated murders, participants said Monday. Oscar Santamaria, Justice Minister and head of the government delegation, described the addition of new guerrilla demands since the July round of talks as a setback. ``The introduction of new documents with further demands alters and distorts the course of the negotiation. It (the guerrilla document) is not in accord with the seriousness of the peace process,'' he said. The Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, the insurgent army known as the FMLN, submitted an 18-point document. Its first demand calls for ``the total demilitarization of society, by means of disappearance of the two armies.'' The rebels, in previous rounds of talks, had demanded trial and punishment of officers implicated in four noted human rights cases, including the 1980 assassination of Archbishop Oscar Romero and last November's massacre by army troops of six Jesuit priest-educators, their housekeeper and her daughter. The new document adds demands for punishment of those responsible for two other cases, as well as ``the murders, massacres and bombardments of civilians that have occurred during the negotiations.'' The document also demands investigations to determine responsibility for 20 other specific crimes in addition to ``all the crimes, murders, disappearances and massacres committed since 1979.'' ``This is what is needed to create a new society,'' said rebel chief Francisco Mena Sandoval, a former army captain who switched sides in 1981. One member of the government delegation called the new guerrilla proposal ``a low blow.'' Another said it appeared designed to postpone the reaching of any substantial accord. The rebels, who last November launched the war's biggest offensive in the capital, say they are prepared to make another major military push if no signficant accords are reached soon. Guerrilla commanders have said privately they believe the army is more vulnerable now than at any time in recent years for three reasons: the impact of last year's rebel offensive, the implication of several officers in the Jesuits' massacre and the imminent reduction of U.S. military aid. This session is the fourth round of monthly U.N.-mediated talks that began in Venezuela in May. The negotiations have produced only one accord, on human rights, signed last month. The negotiators had moved on from the first item on the agenda, the armed forces, after nearly three sessions failed to produce significant movement on that subject. Both sides agree the military issue is the most difficult and crucial to an agreement. The rebels say they are unwilling to again set aside the subject of the armed forces and pursue agreements in other areas. ``The armed forces is really the only subject,'' said guerrilla commander Eduardo Sancho. Also on the seven-point agenda are the pursuit of agreements on electoral, judicial and constitutional reform, economic matters and international supervision to ensure that eventual accords are carried out. The administration of President Alfredo Cristiani, a conservative backed by the United States, says it is willing to restructure, reform and reduce the armed forces, but not abolish them. Participants in the talks agree that a mid-September cease-fire, set as a preliminary objective in May, appears virtually impossible. In El Salvador, the army Monday reported two clashes and rebels said they ambushed an army patrol. Five guerrillas were killed in fighting 50 miles north of San Salvador in Chalatenango province, an army communique said. Another clash near Jocoitique, 125 miles northeast of San Salvador in Morazan province killed one guerrilla, the communique said. Guerrillas also dynamited six more power poles. The attack followed the destruction of 42 posts and pylons last week that left nearly half the country without electricity for two days and caused power rationing in the rest of the country. The nearly 11-year-old civil war has killed an estimated 72,000 people, most of them civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Horse Adoption Program Criticized
DOC.TEXT: A government program offering wild horses for adoption to citizens is becoming increasingly costly, with no evidence that federal rangeland has benefited, a congressional study said Monday. The Interior Department's ``Adopt-a-Horse'' program is aimed at removing wild horses from federal rangeland so that herds do not exceed what the land can support. About 60,000 wild horses have gone through the program over the last decade. But the General Accounting Office, the investigative agency of Congress, questioned in a report whether the program is needed. ``Range conditions have not demonstrably improved, and the number of wild horses removed has exceeded the capacity of the program,'' the GAO said. The study said the Interior Department's estimates on how many horses should be removed often is based on unreliable information as to what the rangeland is able to accommodate. In some cases, the Bureau of Land Management has removed horses from ranges only to increase authorized livestock grazing by ranchers, ``thereby negating any reduction in total forage consumption and potential for range improvement,'' the study said. At the same time, the government continues to have problems in disposing of horses taken off the range, the study said. Some horses remain at training facilities for as long as 19 months when no more than two months are needed for the training, driving up the cost of the program. The GAO said the government also may face a costly long-term commitment to providing sanctuaries for horses that are not adopted. The cost of the first such sanctuary is now nearly $900,000 a year and other sanctuaries likely will be needed, the study said. The report noted that the wild horse program had been the focus of other problems in the past because of an inability to find homes for the horses. Between 1984 and 1988, the BLM opened the program to large-scale adopters, resulting in abuse of the program and thousands of the horses being sold by adopters to slaughterhouses. ``The fee-waiver adoption program resulted in the abuse and commercial exploitation of thousands of wild horses, contrary to BLM's legislative direction,'' the GAO said, noting that the program was halted in 1988 after public and congressional outcries. The GAO cited no evidence of such practices continuing, but it noted that the regulations allowing a waiver of fees for adoptions has not been rescinded. The BLM earlier this year proposed new rules aimed at preventing a single adopter from controlling large numbers of wild horses, reducing the potential for profits and abuses under the program.

DOC.HEAD: Stealth Fighters Head for Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: Twenty black, angular F-117A Stealth fighters kicked up rooster tails of spray Monday as they took off on wet runways at Langley Air Force Base for their much-publicized deployment to the Middle East. One of the planes returned shortly after takeoff under clouds and periodic showers. Air Force officials were unable to say why the plane turned back. Air Force Col. Ron Sconyers, spokesman for the Tactical Air Command at Langley, said it would take the radar-evading planes 12 to 15 hours and several in-flight refuelings to reach bases in Saudi Arabia. Air Force officials were mum on exactly what role will be played by the F-117A, which is designed to bomb targets behind enemy lines. Unlike some other aircraft sent to the area after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion and occupation of Kuwait, the F-117A cannot be considered a defensive weapon, said Col. Anthony Tolin, assistant deputy chief of staff of the Tactical Air Command at Langley, and wing commander for the Stealth fighters until last week. ``I think they provide a great deal of deterrence. The Iraqis know we can get in, hit the target, and get out without ever appearing on their radar. That has to give them pause,'' Tolin said Sunday when the planes arrived. ``They give us an ability, should we need it, to get in with the least amount of casualties and attack those important targets if necessary,'' Tolin said. The planes saw combat during the Panama invasion when they attacked a radar site. The fighters flew to Langley from their home base at Nellis Air Force Base in Nevada. Technicians and ground support personnel also were en route to Saudi Arabia. Sconyers said two of the fighters were held back for maintenance reasons. The $42.6 million-a-copy F-117A is one of the most expensive planes the Pentagon ever launched. Billions were spent on the research necessary to make the plane invisible to radar. It was once so secret the Air Force flew it only at night missions high above the Nevada desert. The plane was designed and built by Lockheed Co.'s super-secret ``Skunk Works'' plant in Burbank, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Military Cooperation Widens With Gulf States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 17th graf bgng:'' ``While the xxx to fix name of state to Arkansas sted Alabama.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American military cargo planes are being allowed to operate from this Arab federation, the second Persian Gulf nation to accept foreign troops in response to the ongoing crisis with Iraq, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney said Monday ``It's a measure of the seriousness of the situation, of the fact they're deeply concerned that their very existence is being threatened by Saddam Hussein,'' Cheney told reporters traveling with him on a four-day mission to garner support from gulf states. A squadron of 16 C-130 cargo transports and about 575 Air Force support personnel are at Bateen Air Base here to join Operation Desert Shield, Cheney said. It was the first time one of the moderate Arab governments in the southern gulf region has publicly announced such overt military cooperation with the United States, even though several states had quietly worked to help such U.S. operations as the reflagging of Kuwaiti tankers during the Iran-Iraq war. King Fahd of Saudi Arabia agreed earlier to allow the influx of tens of thousands of U.S. military personnel, as well as other foreign troops. Cheney said the emirates ``are eager to cooperate with the United States and the other forces that have joined in the multinational effort to ensure that (Saddam) doesn't come any further.'' The announcement came after Cheney met at a white marble and gilt waterside palace with Sheik Zayed al Nahyan, president of the United Arab Emirates, a group of seven loose alliances. Cheney said nations once cool to a U.S. military presence ``are prepared now to actively engage with us, taking steps to enhance their security that would not have been possible prior to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.'' Cheney's presence in this Muslim nation of 1.6 million on the southern edge of the Gulf was remarkable in itself: He is the highest-ranking U.S. official ever to visit the Arab state. Cheney arrived in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, after making a detour to Qatar. He visited five Persian Gulf states within 15 hours. Cheney also was to travel Monday to Oman and Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, where he was scheduled to meet with the Saudi royal family, and to Doha, Qatar. ``Being here in the U.A.E. is a significant departure for us,'' Cheney said as he visited a C-130 crew near the flight line. Asked about possible arms sales to nations in the region, Cheney said he believed there was a ``general interest'' in finding ways to strengthen the security position of the governments of the Gulf in the years ahead. ``We want to work with them in training and exercises while we are here _ and add equipment if that's what they need to enhance their own self-defense capabilities,'' he said. Meanwhile, as thousands of U.S. military personnel continue to pour into Saudi Arabia, support units went to work. The 314th Tactical Airlift Wing from Little Rock, Ark., pieced together a small town of small air-conditioned mobile homes within 48 hours of their arrival five days ago. While some of the airmen and crews worked to maintain the four huge propellers of the giant green C-130 transport planes on the tarmac, several dozen men dressed in cutoffs and T-shirts lounged outside their housing units, hoping to catch a glimpse of Cheney. While the buildings may keep the searing, white-hot desert sun at bay, even those used to Arkansas weather took a beating from the heat. ``I don't think I've ever drank this much water in my life,'' said Col. Dave Mason, the group's commander. Mason said some of his crews had just flown 30,000 MRE's _ Meals Ready to Eat _ overnight, and were ready to transport other loads of ammunition, foodstuffs and supplies. Piled high inside a hangar were the squadron's tents, some food supplies and water filtration gear. The unit is drinking about 2,000 bottles of water per day. Some 35 missions have already been flown by the group, assigned to haul cargo that has been flown or shipped in from the United States throughout the Saudi Arabian peninsula. ``It's rough, very rough,'' said a female captain from Monroe, N.C., one of the 13 women with the squadron. ``I just left a 20-month-old daughter at home.''

DOC.HEAD: Americans Advised to Leave Jordan on `Voluntary Basis'
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Embassy spokesman said Monday that American citizens in Jordan were being advised to leave ``on a voluntary basis.'' Also Monday, the Jordanian news agency reported eight Americans were among 495 passengers who flew in from Baghdad aboard an Iraqi Airways jumbo jet. Sources at Queen Alia airport said all eight were of Arab origin and carried travel documents other than their American passports. Iraq has refused to allow most Westerners to leave Iraqi territory in the aftermath of international condemnation of its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The sources would not identify the evacuees, and U.S. embassy sources said they had no information about them. Other Americans of Arab or Asian origin have been allowed to leave Iraq in recent days. Most of them crossed overland into Jordan. The U.S. Embassy spokesman, Jonathan Owen, said U.S. citizens in the kingdom were being advised to leave in accordance with a State Department advisory to all U.S. citizens ``to defer non-essential travel to Jordan.'' He added that non-essential staff at the embassy, and their dependants, were also told they were ``at liberty to leave on a voluntary basis.'' ``This is not an evacuation,'' Owen stressed. He said the decision was taken in view of the continuing tense situation following the Iraqi invasion. Jordanian government statistics say there are about 3,000 American citizens in the country, many of them with dual Jordanian-U.S. citizenship. The development came as the ailing Norwegian ambassador to Iraq and the wife of the Argentine ambassador and her daughter were among thousands of other foreigners, mainly Arabs and Asians, who arrived in Jordan on Monday. A senior Jordanian security official at the Ruweishid border post said 8,370 foreigners, mainly Arab and Asian nationals as well as a group of 122 Soviet citizens, crossed into Jordan on Monday. The diplomatic group arrived on the Iraqi Airways flight. Associated Press photgrapher Max Nash said the wife of the Argentine ambassador, Maxion Cortes Funes, was accompanied by her 7-year-old daughter, as she arrived at a hotel in Amman. Dressed in a two-piece blue suit, she looked tired but relieved to have left Iraq. Nash said she declined to say anything about the situation in Baghdad. She confirmed that the Norwegian ambassador, Harald Lone, 61, ``who is ill,'' was transferred immediately from the Iraqi jet to another aircraft waiting for his arrival. Earlier reports from the Norwegian capital, Oslo, said Lone had suffered a heart attack and that his government had asked Iraq to allow a special plane to fly into Baghdad to evacuate him. A Soviet embassy spokesman said the group of Soviets included 72 military advisers, 27 women, and 23 children. This was the second group of Soviet evacuees from Kuwait. The first group consisting mainly of 224 oil-rig workers was flown from Amman to Moscow Saturday. The embassy spokesman said there were 880 Soviet nationals in Kuwait when Iraq invaded the oil-rich sheikdom Aug. 2. The embassy spokesman said a third group of 346 Soviets was expected to cross into Jordan after the overland journey Tuesday morning. Tass, the Soviet news agency, late Monday said the third group, mostly oil workers, had arrived at the Jordanian border checkpoint. Tass said 188 Soviets remain in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Cellist Maurice Gendron Dead at Age 69
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to CORRECT spelling of Casals, Ansermet's first name, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The French cellist Maurice Gendron, who played with internationally known stars Yehudi Menuhin and Pablo Casals, died Monday at home, his family announced. He was 69. Neither funeral arrangements nor cause of death were announced. Gendron was married and the father of two children. Considered one of the greatest French cellists of the century, Gendron was born in Nice and took up the cello at age 12 at the Nice Conservatory. Gendron moved to Paris as a teen-ager and captured the prestigious first prize in cello at the Paris Conservatory in 1938. He made a name for himself playing in salons before artists like Pablo Picasso, Jean Cocteau and Francois Mauriac. Gendron played for the Paris Symphony Orchestra for more than 30 years and performed chamber music with Casals and Menuhin. He also featured as a soloist under the direction of Errest Ansermet. The Paris Conservatory made him a professor in 1970. France also awarded him two of its highest civilian honors, Officer of the Legion of Honor and the National Order of Merit.

DOC.HEAD: Seabrook Begins Regular Operation
DOC.TEXT: It's official: The Seabrook power plant, which became a symbol of the nation's debate over nuclear energy, has begun regular operation. After more than a decade of protests and huge cost overruns, the milestone was reached Sunday, utility spokesman said Ron Sher said Monday. The plant's operator, New Hampshire Yankee, emphasized the plant supplies enough electricity for a million New England homes; opponents still fret about the potential for disaster. The declaration the plant is in regular operation for the plant is partly a matter of semantics. During the final weeks of testing, which were declared successful Friday night, the $6.6 billion plant's reactor ran at full power. It has been generating at least some power for customers on the region's power grid since tests began in May. Seabrook Station is one of nine nuclear power plants in New England that together generate more than one-third of the region's electricity, reducing the dependence on ``extremely expensive and unreliable foreign oil supplies,'' said Edward Brown, president of New Hampshire Yankee. It took a decade to build the seaside plant, which was completed in 1986 but didn't receive an operating license until last spring because of regulatory delays caused by the plant's opponents. Seabrook became the national focus of anti-nuclear activists and drew opposition from nearby residents who said the surrounding area couldn't be evacuated safely if there was a nuclear disaster. More than 3,000 protesters were arrested at the plant over the years. The Clamshell Alliance, which led the protests, believes state residents should view any Seabrook landmarks as setbacks said, spokesman Roy Morrison. That's becuase the plant produces nuclear waste and has the potential to make New England uninhabitable, he said. Court challenges of the operating license still are pending, and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said last week it was looking into whether there were irregularities in the way the plant got its license. Morrison said Seabrook operators made the operation official Monday to distract attention from the commission's investigation. The project originally called for two reactors at a cost of less than $1 billion but was scaled back to one reactor because of skyrocketing costs and lengthy constrution delays. The plant's major owner _ Public Service Company of New Hampshire _ went into bankruptcy, in part because of Seabrook costs, and is being taken over by Northeast Utilities of Connecticut, another plant owner. The plant produces 1,150 megawatts of electricity, enough to eliminate the need for about 1.5 million barrels of oil a month, said New Hampshire Yankee. Iraq's invasion of oil-rich Kuwait ``make(s) it painfully clear that New England must immediately begin vigorous development of alternative domestic energy sources that are not dependent upon events halfway around the world,'' said senior vice president Ted Feigenbaum, who will soon replace the retiring Brown. Sher said each of the plant's utility owners and utility regulators in their states would decide how much to charge for electricity. Besides New Hampshire and Connecticut, companies in the Massachusetss and Vermont own shares of the plant.

DOC.HEAD: Armenian Militants Fire on Bus
DOC.TEXT: Armenian militants fired on a bus in an Azerbaijani village with machine guns and grenade launchers and, in a fight with police, one passenger and a policeman were killed, Tass reported Monday. The official Soviet news agency said the clash occurred Sunday on the Armenian-Azerbaijani border, one of the most explosive places in the Soviet Union because of ethnic tensions. The militants, in the hundreds and hidden in hills, fired at a commuter bus in Azerbaijan's Kazakh region, killing a policeman and wounding four passengers, Interior Ministry officials told Tass. Troops called to the area killed one and injured two of the terrorists. Two servicemen were also hurt. Armenian President Levon Ter-Petrosyan told his republic's parliament in the capital, Yerevan, on Monday that the clash was triggered by the capture of Armenian hostages in the area. The Armenian militants moved in to release the hostages, he said in remarks carried by Tass. The dispatch did not say who held the hostages or what the captors' demands were. Armenia and Azerbaijan, on the southern border of the Soviet Union, have been at loggerheads since February 1988 in a dispute over Nagorno-Karabakh. The district has been in Azerbaijan's hands since the 1920s, but Armenians want control over it and have been campaigning to get it with strikes, demonstrations and political moves. In another development involving one of the Soviet Union's more than 100 ethnic groups, a congress of local councilmen in a section of the Moldavian republic, located on the Romanian border, declared formation of a new republic on Sunday. Tass reported Monday that the Gagauz, a Christian Turkish people who are a small minority in Moldavia, sent a message to the Kremlin requesting recognition of the Gagauz republic as part of the Soviet Union. It was unlikely the Kremlin would go along with the move because creation of a new republic requires the consent of other affected republics, and that hasn't come yet.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Planning Trip to Iraq, Associate Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 5 grafs with Jackson not leaving immediately, purpose not made clear; picks up at pvs 5th graf, The trip
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson hopes to fly to the Mideast to meet with Iraqi officials, Jackson associates said Monday. The purpose of such a trip by the civil rights leader was not clear, but one source, who declined to be identified, said it involved Americans held hostage in Iraq. Jackson's office referred callers to Michael Lender, who is working with Jackson on an upcoming television talk show. Lender would say only that Jackson did not plan to leave for the Middle East immediately. Jackson's schedule for Tuesday showed him meeting in the morning with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to discuss civil rights and voting rights matters. Earlier Monday, President Bush for the first time characterized the 530 Americans in Iraq and the 2,500 in Kuwait as hostages. The trip, not officially sanctioned by the Bush administration, would be the latest in a series of trips Jackson has made to world trouble spots. He visited the Persian Gulf in 1987, meeting with Saudi Arabian and Jordanian leaders and delivering 600 pounds of Christmas gifts for the crew of a U.S. warship. In 1984, Syrian President Hafez Assad released a downed U.S. Navy pilot, Lt. Robert Goodman, to Jackson. Also in 1984 Jackson went to Cuba to visit Fidel Castro, who then released some two dozen Americans from his jails. That same year he went to Nicaragua, where he praised the Sandinista government, to Panama and to El Salvador where he tried to mediate differences between Salvadoran rebels and then-President Napoleon Duarte. Jackson, a former Democratic presidential candidate, plans to host a syndicated television show starting this fall. He has spent much of the past year involved in District of Columbia politics. He is a candidate for the position of ``shadow'' senator in the Sept. 11 Democratic primary election. The post, which carries no salary, is designed to lobby Congress for statehood for the nation's capital.

DOC.HEAD: `Floating Hotel' With 49 Aboard Afloat in North Sea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 3rd graf with 3 grafs to update with wind dying, two boats trailing rig, QE2 told it can leave.
DOC.TEXT: A ``floating hotel'' with 49 oil field workers aboard broke loose while being towed during a storm in the North Sea and was floating free in rough seas Monday, Phillips Petroleum Co. said. No injuries were reported and the captain decided that all personnel should remain aboard until the waves abate and a new towline can be attached, said George Minter, a spokesman at Phillips headquarters in Bartlesville. ``They're waiting for the wind to die down and it looks like it's going to, according to the weather reports,'' Minter said Monday afternoon. He said the rig was located about 80 miles off the coast of Denmark. Two boats from Denmark were trailing the rig, he said. The Queen Elizabeth II was in the area when the towline broke and had been standing by to help if needed. But after the two Danish boats began watching over the floating rig, the luxury liner was told it could proceed on its normal course, Minter said. The floating rig _ which Phillips calls an accommodation jackup rig _ houses people working on offshore drilling rigs, Minter said. He said wind blew as high as 60 mph while the rig was being towed, at a speed of about 4 knots, in the Norwegian sector of the North Sea oilfields. The weather was becoming calmer Monday and four helicopters plus ships in the area were keeping watch on the floating rig, Minter said. Phillips had the rig, owned by a Norwegian contractor, on longterm lease, Minter said. Only two of the people aboard the rig were Phillips employees; the rest work for the Norwegian contractor, Minter said.

DOC.HEAD: Missouri Man Arrives Home After Escape From Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Diemler comments Monday, picking up at the 5th graf previous, ``The 5-year-old....'' ADDS 7 grafs at the end with other escapees.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ST1 of Aug. 19
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An American who escaped from Kuwait by dashing across the desert disguised as an Arab said Monday that Westerners still trapped there might be able to escape if they're willing to risk it. Steve Diemler, 35, was reunited with his family at his parents' home here Sunday. He escaped to Saudi Arabia on Friday in a convoy of 13 vehicles carrying 30 to 40 foreigners. ``I would tell them to get out if they can, take the risk,'' Diemler said in an interview Monday. ``I couldn't have made it by myself and wouldn't advise anyone to do it alone. You have to have someone extremely knowledgeable about the area.'' But he added: ``It is up to the individual to weigh the risk. I took the chance and made it and hope others can do it behind me. But I don't want to tell a bunch of people to do it and get them killed.'' He said his convoy was guided across the open desert by Bedouin nomads who refused to take any money for their assistance. The only thing they wanted, he said, was the promise of American help. He decided to make his escape after Iraq last week ordered foreigners in Kuwait to go to specific hotels. ``I mean nobody really thought it was for our own protection,'' he said Sunday. ``Everybody knew the next stop would be Baghdad or someplace else. We knew it was turning into a formal hostage situation.'' The 35-year-old Jefferson City native, who has lived in Kuwait for 10 years working as a radar adviser to the Kuwait Air Force, arrived Sunday in a St. Louis TV station's helicopter that landed in a field next to his parents' home. Family and friends waited in the front yard where yellow ribbons were tied to the trunks and limbs of a half-dozen trees. Wearing a T-shirt with the question, ``Where In the World Is Kuwait?'' one of his first comments was: ``I got out of a place that's not so nice a place to be.'' Diemler said he managed to escape because ``I knew people who might know people.'' He said he wore the traditional outfit for Kuwait men of a long white robe and headband with scarf to disguise his Western appearance. ``The escape was the most frightening because it was going out into the unknown. We had heard all kinds of things,'' he said. ``At the start, I thought it was a pretty desperate thing. There's no way to be sure Iraqis wouldn't shoot at us and we were in close proximity of tanks, armored personnel carriers and troops.'' While waiting for the guides to arrive, Diemler said, Iraqi soldiers drove by three times but didn't stop. ``I thought it was all over before it ever started,'' he said. He said after the convoy started out, they were forced to turn around by Iraqi troops. The convoy went a few miles down the road, turned off into the desert and headed out as fast as they could travel. He declined to give specific details of his escape because, ``I wouldn't want to say anything that might jeopardize the chances of somebody else who is going to follow me.'' Elsewhere, Robert and Katherine Hansen of Tulsa, Okla., said Monday they decided to try to escape from Kuwait after hearing the borders would be open on Aug. 13. Hansen, a consultant to the Kuwait Ministry of Health, said a sandstorm made them turn back on their first attempt, but they met a group of people preparing to leave. ``They had seven cars and someone who knew the desert,'' said Hansen, former dean of the Oral Roberts University dental college. The group of 18 had to abandon one car stuck in the sand and cross several large oil pipelines during the three-hour drive to the Saudi Arabian border, he said. ``We were led on a route that did not have Iraqi soldiers,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Trapped Americans `Hostages,' Says US Not Intimidated
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts new 22nd graf, An NBC, with poll finding support for Bush
DOC.TEXT: President Bush declared for the first time Monday that 3,000 Americans trapped in Iraq and Kuwait are hostages. ``America will not be intimidated,'' he said, demanding their release as the U.S. buildup of forces in the region proceeded at full speed. ``I want there to be no misunderstanding. I will hold the government of Iraq responsible for the safety of American citizens held against their will,'' Bush told cheering war veterans in a blistering speech in Baltimore. ``It could get fairly tough over there,'' he said later at a Republican fund-raising appearance in North Kingstown, R.I. Bush called Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``a man of evil standing against human life itself.'' But he added, ``It was not with passionate hate but really with a heavy heart that I had to commit our troops to Saudi Arabia'' to head off possible Iraqi attack. No shots have been fired in that desert standoff, but U.S. warships have sent warning shots near two Iraqi tankers in an effort to enforce an embargo on goods going in or out of Iraq. Asked late Monday whether the United States was prepared to stop the tankers, which kept moving despite the warning, Bush said merely, ``Just watch. Just watch and see.'' In Kuwait City, meanwhile, at least 12 Americans along with a number of other foreigners were taken from hotels and moved to undisclosed locations, the State Department said. The Americans were among 2,500 U.S. citizens who were in the Persian Gulf country when it was overrun by Iraqi forces three weeks ago. About 530 others are in Iraq. Thirty-five Americans who had been taken from Kuwait to a hotel in Baghdad were removed last week and remain unaccounted for, U.S. officials said. Without giving any numbers, Iraq said Monday it had moved Westerners to potential U.S. military target areas, and it warned its people not to hide foreigners. The official Iraqi News Agency quoted a spokesman for Baghdad's ruling National Council as saying: ``Iraq's foreign guests have been in fact moved to all vital and military installations. They have been provided with all modern facilities and they are all in good physical condition.'' Elsewhere in the inflamed gulf region, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney claimed success in an early stop on a support-seeking trip, announcing that the United Arab Emirates had agreed to let a squadron of U.S. military transport planes use their land. In Saudi Arabia, military officials said the United States was moving significant forces with offensive capabilities into positions from which they could launch strikes into occupied Kuwait, according to military officials. ``I don't see us going into Kuwait but if those orders ever came we would obviously want to be ready,'' one senior U.S. officer said in a news media pool report. In Washington, the State Department advised Americans to defer non-essential travel to Jordan in light of ``continuing unstable conditions in the region.'' A stiffer advisory was issued for Yemen _ non-essential embassy personnel and dependents were ordered to leave and all other American citizens without essential reasons for remaining were advised to do so as well _ after anti-American demonstrations in the capital of Sanaa. Bush, in his speech to the Veterans of Foreign Wars, renewed his call for Saddam to release Americans and thousands of other Westerners in Iraq and Kuwait. The president again compared Saddam to Hitler, and also accused him of violating his own religion. With no sign of a non-military solution to the heightening Persian Gulf crisis in sight, Bush told the veterans, ``Today, the outcome is not yet decided. Hard choices remain. But of this we are certain: America will not be intimidated.'' Bush had previously refused to use the word ``hostages'' to characterize the detained Americans. Aides pointed out that Saddam had not asked for anything in return for their release and also said that calling them hostages might make them seem more significant and make it harder for Saddam to release them. On Sunday, in fact, presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater took issue with U.N. Ambassador Thomas Pickering's use of the word. But Bush on Monday said it was time to state the obvious: ``We've been reluctant to use the term hostage. But when Saddam Hussein specifically offers to trade the freedom of those citizens of many nations he holds against their will in return for concessions, there can be little doubt that whatever these innocent people are called, they are in fact hostages.'' Saddam's government said Sunday that the foreigners would be allowed freedom if the United States withdrew its military forces from the Persian Gulf region and scuttled the international trade blockade against Iran and Kuwait _ an offer the administration quickly rejected. An NBC News-Wall Street Journal poll conducted over the weekend found that 72 percent of those surveyed approve of how Bush is handling the crisis. Seventy percent said they approve of the president's decision to send military forces to Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf. The telephone poll of 805 registered voters had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percent, NBC said. On a one-day trip from Kennebunkport, Maine, where he was in the second week of a vacation, Bush traveled to the White House for meetings, then to Baltimore and on to Rhode Island before returning to Maine. Back in Kennebunkport, Bush telephoned French President Francois Mitterrand to talk about the hostage situation and thank him for France's ``firm response and leadership'' in the crisis. He also called Turkey's president, Turgut Ozal, with warm words. And in his Rhode Island remarks, he praised Britain's prime minister, Margaret Thatcher, as well. The White House says there are no plans for him to cut off the annual vacation before his planned Labor Day return to Washington. His speech Monday included some of the most fiery remarks he has made on the crisis, following a weekend when he testily rebuffed reporters' attempts to question him while he played golf and went to church services. In his speech, Bush made a religious appeal to the leaders of Iraq. ``In moving foreign citizens against their will, you are violating the norms of your own religion,'' he said. ``You are going against the age-old Arab tradition of showing kindness and hospitality to visitors. And so my message is: Release all foreigners now.'' ``Iraq's invasion was more than a military attack on tiny Kuwait,'' he said of the Aug. 2 military incursion by Iraq on its oil-rich neighbor. ``It was a ruthless assault on the very essence of international order and civilized ideals. And now, in a further offense against all norms of international behavior, Iraq has imposed restrictions against civilians from many countries. This is unacceptable.'' Bush said the eruption of the crisis in the Persian Gulf demonstrated a need for a strong military and he called on Congress to avoid deep cuts in his military budget beyond the paring his administration recommends.

DOC.HEAD: Tourists Allowed Back on Roads into Valley
LaserPhoto XYOS1
DOC.TEXT: Tourists flocked back to Yosemite Valley on Monday after being kept away for 11 days by wildfires that disrupted the park's centennial season. Most campsites in the valley and all rooms at Yosemite Lodge had been reserved in advance by people anxious to begin long-awaited vacations amidst the park's granite monoliths and waterfalls. Vehicles were lined up for about 1{ miles when rangers opened the State Route 41 entrance to the valley floor. ``We were just hoping the valley would open back up before we got here; it worked out,'' said a relieved Linda Disosway of Atlanta. She had worried that the fires would keep the park closed on Monday, the one day she, her husband, John, and their three children had reservations. None of those driving into the park was happier than Tim and Erika Dallacqua of Ventura County in Southern California. They were supposed to have been married Saturday in Yosemite Valley but were wed instead in the campground at Wawona because the valley floor _ focus of most park visits _ still was closed. ``We were married right on the riverbed,'' she said. ``It was gorgeous.'' The newlyweds ventured into Yosemite Valley on Monday because they had honeymoon reservations for the night at the stately Ahwahnee Hotel. ``Then we have to get back to work,'' he said. Rene and Dennis Navarre of LaVerne, Calif., were part of a group of 16 who decided not to cancel their reservations for this week when park officials assured them most of the smoke was out of the valley. ``It's so great for kids,'' Rene Navarre said. ``Up here, you can have a family life. The hardest part is doing meals. Dennis does that.'' ``She cooks the rest of the year,'' her husband said. ``I cook when we're camping.'' Linda Brown of San Diego said she was depressed when she and her husband couldn't get into the valley on schedule Saturday, but ``missing two days was OK.'' Her husband, Bob, looked up at the royal blue sky with a few white clouds and proclaimed: ``It's beautiful here.'' The park was closed to visitors Aug. 9 by two major lightning-caused fires that blackened 23,000 acres of land in and near Yosemite. The fires were contained during the weekend. Even though flames never came near Yosemite Valley, people traveling there can expect to see the results of the fires elsewhere. ``Visitors will see burned trees, burned brush and burned ground,'' park spokeswoman Mallory Smith said. ``Smoke is still in the air.'' To satisfy visitors' curiosity, park officials have prepared colored maps that show where the fires burned. Superintendent Mike Finley said it was the first time fires had forced closure of the park 150 miles southeast of San Francisco. The fires, part of a series that burned up and down the Sierra Nevada range, broke out only weeks before Yosemite's centennial celebration, which is scheduled for Oct. 1. Park officials said President Bush may attend.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Puzzled By Mex-Americans' Low Rate; Much Better Than Blacks'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 3rd graf pvs: `They have...,' to ADD when study released.
DOC.TEXT: Researchers aren't sure why, but a study has found that Mexican-Americans, whose prenatal care is as poor as blacks', nonetheless have a much lower infant mortality rate, even slightly lower than whites. Mexican-American women and their babies are ``a real anomaly,'' said Dr. Joel C. Kleinman, an analyst with the National Center for Health Statistics, a branch of the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease Control. They ``have a much, much lower level of education, tend to be poorer and get relatively little prenatal care, but they do very well'' in infant mortality, he said. In an interview last week, he discussed the study which was released in July. ``There are a number of hypotheses'' why Mexican-American infants have a better survival rate than black infants, Kleinman said. Those include ``a lot more social support than other comparable groups, like blacks,'' and ``maybe some dietary factors we are not aware of,'' he said. ``We have to really do a lot more study of Mexican-Americans to understand why they do so well,'' he said. The study found that 18.7 out of every 1,000 black infants born in the United States died before their first birthday, more than double the white rate and worst of any ethnic group studied. But Mexican-Americans' infant mortality rate was only 9.0, slightly better than the white rate of 9.1. That's true even though only about 60 percent of Mexican-American women got prenatal care in the first trimester, the same percentage as black, Puerto Rican and American Indian women. Among white, Cuban and Asian women in this country, about 80 percent got early prenatal care. Mexican-American women also have a higher percentage of teen-age births than whites _ 18 percent to 11 percent _ but less than black women at 24 percent. Health experts say infants of teen-age mothers are at increased risk for health complications, probably due to poorer economic standing, nutrition and medical care. ``Mexicans are the third largest minority group in the United States, accounting for one-quarter million births per year,'' the researchers' report said. ``They appear to have relatively good pregnancy outcomes, despite a high rate of poverty and low use of prenatal care.'' The latest overall infant mortality rate for the nation is 10.4 per 1,000 births _ just 22nd in the world _ in early reports from 1986 statistics. Federal health officials project a 1990 rate of 9.1. The lowest infant mortality rate in the United States is for Japanese-American infants, 6 per 1,000. Asian-Americans in general have a rate of 8.6, slightly better than whites and Mexican-Americans. Cuban-Americans also have a low infant mortality rate, 7.8 per 1,000. ``One of the explanations for Cubans ... is their generally higher socioeconomic group,'' Kleinman said. ``Generally, they're about the same as U.S.-born whites.'' The statistics in the study come from 1983 and 1984 birth and death certificates, the latest available when the comprehensive study was launched. Hispanic data come from 23 states which collect such statistics. The study is the first to match birth and death files in an attempt to avoid earlier inconsistencies in classifying Hispanics, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted In Rape, Attempted Murder of Jogger
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Monday convicted a 23-year-old man of raping, beating and stabbing a jogger, who staggered for help with a knife stuck in her neck. Erwin Williams, of Syracuse, was convicted of second-degree attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, unlawful imprisonment, assault and possession of weapons in the 1986 attack. A second man, Ronald Jock, 32, of Brasher Falls, pleaded guilty to second-degree attempted murder last month in a plea bargain with prosecutors. Jock, along with the victim, testified against Williams during his weeklong trial in state Supreme Court, the state's trial-level court. It took jurors just 2{ hours to reach a verdict. Williams confessed to the attack, but later refused to sign the written statement he gave police. ``Given the district attorney's case, I don't think he expected to walk out of here,'' said his attorney, William Rose. The victim, a 43-year-old suburban Syracuse woman, was choked, beaten and stabbed 11 times during the Sept. 20, 1986 attack, which occurred while she was jogging in Onondaga Lake Park in this city 250 miles northwest of New York. She walked about two miles for help with a knife protuding from her neck. ``This is one of the most heinous crimes ever committed in this county,'' said Onondaga County Assistant District Attorney Mary Felasco. ``The defendant got his just desserts. Justice was served.'' The verdict was handed down just two days after three youths were convicted in Manhattan in the much-publicized 1989 rape and assault of the Central Park jogger. Like the Syracuse woman, she survived despite serious injuries. But unlike the Syracuse victim, the Central Park jogger suffered brain damage and could not identify her attackers. Felasco said she would seek consecutive sentences on the rape and attempted murder charges when Williams is sentenced by state Supreme Court Justice Walter Gorman on Sept. 5. The maximum sentence for each is 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Conductor Leonard Bernstein Cancels European Tour
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf pvs, `Maestro Bernstein...,' to ADD conductor's age.
DOC.TEXT: Conductor Leonard Bernstein on Monday canceled a six-city European tour for health reasons. Bernstein hasn't recovered from a series of respiratory ailments that plagued him last winter and spring, Harry Kraut, Bernstein's personal manager, said in a news release. He had been scheduled to tour with an orchestra from the Tanglewood Music Center, a summer training center for young musicians where Bernstein began his career in 1940. ``Maestro Bernstein deeply regrets that he must follow his doctor's instructions and cancel his participation,'' Kraut said. Bernstein's 72nd birthday is Saturday. The tour, scheduled from Aug. 22 through Sept. 3, was to have been the first time the center performed outside Tanglewood. It was to have included concerts in Germany, Austria and Spain.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Drank Cocaine-Laced Soda Dies
DOC.TEXT: A man who slipped into a coma after drinking a Colombian soft drink that had been laced with cocaine in an apparent smuggling scheme died Monday after doctors disconnected life-support equipment. Maximo Rene Menendez, 25, collapsed July 26 after drinking from a six-ounce bottle of Pony Malta de Bavaria that contained many times the lethal dose of cocaine. Drinking just one gram of the drug can be fatal, investigators said. ``His life support was disconnected at 5:02 p.m. and he expired at 5:15,'' said Victor Maya, executive director of AMI Kendall Regional Medical Center. ``There was absolutely nothing that could be done for this man.'' Menendez's family had a court order to cut off his life support on Aug. 13 after neurologists concluded he had no brain activity. But his leg moved and he took shallow breaths after the respirator was turned off the next day. Doctors reconnected the equipment and the family asked for a second opinion by experts at the University of Miami, who agreed Menendez was brain dead without hope of recovery, Maya said. FBI experts have discovered at least 45 contaminated bottles containing 20 to 40 grams of the drug in a 1,000-case shipment of the soft drink. Federal officials warned consumers that hundreds of cases of Pony Malta distributed in South Florida were unaccounted for. The FBI wants to question Hugo Alfredo Rios, whose Miami Sweet company imported the shipment from Cerveceria Bavaria S.A. in Colombia. The bottler said Rios was unauthorized to import the drink.

DOC.HEAD: Israel to Allow Transit by Egyptians Fleeing Iraq, Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS throughout to ADD figures from Egyptian officials on number of returnees, comments by returning Egyptians about abuses by Iraqi troops. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Israel will allow Egyptians fleeing Iraq and Kuwait to travel through the Jewish state on their way home, Israeli television said Monday. The television report said Egyptian Ambassador Mohammed Bassiouny met with Foreign Minister David Levy to request that Egyptians stranded in Jordan after leaving Iraq be allowed to transit Israel. The television report quoted Levy as saying ``it seemed a natural step to help the citizens of a friendly nation fleeing tyranny.'' Meanwhile, Egypt's official Middle East News Agency quoted a source in the Egyptian Foreign Ministry as denying reports that Egyptians returning home from Iraq would pass through Israel. But a top Israeli official confirmed that Egyptians stuck in the Jordanian port of Aqaba awaiting transportation home would start traveling through Israel within days. The Egyptians will travel the five miles from Aqaba to the Israeli resort of Eilat on the Red Sea, and then four miles to the Israeli-Egyptian border at Taba, said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``We are just being humanitarian and good neighborly,'' the official said. The official said Bassiouny will travel to Cairo on Tuesday to formally inform President Hosni Mubarak of Israel's decision. Many Egyptians who have reached Jordan are unable to get air or sea transport home. Bassiouny told Levy that thousands of Egyptians are stranded in Aqaba and the situation is growing worse daily, according to the Israeli television report. More than 54,000 Egyptians have already returned to Egypt after fleeing Kuwait and Iraq, and tens of thousands of others are still on their way, according to Egyptian officials. Some of the returning Egyptian refugees have accused Iraqi troops of stealing their valuables and raping women in Kuwait. Israel army radio reported that Egypt sent 35 buses to Aqaba on Monday. The radio report said Egyptians traveling from Aqaba through Israel would not be subject to a passport check. Usually Egyptians crossing the Israeli border are thoroughly searched. Israel has been considering this move since thousands of Egyptians and other foreigners began fleeing into Jordan after Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Despite the importance Israel places on its relations with Egypt, Israeli officials had hesitated to open the tightly guarded border to permit thousands of Egyptians to pass through daily. Egypt is the only Arab country to have signed a peace treaty with Israel _ the 1979 Camp David accords under which Israel agreed to return the Sinai Peninsula to Egypt. The Israeli action comes after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein announced that he will hold Westerners in Iraq and Kuwait, using some of them as human shields at strategic installations. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak has sent several thousand troops to Saudi Arabia as part of a multinational Arab force to deter a possible Iraqi attack. But despite the Egyptian government's actions, Saddam has allowed thousands of Egyptians to cross into Jordan. Before the crisis, there were an estimated 150,000 Egyptians in Kuwait and 1.6 million in Iraq. On Monday, 700 Egyptian refugees arrived in the port of Suez on board the Egyptian ferry el-Tor that sailed from Aqaba. Some of the passengers recounted tales of horror following the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. They said Iraqi soldiers' treatment of Egyptians worsened after Mubarak hosted the Aug. 10 Arab League summit in Cairo that decided to send a joint Arab force to Saudi Arabia. ``I saw four Iraqi soldiers burst into the hosptial where I work and take away two nurses to rape,'' said Samia Ibrahim, a 30-year-old nurse. ``They forced us to work for 14-hour shifts with no pay and they stole our food and money. ``In order to let us through, they stole our video tapes and any other electric appliances,'' she said. Hossam el-Din Zaky el-Sayed, 26, said Iraqi soldiers even stole his watch before letting him leave. The returnees said they left most of their money and valuables behind. Officials say Egyptian expatriates had billions of dollars in Kuwaiti banks, most of which have been looted by Iraqi soldiers.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Calls for Tax Increase to Ease City Deficit
DOC.TEXT: Mayor W. Wilson Goode, urging Philadelphians not to panic, pleaded with the state and the City Council Monday night to help him raise taxes and cut spending to avoid a $206 million deficit. ``We are not bankrupt,'' Goode said. However, ``we must stop reading lips and start read the writing on the wall. This city needs new tax revenues.'' He spoke as his administration announced an emergency borrowing plan needed to keep the city from running out of cash next month. Goode, during an half-hour televised speech, called on the state Legislature to give the city power to increase taxes by $150 million. The tax burden would be spread among consumers, homeowners and businesses, he said. Goode also called for the lease or sale of Veterans Stadium _ home of baseball's Phillies and the football Eagles. Other city assets also might be sold, including the Water Department. On Monday, Goode's administration announced plans to borrow $400 million through temporary loan notes within the next two weeks. Without the notes, the city would be out of cash by late September, according to a report issued Monday by City Finance Director Betsy Reveal. Even with them, the city's general fund would be out of cash by May ``unless both interim and permanent corrective measures are taken,'' the report said. Goode said the city's financial problems grew over decades, with previous administrations merely taking temporary steps to avoid crises, and were exacerbated by the recession now gripping the Northeast. He also blamed the state Legislature, saying its power to prevent tax increases is strangling the city. Goode also criticized the City Council, saying it repeatedly has thwarted his attempts to raise taxes over the years. He asked the council to cooperate and outlined several steps needed he said must be taken immediately: _A freeze on city hiring and developments. _A repeal of the city's early retirement program. _An assessment of the measures the city's unions are willing to undertake to cut costs. _A cut in all non-essential services, which he did not list. _A complete assessment of buildings that could be sold or leased. Goode's speech was his first public reaction since word of the impending financial crisis leaked out a week ago. The note sale is expected the week of Aug. 27 unless the city can obtain a letter of credit, in which case it would be postponed one week, said Reveal. The city reportedly has had trouble attracting buyers for the notes. Lead underwriter for the public offering will be Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The city's fiscal 1991 budget, which was balanced on paper when it was passed in May, projected the deficit for the previous fiscal year would amount to $60.8 million. However, the deficit was swollen by sluggish tax receipts on commercial property and other tax receipts and is projected at $73.8 million in the new report. That amount must be paid during the current 1991 fiscal year, which began June 30. According to the report, 1991 revenues will be $106.2 million less than expected when the budget was adopted and obligations will be $132.3 million more than expected. The decrease in revenues was blamed partly on the state Legislature's refusal to approve a half-cent local sales tax and mandatory withholding of the city wage tax. The $206.4 million deficit projection does not include a $45 million subsidy for the regional mass-transit system. Goode has vowed to withhold the subsidy for Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority unless the city gets approval of and revenue from a local sales tax.

DOC.HEAD: USAir Plane Burns after Being Flipped by Wind
DOC.TEXT: A USAir commuter plane was flipped over Monday by a gust of wind from a thunderstorm at Charlotte-Douglas International Airport and burst into flames, leaving two people with minor injuries, officials said. The plane was waiting on the runway for passengers to board when a gust of wind estimated at 77 miles an hour overturned it, said Jan Haggerty, a spokeswoman for Charlotte-based CCAir. CCAir operated plane under contract to USAir. The pilot and a flight attendant escaped befor the fire, she said. The two injured people, whose names were withheld, were taken to Carolinas Medical Center where they were treated for cuts and bruises and released, said Catherine Rencher, a hospital spokeswoman. Jerry Orr, airport aviation director, said the $7 million plane, which seats 36 people, was a total loss.

DOC.HEAD: Zaire Students Given Ultimatum to Leave Embassy
DOC.TEXT: About 40 Zairean students who have been occupying their embassy in Beijing for six days were given an ultimatum Monday by Chinese authorities to leave immediately, the students said. The students began their occupation last Wednesday, holding the ambassador and his staff hostage in the walled embassy compound. The students are protesting their government's failure to provide promised living allowances and plane tickets home for graduates. At about noon, six Chinese officials from the Chinese Foreign Ministry, the State Education Commission and the Beijing Public Security Bureau came to the Zairean Embassy to deliver the ultimatum. ``They told us that we had to leave immediately. If we don't, they will take the necessary measures,'' said Katembo Salumu, 29, who graduated from Qinghua University this summer. The officials did not elaborate, but cautioned that this was ``the last warning,'' the students said. The Education Commission confirmed the visit took place, but refused to give details. The Foreign Ministry said it had no comment. The Chinese government had not previously been involved in the dispute, although several uniformed and plainclothed police in a Public Security car kept watch outside the embassy each day. It is the second year in a row the students have staged a sit-in at the embassy with the same complaints. Zairean Ambassador Lombo Lo Mangamanga said the police last year refused to enter the compound when he asked them to remove the students. The students said Monday's visit was prompted by a meeting in Zaire between their foreign minister, Mushobekwa Wakalimba, and the Chinese ambassador. Salumu said the students told the Chinese authorities, ``This is not a problem with the Chinese _ it's with our own government.'' ``We told them we will stay here. If they want to take any measures, it's up to them. We are not scared,'' said Bangala Ngoy, 29, a graduate student at Shanghai's Huadong Chemical Engineering College. The students have said they would stay at the embassy until they get their living subsidies, which have not been paid in at least 14 months, and until their government pays for air tickets home for seven graduates. The students have locked the embassy compound gates with a bicycle chain, refusing to allow the half-dozen Zairean diplomats out or the embassy's Chinese staff in. Last Thursday, Mangamanga arranged for the Chinese government to provide plane tickets for the students who had none, but the students refused to accept the settlement, arguing that their government should pay for the tickets it promised to provide. The students said they were told the Zaire foreign minister told the Chinese ambassador that funds for their living allowances have been transferred to Belgium, from where it would be forwarded to Beijing. Zaire has about 80 Zairean studying in China _ one of the largest groups of African students here.
