Under friendship agreements signed in the 1960s, China gives scholarships to students from many African countries to complete entire degree programs in China, usually in the sciences. Each year, students from several African countries complain that they are not getting promised funds and plane tickets home from their governments.

DOC.HEAD: Desert-Trained Regiment Ships Out to Middle East
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers sweltering in the Middle East will get some seasoned help soon, when the 3rd Armored Cavalry, one of the Army's elite desert units, ships out, officials said Monday. The entire regiment, with nearly 4,500 soldiers, 1,700 vehicles and 75 aircraft, will be dispatched to the Persian Gulf, said the regiment's commander, Col. Doug Starr. He said his troops are used to dealing with the searing heat and wind-whipped sand they'll encounter while helping the United States face off with Iraq's Saddam Hussein, whose troops are massed on the border of Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. The unit regularly leaves Fort Bliss to train in southern New Mexico, West Texas and the California desert. ``We're well trained in the desert, used to the desert, acclimated to the desert,'' Starr said. ``We feel we are ready to deploy to whatever part of the Middle East the commander in chief may want to send us.'' Starr said the unit knows from experience how to keep military working in the harsh desert climate, how much water each soldier needs and how to endure insufferable temperatures inside a tank. ``The inside of a tank in this type of environment is a tough place to be ... It requires a lot of physical fitness a lot of desert acclimation ... There's just no easy answer to how you defeat the heat,'' said Starr. It may be thoroughly trained, but the unit lacks combat experience. Starr said he and one other officer and a few senior enlisted soldiers are the only members of the regiment with combat experience. The regiment will act as a flank guard or on scouting missions, doing reconnaissance and feeding intelligence to other units. ``What we'll lend to that theater is a great deal of combat power,'' Starr said. The regiment has been loading vehicles on rail cars since Aug. 5 and post officials announced Thursday that the unit was deploying, a military term that means the troops are on alert, preparing for movement and likely to move at any time. Fort Bliss officials refuse to reveal when the unit will actually move.

DOC.HEAD: Cargo Ship Burning In Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian-owned cargo ship caught fire Monday in the Atlantic Ocean about 240 miles southwest of Ireland, the coast guard said. The Indian master of the 37,000-ton bulk carrier Innovator, believed to have a crew of 31, reported no injuries and said there was no need to evacuate the vessel, a coast guard spokesman in Falmouth said. The fire broke out in the accommodation quarters of the Bahamian-registered vessel, the spokesman said. He said the master later reported the crew brought the blaze under control, had restarted the engines and expected to continue its voyage to the St. Lawrence Seaway. The British-registered cargo vessel MV Ullswater went to the scene carrying hoses, firefighting foam and breathing apparatus, but help was not needed, the spokesman said. The master told the coast guard the carrier has no cargo on board, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Pearl Bailey Probably Died Of Heart Attack
DOC.TEXT: Singer Pearl Bailey most likely died of a heart attack, although the cause of death won't be known precisely for a few weeks, a hospital officials said Monday. Autopsy results suggest a heart attack, but tests to confirm that aren't complete, said Dr. Emanuel Rubin, chairman of the pathology department at Jefferson Medical College, which conducted the autopsy. The 72-year-old singer, who had a history of heart ailments, died Friday evening at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital, which is connected with the college. She was unconscious when she was rushed to the hospital and was pronounced dead a half hour later. Rubin said a provisional diagnosis showed Miss Bailey had significant narrowing of the coronary arteries, the main source of blood for the heart muscle. ``If (the heart) doesn't receive enough blood, that's a heart attack,'' he said. ``The conclusive diagnosis will be made from an examination of microscopic slides, which will be available in a few weeks.''

DOC.HEAD: American Missionary Killed in Liberia; Informal Truce Reported
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with hometown, age, details. Picks up 4th pvs, `A second...'
DOC.TEXT: Diplomats said Monday that government troops in Liberia had killed an American missionary, and there were reports that one of Liberia's rebel factions had reached an informal truce with the government. The missionary, a Baptist, was killed by government troops who arrested him Thursday, according to diplomats. They said the body of the slain man, identified as Clark Alan Jacobsen, 42, of Sterling, Alaska, was handed over to the U.S. Embassy on Saturday. The embassy was filing a formal protest with the government, the diplomats said. They did not say why Jacobsen was detained. Jacobsen traveled to Liberia last September with Joel Poe of Sterling as missionaries for the Sterling-based Frontiers of Faith Ministries. Poe returned to Alaska in October but Jacobsen stayed to continue his mission work, according to Poe, who said Jacobsen had planned to return home next month. A second American arrested and accused of fighting for the rebels, Andrew Voros of New Jersey, was freed Saturday and evacuated from Monrovia by U.S. Marines, the diplomats said. Jacobsen was the second American known to have died in Liberia's 8-month-old civil war, which has left at least 5,000 people dead, most of them civilians. A Protestant missionary, Tom Jackson, and his British wife June were killed March 24 near Bahn, a town in northeastern Nimba county where they had lived for years. They were forced by soldiers to travel in a convoy that was ambushed by guerrillas loyal to rebel leader Charles Taylor. Most of the 6,000 Americans who had livedin Liberia were missionaries. After the deaths of the Jacksons, the U.S. Embassy in Monrovia put out the first of several warnings for Americans to leave. Meanwhile, followers of rebel leader Prince Johnson and troops loyal to President Samuel Doe told a Western diplomat they were prepared to join forces to resist a possible attack by rebels from a rival faction opposed to the truce. Those rebels, led by Taylor, are camped out on the outskirts of the capital, Monrovia. There was no official announcement of a cease-fire from either Johnson or Doe. News of the truce was received in a radio telephone call from diplomats in Monrovia to their embassies in Abidjan, capital of neighboring Ivory Coast. ``The diplomat said he found AFL (Armed Forces of Liberia) and INPF (Independent National Patriotic Front) troops dancing in the streets, saying it was all over,'' said one diplomat in Abidjan. He spoke on condition of anonymity. ``As part of the celebration, they were throwing money into the air and both lots of soldiers together with some civilians in the streets were looting what was left in the stores,'' the diplomat said. He said there was speculation that the lower ranks of the military and the Prince Johnson rebel faction ``patched it up themselves because everybody is thoroughly fed up with the whole thing.'' The rebellion to oust Doe reached Monrovia in June. Since then, the city has been battered by rockets and mortars. Bodies litter the streets and all the hospitals are closed. Government soldiers and rebels have plundered shops and homes and beleaguered residents have been without fresh food supplies, water, electricity and telephone communication for nearly two months. It was unclear if Monday's truce would hold. The cease-fire comes as West African leaders trying to halt the fighting prepare for a peace conference scheduled to start next week in Banjul, Gambia. Taylor and Doe plan to send envoys to the meeting. Johnson, who split with Taylor in February and formed a rival faction, has also said he would attend. A six-nation task force of the Economic Community of West African States was mobilizing in Freetown, Sierra Leone, to sail to Monrovia to enforce a truce. Thousands of Guinean troops have been stationed on Liberia's northwestern border since Taylor's rebels began crossing into Guinea to kill Liberian refugees of the Mandingo tribe. Taylor's rebels have accused the Mandingo of supporting Doe.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Demands Release of Foreigners in Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International on Monday demanded the immediate release of all foreigners detained in Iraq and Kuwait, and protested reported human rights abuses by Iraqi troops in Kuwait. The London-based rights organization said it is sending appeals to the Iraqi government in Baghdad, Iraq's mission to the United Nations, and Iraqi ambassadors in key countries. Amnesty expressed concern about Iraq's plan to detain as many as 13,000 Westerners. Amnesty said holding foreign nationals was ``arbitrary and contrary to fundamental internationally recognized standards of human rights'' and demanded their immediate and unconditional release. It cited reports that up to 200 Westerners were being held in Baghdad hotels and that others had been moved from hotels in Kuwait to secret locations, possibly including military and industrial installations in Iraq. The organization said it was also concerned about reported rapes, killings and summary executions by Iraqi forces in Kuwait. Amnesty said it had received information, impossible to confirm, about a number of reported killings of unarmed civilians in Kuwait outside the context of armed conflict. In one incident on Aug. 8, it said, Iraqi soldiers reportedly fired at a group of some 35 women and young people in the Jabiriyya district of Kuwait city who were peacefully protesting Iraq's annexation of Kuwait. A witness reported that three people _ aged 13, 16 and 20 _ died after being shot in the head and heart, it said. Amnesty, which opposes the death penalty in all circumstances, said it was concerned that Iraq had extended it to cases involving looting and hoarding food. An Iraqi soldier was reported to have been executed Aug. 16 for looting and his body was hung from a crane as a warning to others, it said. Hundreds of Iraqis living in Kuwait were reported to have been arrested by Iraqi troops within days of the invasion, and Amnesty said there has been no information about their fate. The majority were reportedly Shiite Moslems with suspected links to al-Dawa al-Islamiyya or Islamic Call, an outlawed Iraqi opposition group whose members face the death penalty in Iraq, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Records Show Chiles Was Depressed, Not Suicidal
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. Senator Lawton Chiles on Monday released 26 years of medical records in an effort to defuse suggestions he's unfit to fulfill his current political ambition _ to be governor of Florida. A doctor treating Chiles for depression said Monday that the Democratic candidate was never suicidal and suffered no ``disabling'' symptoms. Chiles, 60, served three terms in the Senate before announcing in 1987 he wouldn't seek a fourth term because of what he termed ``burnout.'' Chiles' opponent in the Sept. 4 primary, U.S. Rep Bill Nelson, and Republican Gov. Bill Martinez have released their medical records and urged Chiles to do the same. The records released Monday showed Chiles has taken anti-depressant medication since November 1987, including the drug Prozac, which has been linked by some to suicidal thoughts. Chiles first became depressed following open-heart surgery in 1985, but that episode didn't require medication, his family doctor, Karl Hempel of Tallahassee, said Monday. ``He's never been suicidal from the very start,'' said Hempel. Chiles suffered a chemical imbalance causing ``routine depression with the typical symptoms,'' he said. ``I would definitely not tell him to retire,'' said Hempel. ``He doesn't have anything that is even close to being disabling.'' Nelson's running mate, state House Speaker Tom Gustafson, suggested two weeks ago Chiles could be a suicide risk because he had taken Prozac. Gustafson later apologized for the remark. At least two former patients have sued the drug's maker claiming Prozac caused them to attempt suicide. The manufacturer, Eli Lilly & Co., has denied the drug has such ill effects. Chiles released an inch-thick collection of medical documents dating back to 1966, which documented a variety of ailments, including chronic ulcerative colitis and an arthritic spinal disorder. In November 1987, a Naval reserve doctor prescribed the anti-depressant doxepin after Chiles complained of insomnia, loss of appetite and sex drive, the records showed. A month later, Chiles made his announcement he wouldn't seek a fourth Senate term. In a report of the evaluation, Dr. R.J. Pentzien, a psychiatrist at Bethesda Naval Hospital, said Chiles had ``no history of suicidal ideation, plan or intent,'' Later, Chiles stopped taking medication for several months, according to the records. Hempel prescribed Prozac for Chiles in December 1989 and he takes it now. While campaigning Monday in southern Florida, Chiles said the records ``should put an end'' to questions about his health. ``I think that my health is perhaps a legitimate issue,'' Chiles said, adding that his rigorous campaign schedule proved he is fit.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Camp Inmates Hijack Flight to Pakistan, Surrender, Seek Asylum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 9-12, ```All indications...the country,' with 3 grafs to delete repetitive reference to artificial limb, fix typos in `spokesman' and `hijackers;' picks up graf 13 pvs, `After negotiating...' ^LaserPhoto KAR1
DOC.TEXT: A gang of convicts from a Siberian labor camp overpowered their guards aboard an Aeroflot passenger flight, hijacked the plane to Pakistan and sought political asylum Monday. No one was hurt. One of the convicts apparently smuggled weapons on board in an artificial limb, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported. The 11 hijackers surrendered after landing at Karachi International Airport, and the 29 passengers and nine crew members were freed unharmed, officials said. It was the latest in an unprecedented spate of hijackings involving Soviet aircraft. There have been at least 13 hijack attempts in the past three months. Airport officials insisting on anonymity said the Tupolev 154 had only five to 15 minutes of fuel left when it landed in Karachi. The authorities did not say whether the hijackers would be given asylum or sent back to the Soviet Union. The hijacking began Sunday when 15 prisoners were aboard an Aeroflot flight from Neryungry, about 3,000 miles east of Moscow, where their labor camp was located. The flight was bound for the nearby city of Yakutsk in eastern Siberia, officials said. It was not known why the prisoners were being taken to Yakutsk, or why they were serving time in prison. The prisoners, armed with guns and homemade explosives, overpowered their guards and threatened to blow up the plane, said the independent Soviet news agency Interfax. The hijackers forced the plane to return to Neryungry. There, six prisoners left the plane but two more joined the group, according to Soviet Interior ministry spokesman Yuri I. Arshenevsky. Of the 70 passengers left on board, the hijackers allowed 41 women and children to leave the plane in Neryungry, Arshenevsky said. Then they flew west to Krasnoyarsk in Siberia, where authorities negotiated with them for two hours and allowed them to refuel. The plane next flew to Tashkent in Soviet Uzbekistan. There, the hijackers demanded the aircraft be allowed to leave the country. After negotiating through the night, authorities allowed the plane to be refueled and to take off. The hijackers promised to free the passengers and crew when they landed, officials said. Karachi airport authorities initially denied the jetliner permission to land but relented when the pilot said he did not have enough fuel to fly to another destination, officials said. The airport was briefly closed but reopened to normal traffic after the hijacked plane landed, officials said. Pakistan is an Islamic country, but authorities said none of the hijackers was believed to be Moslem. There have been at least 13 attempts to hijack Soviet aircraft since late May, mostly by Soviet teen-agers or young men who said they wanted to live in the West. That compares with about 70 such attempts in the 57-year history of Aeroflot, the Soviet state airline. At least six hijackers made it out of the Soviet Union, but all were arrested. Soviet media emphasized that Western countries have been returning the hijackers to the Soviet Union to face charges. Hijacking carries a penalty of five to 20 years in jail in the Soviet Union. Finland on Monday ordered the extradition of Mikhail Varfolomeyev, who commandeered a Soviet plane on a domestic flight from the Estonian capital of Tallinn to the Ukrainian city of Lvov. He sought asylum when the plane landed in Helsinki. Finland extradited another young Soviet hijacker last month. As for Monday's incident, Soviet authorities were trying to figure out how it happened. Tass quoted Deputy Interior Minister Ivan Shilov as saying there would be an investigation into how the convicts managed to commandeer the plane. ``Such a large group of prisoners should, ideally, be transported separately, of course,'' he said. ``But chronic shortages of flights even for ordinary passengers prevent us from using a special plane.'' He added that was ``certainly is no justification for what happened.''

DOC.HEAD: Prison Chairman Wants Review of Human Prey Exercise
DOC.TEXT: A panel was appointed Monday to review the use of prison inmates as human prey to train tracking dogs _ a practice that has drawn criticism from state legislators and others. A prison official acknowledged taking two friends on what he dubbed ``The Ultimate Hunt.'' ``Both public concern and the media's attention to this subject warrant a serious review,'' said Charles Terrell, chairman of the Texas Board of Criminal Justice. The practice was criticized after news reports that Jerry Hodge, vice chairman of the Board of Criminal Justice, participated in the hunts last year with two friends and later gave them jackets emblazoned ``The Ultimate Hunt.'' Hodge has apologized for the jackets but defended his participation in the hunt, saying the inmates were volunteers and weren't in danger. Prison officials say they need to use inmates to teach the dogs to track prison escapees. Those on the hunt ride horses, following the dogs as they track prisoners. Terrell is resigning as chairman Sept. 1. Sources told The Associated Press that Hodge's appointment was to be announced Aug. 14, the same day news of the incident became public. Gov. Bill Clements, who called Hodge's actions inappropriate, denied he had chosen Hodge to replace Terrell. Clements said he would take the information into consideration in making his decision, but said he didn't feel it disqualified Hodge. Questions about the practice previously surfaced seven years ago when the lacerated body of an inmate ``dog boy'' was found drowned in a stock pond, according to former prison board member Harry Whittington. In 1983, a $14,000 out-of-court settlement with the prison system was reached in a lawsuit involving two inmates that were attacked by dogs. One man suffered more than 100 bites and the other 56 bites. Prison officials have said protective clothing worn by the inmates is designed to prevent injury. Medical records show 23 dog bites suffered by inmates since 1987, according to prison officials.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Protest U.S. Role in Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: A small group took to the streets Monday to protest the deployment of U.S. soldiers and sailors in the Persian Gulf region. About 15 people waved signs and lofted a banner in protest of the U.S. policy in the Middle East at a busy intersection in North Kingstown, where President Bush made a campaign stop on behalf of Republicans Gov. Edward D. DiPrete and Rep. Claudine Schneider. The president never saw the demonstrators, who took up a post that his motorcade didn't pass. They moved their protest to downtown Providence later in the afternoon to catch the rush-hour crowd passing in front of the federal building. ``U.S. troops out of the Middle East. No war for the oil companies and Wall Street. Money for jobs, homes, schools at home, not war abroad,'' their banner said. They likened the deployment of thousands of U.S. troops, planes and ships _ intended to protect Saudi Arabia and block trade with Iraq's because of the Iraqi invasion of neighboring Kuwait _ to the early stages of the Vietnam war. ``We're responding like in 1963 when advisers were sent to Vietnam,'' said Bill Bateman of the All Peoples Congress. ``This is the opening shot of an antiwar movement. They're making all the war moves.'' Although he conceded it was unlikely that his small protest would move the United States to reconsider its policy, he argued that U.S. opposition to the Vietnam War also started small, growing into a nationwide movement. ``They only respond when the numbers grow, when the people start coming home in body bags,'' he said. Another protester, Timothy Sprouls of the Rhode Island Middle East Committee, said he was particularly opposed to the U.S. response because of the rapid buildup of forces in the Gulf region. ``The United States jumped in there with both feet,'' he said. ``There's been no discussion or dialogue.''

DOC.HEAD: Pilot's Actions Probed in Crash That Killed Seven from Refugee Family
DOC.TEXT: A pilot whose airplane crashed, killing him and six relatives, allowed too many passengers in the craft and may have been flying in stormy weather to meet a license renewal deadline, authorities said Monday. The single-engine plane crashed Saturday night in a cornfield but wasn't discovered until after the passengers _ members of a Hmong refugee family attending a birthday party _ were reported missing Sunday, authorities said. The victims were identified Monday as pilot Jay Her, 31, of Watertown; his two children, Amy, 7, and Tom, 3; his brother, Yuayia Her, 47, of Sheboygan; Yuayia Her's son, Dani, 11; another brother, Vang Neng Her, 45, of Watertown; and nephew Vang Yang, 13, of Milwaukee. Relatives said the flight was part of a birthday celebration for Amy Her. ``It was a very close-knit family, a family of three loving brothers ... now they're all dead,'' said Chao Her, Jay Her's cousin. Relatives said the brothers and other family members fled from Laos to Thailand at the end of the Vietnam war and later made their way to Florida before resettling in Wisconsin. Her's rented Piper Lance aircraft could carry six people but he apparently squeezed in an extra child by strapping two youths into one seat, said William Bruce, an investigator for the National Transportation Safety Board. There were severe thunderstorms in the area Saturday night, but investigators were unsure whether they contributed to the crash, Bruce said. A preliminary investigation didn't reveal any evidence of mechancial failure, he said. Jefferson County Sheriff Keith Mueller said Her was apparently trying to earn flight time before a midnight deadline for recertification of his pilot's license. Jeff Baum, manager of the Watertown airport, said Her was a veteran pilot. ``What went through his mind to leave in those weather conditions and put seven people into a six passenger plane I don't know,'' said Baum. The airport closed at dusk but pilots are authorized to leave after that. Investigators believed Her took off at about 10 p.m. He hadn't filed a flight plan, authorities said. The wreckage was found amid six-foot high cornstalks in a field near the airport. The plane apparently crashed after its left wing struck the ground, causing the plane to cartwheel, Bruce said.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Pleads Innocent to Tax Evasion
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Floyd Flake pleaded innocent Monday to conspiracy, fraud and tax evasion charges stemming from allegations he diverted money from programs of the church where he is pastor. After the arraignment, the two-term Democrat assured 250 supporters he will be vindicated at trial. Flake, 45, was indicted Aug. 2 on 17 counts of conspiracy, fraud and tax evasion. His wife, Margarett, 42, was indicted on nine counts. Lawyers entered pleas for them at a five-minute court appearance before U.S. District Judge Eugene Nickerson in Brooklyn. Neither Flake nor his wife spoke; but they stood erect, looking confident throughout the proceeding. The judge released them in their own custody and scheduled the next hearing for October. Afterward, Flake thanked the applauding supporters as he left the courthouse. ``I am not guilty,'' he told them. ``My record speaks for itself.'' The supporters had arrived in chartered buses; many were from the Allen African Methodist Church in the borough of Queens, where Flake is the pastor. Some carried signs, including one that read: ``Come, see the great work he has done.'' ``The indictment was ridiculous for a man of his caliber,'' said Gregory Meeks, an attorney. ``Congressman Flake is a great man; he's proven it by his deeds,'' said another demonstrator who identified himself only as Tony. Flake, who represents New York's 6th Congressional District, was charged with diverting $141,700 from church and housing funds for his own use, and for failing to report it as taxable income. The charges center on the 300-unit Allen Senior Citizens Apartments, which Flake's church built in 1981 with a $10 million federal loan. The church operates the complex with a $100,000 monthly subsidy from the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The indictment charged that between 1983 and 1987, the Flakes embezzled $75,000 from the complex. U.S. Attorney Andrew Maloney said the money was siphoned off in $6,000 increments from quarterly HUD allocations of $9,000, set aside for transporting the elderly residents to and from appointments in the neighborhood. He said the actual transportation costs were only $3,000 a quarter. The indictment also alleged that Flake took another $66,700 from a special church ``ministerial expense fund'' for his own use between 1983 and 1988, and again did not report the money as taxable income. Maloney said church members were unaware of Flake's activities. When he was indicted, Flake's attorney, Gustave Newman, said the money was used for church purposes and the charges wouldn't stand up in court. He also said the case would not affect Flake's plans to run for a third term this year. Mrs. Flake's attorney, Ted Wells, said his client was only a secretary, the person who signed tax forms and checks. He said she had ``no substantive involvement'' in church operations. The charges included one count of conspiracy, two counts of fraud and six counts of tax evasion against each of the defendants. Flake was additionally charged with another four counts of filing false tax returns and four counts of making false financial statements. If convicted on all 17 counts, Flake would face a maximum of 87 years in prison and fines of up to nearly $4 million. His wife would face maximum penalties of 55 years in prison and $2.1 million in fines.

DOC.HEAD: Three Slain, Two Deputies Hurt Before Barricaded Gunman Surrenders
DOC.TEXT: A gunman shooting wildly while holed up in a mobile home for 10 hours wounded two sheriff's deputies and apparently killed three people inside the home before surrendering Monday, authorities said. Heinz Joachim Podszuweit, 30, described as a survivalist with a military background, was arrested at 9:05 a.m. after keeping a Riverside County Sheriff's Department special weapons team at bay since late Sunday. Inside the home, deputies found three bodies as well as a high-powered rifle and hand grenades, said Detective Henry Sawicki. ``It appears we have an individual who went mentally over the brink,'' said Sheriff Cois Byrd. Speaking of the deaths inside the mobile home, he added, ``it appears there was some kind of conflict.'' The names of the dead weren't immediately available. The shooting began about 11:30 p.m. Sunday when deputies responding to neighbor complaints were met with gunfire, Sawicki said. One deputy was shot in the foot; another grazed on the shoulder.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of Aug. 13-20:
DOC.HEAD: News Rules Said To Protect Soldiers' Families, Secure Information
DOC.TEXT: The boundaries on what information American journalists in Saudi Arabia can relay home are in place to protect soldiers' families and to ensure against tipping off the Iraqis, a Pentagon official said Aug. 15. One of the ground rules prevents journalists from disclosing the size of troop units or where they are located in the desert in the dispatches that are shared with the nation's news media on a ``pool'' basis. ``That's the kind of stuff the Iraqis would love to know ... You might as well be giving them grid coordinates to set their artillery for,'' said the official, who is helping to handle the pool coverage from Washington. He asked to remain unidentified. Another restriction on the 15-member pool of U.S. journalists, flown to Saudi Arabia by the Pentagon, prohibits them from identifying individual soldiers _ except command-level officers _ by name. That rule is in place to protect the GIs' families in the United States, the Pentagon official said. ``You have people who don't much care for the fact that we're there in the first place and who want to strike back at a target,'' he said. Allowing the journalists to report how many troops are gathering at a certain spot would be ``giving the enemy, the potential enemy, information that is better left unsaid at this point,'' the official said. Photographers are not prevented from taking pictures of anything they see, but a group of U.S. military ``escorts'' control where the pool reporters and photographers are taken each day. ``If they are taken to an object or a human being, they are not being prevented from taking pictures of anything,'' the official said. A military official does a ``security review'' of the stories before they are dispatched to the reporter's Washington bureau. Then a Pentagon official in Washington gives it a final review before it is allowed to be distributed by wire services and to other news organizations. ABC's Sam Donaldson accidentally violated the rules by specifying the location of an airbase used by U.S. warplanes and got a warning from his U.S military escort. ``He made an honest mistake'' and hasn't repeated it, ABC News vice president Robert Murphy said of Donaldson's goof. It occurred Aug. 15 during his live ``Nightline'' report from the airbase in Saudi Arabia. ABC said a tape of his report, with the location electronically bleeped out, aired the next night on ``PrimeTime Live,'' which Donaldson co-anchors with Diane Sawyer. The pool in Saudi Arabia includes seven print reporters from The Associated Press, the Los Angeles Times, the Scripps Howard News Service, the Milwaukee Journal, United Press International, Reuters and Time magazine. It also includes a National Public Radio reporter, still photographers from the AP, UPI and Time and a CNN television crew.
DOC.HEAD: Group of Americans and Britons Flee Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Journalists and others who fled Kuwait after the Iraqi attack told stories of wandering in the desert while trying to elude the invading army. Stephanie McGehee, an American stringer for The Associated Press, was in a convoy of cars that fled Aug. 17 after Britons and Americans were ordered to gather at two Kuwait hotels. ``It was a hectic, rather perilous drive past Iraqi checkpoints and through uninhabited desert regions between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia,'' McGehee, of Leucadia, Calif., said by telephone from the Khafji border post. She and other foreigners decided to take their chances in the desert rather than risk becoming hostages in Baghdad. McGehee, who had lived 12 years in Lebanon and Kuwait, said she donned a black, floor-length robe of the sort worn by Kuwaiti women and used her knowledge of Arabic dialects to talk her way past Iraqi troops. ``It seems the Iraqis got the impression the entire convoy comprised only Arab evacuees,'' she said. ``I spoke at length in Arabic with a mixture of Kuwaiti and Lebanese accents to the Iraqis at the last checkpoint.'' The ploy seemed to work at first and none of the other cars were checked. But the Iraqi troops suddenly told the party to return home. They moved a few miles back toward Kuwait, then veered into the desert and kept driving until they saw some Bedouins who pointed to the Saudi border. A Dutch journalist who escaped from Kuwait on Aug. 14 said she met others who wandered the desert seeking a way out. ``They were loaded into cars, buses, trucks _ anything that moved,'' said Hetty Lubberding, a correspondent for Dutch radio. Ms. Lubberding said her three-car convoy of British and Irish citizens was turned back at the border crossing like thousands of other vehicles. They then headed into the desert to meet a Bedouin who was supposed to lead them to safety. They had not planned to travel across the desert and so had brought little water or other supplies. No Bedouins were in sight and the group was soon lost, unable to find their way back to Kuwait City, about 24 miles to the north. ``Lots of other people were wandering around lost,'' Ms. Lubberding said. Her convoy picked up several Egyptians whose car got stuck. They fell in behind some Filipinos who had been pointed across the desert toward the Saudi border by an Iraqi patrol. Nerves strained, they came face-to-face with an Iraqi tank. Having heard reports that a Briton was shot trying to cross, their first instinct was to run. ``We were a little wary, but we decided to approach,'' she said. The Iraqi soldiers on the tank gave them water and pointed the way, she said, sending them to a Saudi border post.

DOC.HEAD: Closed Society, Heat Make Reporting Difficult in Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: Western reporters are finding that the challenge of reporting in a society that has been virtually closed to foreigners until now is as daunting as working in heat that often soars above 100 degrees. The Saudi government allowed U.S. Defense Department officials to chaperone a small pool of reporters in the country the week after the invasion. It wasn't until a week later that the kingdom agreed to grant visas for open coverage to more than a dozen journalists. Habib Shaheen, a spokesman for the Saudi government, said the number of reporters in the country was unprecedented. On Aug. 18, the Saudi government flew reporters to Jiddah, 1,000 miles away, for interviews with top officials. Ever sensitive to the draw of television, the government arranged for NBC's Tom Brokaw, ABC's Sam Donaldson and CBS' Bob Simon to have individual interviews with the Saudi oil minister and the foreign minister. ``Very smooth,'' Donaldson pronounced after his 10 minutes with Prince Saud al-Faisal, the foreign minister. Al-Faisal, clad in his traditional flowing robe and red headdress, spoke in flawless English as he recounted Saudi Arabia's insistence that Iraqi troops leave Kuwait. The Saudis' decision to open their borders awed some reporters who until now have spent years trying to penetrate the kingdom. ``We would wait forever just to get one interview and now we have three top officials in one day,'' said Barnie Mason of BBC radio. The logistics for covering the news are formidable. CNN's Carl Rochelle was a pool reporter who flew to Saudi Arabia with Defense Department staff. Once in the country, he and his technicians had to set up a portable satellite station at the Dhahran Air Base. The heat was so intense that one technician was overcome and military officials were forced to install an air conditioner in a tent. ``We've learned to drink a lot of water,'' said Tom Mote, a CNN cameraman.
DOC.HEAD: Settlement Preserves Independence of Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: The Times Publishing Co. settled a stock feud with Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass that company officials said preserved independent control of the St. Petersburg Times. The publishing company agreed to recapitalization, including redemption of its preferred stock, the parties announced in a joint statement Aug. 17. In return the Bass group is dismissing its suit against the Times. ``The agreement assures the long-term independence, journalistic control and competitive vigor of the St. Petersburg Times, as well as significant ongoing support for the Poynter Institute,'' said Andrew Barnes, chairman of Times Publishing. David Bonderman, managing partner for the Bass group, Poynter-Jamison Ventures Ltd., said the settlement was in everyone's best interest. The partnership includes the nieces of the late Eleanor Poynter Jamison, sister of founder Nelson Poynter, who ran the paper for 30 years. ``We always believed this to be a good investment and are happy we could work with Andy Barnes to help end a family dispute that has brewed for years,'' Bonderman said. Earlier this year, the Bass group made a $270 million buyout offer for Times Publishing Co., parent firm of the newspaper, Congressional Quarterly and other magazines. The Bass group owned 40 percent of the voting stock but got only 5.7 percent of the dividends of Times Publishing Co. under an unusual stock arrangement. The partnership sought a better return on its investment and maintained directors had an obligation to recall preferred stock, as allowed by bylaws, at $106 a share or $318,000. But the Times defended the stock arrangement as beneficial to the journalistic standards of the newspaper and the health of the Poynter Institute, which essentially controls the newspaper. The institute offers education and national conferences to journalists and students. As a result of the settlement, the publishing company is incurring debt, said Barnes, who is editor and president of the Times. The debt should not affect operations, said Barnes, who also is chairman of the Poynter Institute and chief executive officer of the Times Holding Co. Nelson Poynter, who ran the paper for 30 years, had set up a unique way to keep a profitable daily newspaper in the hands of journalists, free from control of outsiders or even his family. He established the not-for-profit journalism school, which ultimately is the major stockholder of the newspaper. Times Publishing is owned largely by Times Holding Co., which in turn is owned almost entirely by the non-profit Poynter Institute for Media Studies. State Attorney General Bob Butterworth had intervened in the suit on behalf of the Poynter Institute, which he said was threatened by the Bass partnership. Butterworth said he was pleased with the settlement, but disturbed by the agreement by the parties not to comment on terms or related matters. ``This office will take whatever steps are available to ensure that the state has sufficient information to determine that the settlement, in fact, does not have an adverse impact on the Poynter Institute's beneficiaries, including the state university system and Tampa Bay-area public schools,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: UPI Laying Off 31
DOC.TEXT: United Press International will lay off 31 employees, transfer others and leave some small news bureaus with no staff as part of a series of organizational changes, the news agency said Aug. 14. Washington-based UPI said it is also negotiating to purchase the use of the news report of States News Service as part of a joint venture intended to supplement its own coverage of the federal government. UPI spokesman Milt Capps said four regional reporters who had been tailoring reports of federal news for individual states and regions will be assigned other duties. He said UPI's coverage on Capitol Hill will not otherwise be affected. Capps said the layoffs involve 16 regular employees and 15 probationary staff members in UPI bureaus around the country. The Washington Post said the wire service plans to eliminate one-person bureaus in Green Bay, Wis.; Scranton, Pa.; Atlantic City, N.J.; Springfield, Mass., and Fairfax County, Va. Capps confirmed that reporting of news in nearby Fairfax County will now be handled by UPI's Washington bureau but said he would not address other details. He did say that although some of the news bureaus are not now being staffed, UPI has not closed them and retains the option of reassigning reporters to them. ``We aren't reducing any of our coverage in those areas,'' Capps said. ``We do not consider that there will be any substantive change in our reporting from those regions.'' He said the changes are part of a long-term strategy aimed at trimming personnel costs while sharing news reporting with joint-venture partners, including Financial News Network, a cable television network. UPI is owned by Infotechnology Inc., which also owns 47 percent of FNN. ``Our aim is to free up additional resources to differentiate UPI's reports from those of our competitors in ways that cannot be easily duplicated,'' Capps said.
DOC.HEAD: AP Technical Employees Ratify Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Technical employees at The Associated Press announced Aug. 14 they had ratified a three-year labor contract. Jim Peecook, president of the 310-member Local 1314 of the Communications Workers of America, said the vote total would be withheld. Under the accord reached on July 14, the weekly salaries of top-scale technical workers increase by $23.50 the first year, $24 the second and $24.50 in the third year to $636.50. The pact calls for increases in pension benefits and geographic differentials in the third year and provides for a managed care system for the health plan. The agreement is retroactive to May 19.
DOC.HEAD: Editorial Calling for Drug Legalization Draws Criticism, Support
DOC.TEXT: A San Francisco Examiner editorial urging legalization of drugs was yet another blow to the United States' drug policy, law enforcement officials say. ``Let's face it: No amount of laws, no amount of interdiction, no amount of courts, no amount of jails, no amount of anything has reduced the craving for the use of drugs,'' the Aug. 12 editorial read. It said all anti-drug laws should be repealed and the war on drugs called off. ``For these people to make statements like this, I think they are very uninformed. They are making it from a philosophical point of view that I don't think takes into consideration those who are actively involved in the problem,'' said Robert Bender, Drug Enforcement Agency agent in charge in San Francisco. In San Jose, where police say 80 percent of serious crime is drug-related, Police Chief Joseph McNamara said he agreed with some of the newspaper's arguments. ``Many of the points in the editorial are valid,'' McNamara said. ``The tremendous corruption, the clogging of courts, jails and prisons indicate we need to look for new solutions. But I don't think the country is ready for legalization.''
DOC.HEAD: Critics: Campaign Encourages Neighborhood Spies
DOC.TEXT: A weekly newspaper's campaign to get readers to send in coupons naming suspected criminals is being praised by anti-crime activists and criticized as a witch hunt by civil libertarians. The public service advertisements have been running in the 30,000-circulation Lake Worth Herald since July, with blanks to fill in people's names, addresses and alleged criminal activities. Herald Editor Jay Kravetz has forwarded eight names to the police since the campaign began. He said he got the idea after reading about similar ads in other newspapers. ``I wish that everybody would call the police who ran into or saw a crime,'' said Kravetz, ``But they don't. This is for people who don't want to call police.'' Lake Worth Police Lt. Jack Garson said the tips have supplemented some cases but have not led to any arrests. James K. Green, legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union in Florida, said the practice ``raises some disturbing questions.'' ``What kind of a society do we want to live in _ a society of informers? Or do we want to leave that to the police?'' Green asked. ``It's not the function of a free press to act as a patsy to law enforcement.'' But supporters, such as Shirley M. Campfield of the Lake Worth Concerned Citizens, said the coupons are an excellent crime-fighting tool. ``It has a lot to do with where Lake Worth is at the moment,'' Campfield said. ``Some aggression is called for to get us over the hump.'' The newspaper can put pressure on police to investigate when the same names keep turning up, she said. ``A lot of people complain that they talk to the police and nothing happens.''
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Celebrates 100 Years With Donation
DOC.TEXT: The owners of The Indiana Gazette marked the newspaper's centennial Aug. 13 with a $20,000 donation to a children's program at a city library. Joseph L. and Lucy Ray Donnelly said the family made the donation in memory of Mrs. Donnelly's father, R. Hastie Ray, who ran the paper from 1911 until 1970. The gift will help add a children's section to the Indiana Free Library, which will include areas for children to read or listen to taped books and music.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Blows Lid off Tupperware `Secret'
DOC.TEXT: The Peoria Journal Star popped the lid off Tupperware's secret new product for 1990, and the plastic kitchenware giant is steamed. The newspaper reported Aug. 15 that Tupperware's ``revolutionary new product line'' is a group of stackable microwave dishes. ``The paper really did a number on us,'' said Alan Luce, Tupperware vice president for administration. ``This was a major product breakthrough for us. It was not like a new tumbler or color. This was a major secret.'' The new line was to have been unveiled nationally Aug. 27. But the newspaper got a reporter inside a closed session of a Tupperware convention Aug. 14 when the product was introduced to a jubilant crowd of dealers and sales managers. Luce said the story ``ruined the fun, surprise and excitement'' for conventioneers attending sessions later in the week in Peoria, Long Beach, Calif., and Orlando, Fla. ``We've got 110,000 independent Tupperware dealers in the United States. We prefer that they know about our new products before the general public knows,'' said Lawrie Pitcher Platt, spokeswoman at Tupperware headquarters in Orlando. Mayor Jim Maloof said his secretary received several calls from upset Tupperware officials. He said he called the newspaper to ask if the story could be pulled from its evening editions. The paper refused. ``I don't understand what's the big deal. They had news, and we went and got it,'' said Jack Brimeyer, assistant managing editor. ``We didn't treat them any differently than any other business or news story.'' The mayor also said he had heard Tupperware had threatened to cancel its three-year contract to hold conventions in Peoria. The company plans to hold its 1991 convention in Hawaii for Tupperware's 40th anniversary, but Luce said that had nothing to do with the Tupperware flap. The new line is called Tupperwave. It's a nine-piece selection of casserole-type dishes and accessories that can be stacked three-high in a microwave to allow simultaneous cooking of entrees, side dishes and desserts.
DOC.HEAD: First Soviet Newspapers Registered Under Freer Rules; But Prices Rising
DOC.TEXT: Newspapers have begun registering under new, freer press regulations that replaced tough censorship. All publications will be permitted except those urging the violent overthrow of the government, promoting racial or religious intolerance or publishing propaganda for war, violence or cruelty, according to the law. None of the old or new national publications applying for registration has been turned away, Dmitri Mamleyev, first deputy chairman of the State Press Committee, told a news conference Aug. 14. The same day, the committee also announced a doubling in the price of many publications, blaming increases in the cost of paper, printing equipment and transportation. Some politicians have called the increases an attack on glasnost, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's campaign for greater openness. The popular magazine Ogonyok, which now costs 40 kopecks at the newstand, will rise to about 1 ruble _ more than double its price. The price of books also is expected to more than double, officials said. Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the largest Soviet republic, Russia, told speakers at a meeting in the northern Russian city of Vorkuta on Aug. 13 that the Soviet parliament had been too easy on the Communications Ministry. ``We should have taken it under control. ... We'll return to the issue and after that they will probably stop their attacks on glasnost,'' Yeltsin said in remarks reported by the Interfax news agency, an arm of Radio Moscow. Press committee officials in Moscow said the Communications Ministry is billions of rubles in debt because of the increases in production costs. They also said newstand prices could remain the same if the unions and other groups that publish periodicals were willing to sacrifice their profits to cover the increases. More than 120 newspapers and other Soviet news organizations have applied under the new press law, which was approved unanimously by the Supreme Soviet in June after months of debate and took effect Aug. 1. To establish a publication or news organization, Soviets need only provide their name, address, frequency of publication, circulation figures and source of financing.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Sentenced for Beating News Photographer
DOC.TEXT: Two soldiers have been given suspended sentences and fined for beating a news photographer in the occupied West Bank, the army said. Havakuk Levinson, who worked for the Reuters news agency, was beaten March 22 when he tried to photograph troops firing at stone-throwing Arab youths. One soldier was convicted of ``shameful conduct'' and received a three-month suspended sentence on Aug. 15. He was fined $100, the military command said. A first sergeant major was convicted of ``improper conduct.'' He received a five-month suspended sentence and was ordered to pay $250. Another soldier was convicted earlier of assault and improper conduct. He was ordered to spend two months doing manual labor and placed on probation for an additional four months. He was also reduced in rank from staff sergeant to private, the army said.
DOC.HEAD: U.S. Tours Scheduled for Budapest, Prague, Warsaw Journalists
DOC.TEXT: Eight reporters and editors from Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland were named Aug. 13 for three-month working sessions on newspapers in the northeastern United States and Los Angeles. They are scheduled to arrive in September as the first Times Mirror fellows, selected by a panel of editors from the Times Mirror newspapers, the Times Mirror Center for The People and the Press said. The journalists from countries in transition from communism to democracy will begin their U.S. sojourns with two weeks of orientation at the Center in Washington, followed by assignments covering government, business, economics, the arts and people for Times Mirror Co. daily newspapers. The Washington center organizes public opinion surveys and other studies on issues relating to the press, politics and public policy. The fellows, their home and U.S. publications: Krystyna Lubelska, an editor and writer on social problems for the Polish national daily Zycie Warszawy of Warsaw, will work at the Los Angeles Times. Vladimir Matejovsky, a commentator and foreign affairs correspondent of Mlada Fronta, of Prague, a newly independent Czechoslovak national daily. The Baltimore Sun. Emoke Nagy, a literary and performing arts critic of Magyar Nok Lapja, Budapest. New York Newsday. Witold Pasek of Warsaw, an investigative reporter for Gazeta Wyborcza, daily linked to Poland's Solidarity movement. The Morning Call of Allentown, Pa. Pal Reti of Budapest, head of the Opinions department of Hungary's World Economic Weekly (Heti Vilaggazdasag). The Hartford Courant. Tomas Smetanka, foreign editor of Lidove Noviny, Czechoslovakia's leading post-communist daily. Newsday, Long Island, N.Y. Ivana Stepankova, a commentator and diplomatic writer of Mlada Fronta. Los Angeles Times Washington bureau. Eniko Tegyi, a cultural reporter and theater critic of Nagyar Nemzet, a Hungarian national daily. The Advocate of Stamford, Conn., and Greenwich Time of Greenwich, Conn.
DOC.HEAD: Press Institute Asks Chile To Protect Threatened Journalists
DOC.TEXT: The International Press Institute asked the government of Chile to protect four leftist journalists who have been threatened by right-wing extremists in that country. The London-based institute, which represents journalists, editors and publishers around the world, made the request Aug. 14 in a letter to Interior Minister Enrique Krauss. The four journalists received written threats on July 30 and 31 from a previously unknown right-wing group calling itself the Gabriel Rodriguez Alcaino Command, the letter said. ``We urge that every possible step be taken to investigate these threats and to locate and apprehend those responsible,'' said the letter, signed by Peter Galliner, the institute's director. The letter identified the threatened journalists as editors-in-chief Manuel Cabieses Donoso of Punto Final, Libio Perez of Pagina Abierta, Juan Andres Lagos of El Siglo, and its general editor, Guillermo Torres. All three publications are connected to Chile's radical left. Punto Final is a biweekly magazine that represents the views of the Revolutionary Left Movement. Its editor-in-chief, Cabieses, was arrested after the 1973 military coup that ousted leftist Salvador Allende. He said that while in detention he suffered severe torture. Cabieses was sent into exile abroad and has since returned to Chile. El Siglo is the official publication of Chile's Communist Party. Torres is also a director of the Chilean Journalists Association. The Chilean government has strongly condemned the threats and said it would take appropriate measures.

DOC.HEAD: Network Anchor Buildup in Middle East
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. network anchorman buildup in the Middle East continued Aug. 16 as both ABC's Sam Donaldson and NBC's Tom Brokaw reported for duty in Saudi Arabia. Brokaw, anchorman of ``NBC Nightly News,'' and Donaldson, co-anchor of ``PrimeTime Live,'' flew to Saudi Arabia the day before, raising to seven the number of network anchors sent to report on the Middle East crisis. ``CBS Evening News'' anchor Dan Rather, who entered Iraq on Aug. 15, has been reporting from the Middle East since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait sparked the crisis. ABC ``Nightline'' anchor Ted Koppel became the first U.S. network correspondent allowed into Iraq, on Aug. 14. He flew back to Jordan two days later, but ``World News Sunday'' anchor Forrest Sawyer remained in Baghdad, ABC said. On Aug. 17, however, the ABC crew was told it could no longer make satellite TV transmissions and had to leave the country. Rather and CBS correspondent Allen Pizzey were allowed to remain, at least until Aug. 20. Garrick Utley, co-anchor of NBC's ``Sunday Today,'' flew to the Middle East the week after the invasion, and ``CBS This Morning'' co-anchor Harry Smith went to Cairo Aug. 13. Smith returned to New York after a week, while NBC ``Today'' anchor Bryant Gumbel began reporting from Saudi Arabia on Aug. 20.
DOC.HEAD: Network Middle East Coverage Boosts Ratings
DOC.TEXT: The networks' coverage of the Middle East crisis in the week following the Iraqi invasion boosted ratings for their evening newscasts by 19 percent and gave them a larger average audience than prime-time entertainment shows. The increase was due to public interest in the news from the Middle East and U.S. military movements there, NBC research vice president Preston Beckman said Aug. 14. CBS, NBC and ABC evening newcasts collectively averaged a 28.8 rating and a 60 percent share of the audience last week, compared with a 28.1 rating and 53 share for prime time programs, Nielsen audience estimates showed. ABC's front-running ``World News Tonight'' averaged a 10.6 rating. ``The CBS Evening News,'' whose anchor, Dan Rather, has been in the Middle East since Iraq's Aug. 2 in invasion of Kuwait, averaged a 9.3. ``NBC Nightly News'' ran third with an 8.9 average. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. The audience share is the estimated percentage of homes tuned to a given program in its time period. ABC research vice president Alan Wurtzel said that it's rare for news ratings to do better than entertainment ratings. He attributed the ratings both to viewer interest in the crisis and ``the summer doldrums in prime time viewing.'' CNN officials said their network's ratings had generally doubled; the newscasts were seen in 763,000 homes Friday night, and 659,000 homes on Sunday. Viewers of Monday night's network newscasts saw the first TV footage from a press pool flown out to the carrier Independence in the Gulf of Oman. CBS anchorman Rather, among the correspondents on the big ship, taped his anchor portion of the ``CBS Evening News'' there. Although the TV correspondents had to share pool video footage shot by a network cameraman, Rather's report included a home-video segment taped by an unidentified sailor. It showed Rather touring the ship and interviewing crewmen. While in the ship's boiler room, Rather, using a microphone attached to the sailor's videocamera, told viewers: ``(`Top Gun' star) Tom Cruise doesn't make movies about this place.'' ``Hi, Mom and Dad,'' said one grinning young sailor as Rather held the microphone up for him. Under press pool rules, CBS had to share Rather's home-video footage, some of which was fuzzy and taken in poor light. But there were no takers, spokesmen for the other networks said. The quality wasn't good, said David Miller, NBC's foreign news editor: ``I thought it was shabby.''
DOC.HEAD: Gulf States Plan Kuwait News Program
DOC.TEXT: Five Persian Gulf countries have agreed to devote prime television time to a program produced by the exiled government of Kuwait. The agreement was reached Aug. 15 by the ministers of Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Oman, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, members of the Gulf Cooperation Council with Kuwait. Kuwait's government fled when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, set up a provisional government and declared it had ``annexed'' the oil-rich country. The U.N. Security Council said the annexation was ``null and void.'' The Kuwaiti government-in-exile now operates from a base in the Eastern Province of Saudi Arabia. An official statement said the information ministers met in emergency session on how to respond to the Iraqi invasion. The statement said the ``State of Kuwait'' would prepare a special TV program that would be broadcast daily from the other countries of the Gulf Cooperation Council after the main daily news bulletins.
DOC.HEAD: Union Files Unfair Labor Charge Against NBC
DOC.TEXT: A technical union at NBC has filed a petition with the National Labor Relations Board accusing the network of unfair labor practices. NBC denies the accusations. The charges by the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians were filed Aug. 15, the same day NBC put in effect a four-year contract proposal that a majority of the union's members at NBC have rejected twice. The union, which represents 2,373 employees at NBC and NBC-owned facilities, accused the company of ``failing and refusing to bargain in good faith.'' Its previous contract expired on March 31. ``NBC has fully met its obligations under the National Labor Relations Act,'' said NBC spokesman Joe Rutledge, who said the company's final offer came after more than seven months of negotiations and 35 separate meetings. ``We're confident that just as when NABET filed a similar complaint in 1987, the NLRB will find the charges without merit.'' The 1987 charge was filed during a bitter strike by the union that lasted 17 weeks. No walkout this time is imminent. No strike vote has been taken and union officials say they'll probably go to court to fight NBC's action.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Investigating Broadcast of Mapplethorpe Photos
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Communications Commission is investigating complaints against a public television station that showed nude photographs taken by Robert Mapplethorpe. WGBH included the photos in a 10 p.m. newscast July 31, the day before Boston's Institute of Contemporary Art opened an exhibit of Mapplethorpe's work. At least three people have complained to the FCC, including Donald Wildman of the American Family Association in Tupelo, Miss., who sent a videotape of the broadcast to the FCC. Roger Holberg, an FCC attorney, said the agency has not determined whether there is enough of a case to warrant contacting the station. WGBH may be partially protected because the broadcast was after 8 p.m., when the FCC does not enforce indecency rules. But the broadcast could be investigated for obscenity, which is treated differently under federal law, Holberg said. Eric Brass, attorney for WGBH, disputed the complaints. ``It just is not obscene,'' he said. ``I believe we have the right to do what we did in the context of a serious news program. We cannot be in the position of censoring debate about censorship. That's what it would come down to.''
DOC.HEAD: `Hard Copy' Producers Found Innocent of Inducing Minors To Gamble
DOC.TEXT: Two producers from the television show ``Hard Copy'' were found innocent Aug. 16 of charges they induced two teen-agers to gamble. Municipal Judge Bruce Weekes said he found the teen-agers' testimony against producers Daphne Pinkerson and Ellen Gussenberg unbelievable and rehearsed. Ms. Pinkerson and Ms. Gussenberg were charged with inducing minors to enter TropWorld Casino and Entertainment Resort during their research for a report on underage gambling. The charges could have carried penalties of up to six months in jail and $1,000 fines.
DOC.HEAD: TBS Reports $44 Million Loss on Goodwill Games
DOC.TEXT: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said Aug. 14 it lost $44 million on the Goodwill Games, which caused the company to post a second-quarter loss of $8.3 million. The loss on the Goodwill Games ``masked the better-than-planned performance of our ongoing operations,'' TBS chairman Ted Turner said in a statement. The loss included a failure to deliver audience level guarantees to advertisers who bought time on the TBS Superstation for the televising of the Games. Turner said it would provide compensatory advertising time for future programming on its other cable TV networks. Turner said during the recent games in Seattle that the quadrennial international sporting event could lose $26 million, twice what had been projected. That fueled speculation that the Games, which Turner developed in 1985 to foster better relations between nations, might be doomed. The first Goodwill Games, in 1986, lost $26 million. Kitsie Riggall, a TBS spokeswoman, maintained that it would be premature to say the event was finished. ``We've been saying all along that the board (of directors) will review the Games at a future date and will make a decision,'' Riggall said. ``They will review these numbers as well as the Games itself . . . its value to the cable industry, the gains it made with the athletic community. There are several things to look at,'' she said. Turner said earlier this month he expected the board to decide by the end of September whether to continue TBS' involvement in the Games.
DOC.HEAD: Philly News Station Switches to Oldies; 35 Jobs Lost
DOC.TEXT: WCAU-AM Radio left the air Aug. 14 as a news-talk station and switched to oldies music, owner CBS announced. The move will eliminate 35 jobs. WCAU will simulcast some programming with its sister station, WOGL-FM and will switch call letters to WOGL-AM. CBS spokeswoman Helene Blieberg said the job cuts would leave 20 employees.

DOC.HEAD: Harris Announces New Publishers, Editors
DOC.TEXT: Harris Enterprises Inc. said Aug. 15 it has appointed new editor-publishers at three of its Kansas newspapers and at another paper in suburban Los Angeles. All come from within the family-owned newspaper group. Julie Doll, editor and publisher of the Hays Daily News, will become publisher of the Camarillo (Calif.) Daily News on Sept. 10. Doll, 33, editor-publisher at Hays since 1984, succeeds Hank Crockett, who resigned earlier this month to pursue a different newspaper position. Kay Berenson, editor of The Salina Journal, will succeed Doll as editor and publisher of the Hays Daily News on Oct. 1. Berenson, 42, has been at The Journal 12 years and has been editor since 1988. No successor has been named for her. Bruce Buchanan, editor and publisher of The Parsons Sun, will become editor and publisher of the Olathe Daily News on Oct. 1. Buchanan, 33, has been editor-publisher of The Sun since 1985. He succeeds Mike Hurd, who will become director of planning and human resources for Harris. Ann Kennett, assistant to the publisher of The Sun, will replace Buchanan as editor-publisher. Kennett, 39, joined The Sun in 1981 and has directed the newspaper's advertising and circulation departments.
DOC.HEAD: Shields Becomes Publisher at Mitchell
DOC.TEXT: Randall Shields was named publisher of the Mitchell Daily Republic, replacing Jon M. Noel, who resigned. Shields, 39, had been account manager for Scitex America Corp. in Bedford, Mass., since 1988. Noel had been publisher since October of 1988.
DOC.HEAD: Warner Appointed West Chester Editor
DOC.TEXT: David Y. Warner was appointed editor of the Daily and Sunday Local News, one of three promotions announced Aug. 13 by the newspaper. ???]?/?her T.J. Tergliafera also named John DeSanto sports editor and Randall S. Shantz head of the copy desk. Warner, 46, had been interim editor since the resignation of James D. Sneddon in June. He joined the paper in 1987 as business editor and was promoted to city editor in 1988. Warner previously worked at newspapers in Pittsburgh and Australia. DeSanto, 38, came to the Local News as a copy editor in 1988 from the Quay County Sun in Tucumcari, N.M. He had previously worked at newspapers in Texas, Georgia and New Jersey.
DOC.HEAD: Gordon to Jackson Editor
DOC.TEXT: Anne Gordon, a former assistant managing editor at The Denver Post, has been appointed editor of the Jackson Hole Daily and its weekly sister newspaper, the Jackson Hole News. Gordon, 33, was business editor of the Post from 1985 to 1988 before moving to assistant managing editor. Most recently she worked as assignment manager at KCNC-TV in Denver.
DOC.HEAD: Amari Named Managing Editor at L.A. Daily News
DOC.TEXT: Jane Amari has been promoted to managing editor of the Daily News of Los Angeles, Editor Robert W. Burdick announced Aug. 17. Amari, 43, had been managing editor-features the past three years. She replaces Douglas R. Dowie, who resigned to return with his family to the East coast. Before coming to the Daily News, Amari was managing editor of the Rockford (Ill.) Register-Star, editor of The Daily Pilot in Costa Mesa and editor of the Los Angeles Times Syndicate. She also has worked for The Miami Herald, the St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times and the Detroit Free Press.
DOC.HEAD: Ammerman to Managing Editor at Starkville
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Ammerman, managing editor of The Daily Sentinel-Star of Grenada, Miss., the past two years, has been named managing editor of the Starkville Daily News. Ammerman, who was hired Aug. 10, previously was a sports writer and sports editor for the Starkville newspaper. He replaces Joe Carrithers, who left to pursue a doctorate in English at the University of Southern California.
DOC.HEAD: Burbach Named Managing Editor in Aberdeen
DOC.TEXT: Mike Burbach, news editor of AgWeek magazine in Grand Forks, N.D., the past five years, has been named managing editor of the Aberdeen American News. Burbach, 31, formerly worked for the Grand Forks Herald.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.TEXT: Max Bergerre, a French journalist who covered six popes, died Aug. 12 of cancer. He was 86. The dean of the Vatican press corps, Bergerre began reporting from the Vatican in 1931, at the time of Pope Pius XI, for the French news agency Havas. After World War II, he worked as Vatican correspondent for Agence France Presse. In recent years, he helped cover the Vatican for the Italian news agency ANSA.

Gardner L. Bridge, an Associated Press newsman in Washington and New York for 40 years, died Aug. 13 of an intestinal obstruction. He was 83. Bridge began his career with AP in 1925 as a Morse code operator, leaving briefly to work as a reporter for the Albany Evening News. He returned to AP in New York in 1931 as a reporter and later became city editor and bureau chief. He transferred to Washington in 1942 and retired in 1971. In Washington, Bridge covered the Senate and was assigned to every national political convention from 1944 to 1968. Survivors include two daughters and two grand-children.

Hedley Donovan, the former editor in chief at Time Inc. who oversaw the growth of Sports Illustrated, the founding of Money magazine and People and the re-birth of Life, died Aug. 13. He was 76. Donovan died at New York Hospital of an acute infection, the hospital said. He had a chronic lung condition. Donovan took over Time Inc. in 1964 as the hand-picked successor of Henry Luce, the staunch conservative who founded the magazine and had been its only editor in chief. Donovan gave Time a less ideological stance. He retired in 1979 and became a non-salaried adviser to President Carter. Survivors include two sons and a daughter.

Norma Hendricks, a former Leesburg mayor and newspaper columnist, died Aug. 15. She was 79. Ms. Hendricks began working at the Daily Commercial in 1951 as a police reporter. In 1961, when she was city editor of the Commercial, the paper won a Sigma Delta Chi public service award for a series of articles pointing out the need for a public hospital in the town. She left the newspaper in the early 1960s, was elected to the city commission in 1962 and was appointed to fill the term of Mayor Claude Moore three years later after he died in office. Ms. Hendricks returned to the Commercial in 1974 and became a popular news columnist. Survivors include two sons and five grandchilren.

Irwin Albert Lewis, a former CBS and NBC pollster credited with conducting the first exit polls, died of cancer Aug. 18. He was 68. Lewis had been director of the Los Angeles Times Poll since its creation in 1979. He was a civilian employee of the Armed Forces Network in Germany during the 1950s, working as a news writer and bureau chief. He went on to work for United Press International and for Armed Forces Radio. In 1956-57, he wrote for Dave Garroway on the original ``Today'' show. Lewis later joined the NBC election unit, becoming its director of polling in 1966 and director of elections in 1969. Lewis was named director of polling for the CBS News-New York Times Poll in 1976. He went on to join the Roper polling organization the following year. Survivors include his wife and four daughters.

Jim Mencarelli, a 13-year veteran reporter for the Grand Rapids Press known for championing causes of the poor and the eccentric, died Aug. 15 at his home. He was 48. Mencarelli was recuperating after being hospitalized earlier in the month for a bleeding ulcer. He joined the newspaper in 1977 and, as a reporter, rode with a bus full of hippies from San Francisco to Chicago, attended mercenary training school, went cave exploring in Kentucky and profiled the local Hispanic community. ``Ninety percent of being a good reporter is getting the people intimately involved with a story to talk to you, and that was Jim's greatest gift,'' said Mike Lloyd, editor of the Grand Rapids Press. Survivors include his wife and two daughters.

Richard L. Strout, a Washington journalist from the Harding administration to Ronald Reagan's first term in the White House, died Aug. 19. He was 92. Strout died at Georgetown University Medical Center, where he had been admitted after a bad fall Aug. 8, said Godfrey Sperling, his longtime colleague at the Christian Science Monitor. Strout reported for the Monitor for more than 60 years and wrote the political column ``TRB from Washington'' in the New Republic magazine from 1943 to 1983. He retired from the Monitor in 1984. In 1978 Strout was given a special citation by the Pulitzer Prize committee for his lifetime achievement. He also won the George Polk Memorial Award in 1958 and the National Press Club's Fourth Estate Award in 1975, among others. Strout is survived by his wife and their two children; three children by a previous marriage and 11 grandchildren.

Gaylord Royce Wyman, retired city editor of the Taunton Daily Gazette, died Aug. 14. He was 64. Wyman served as wire editor and suburban editor at the Gazette before succeeding Edgar A. Gay at the city desk in 1971. He retired in 1988. Survivors include a brother, a sister and several nieces and nephews.
DOC.HEAD: Six Gannett Fellows Named
DOC.TEXT: Six mid-career journalists have been named as Gannett Foundation Fellows for study of Asian issues at the University of Hawaii-Manoa this year. They are Kenneth D. Barry, 41, financial reporter with Reuters in Washington, D.C; Scott K. Brown, 29, staff correspondent with Time Magazine in Los Angeles; Yoshiko Hayashi, 29, business reporter for Asahi Shimbun in Tokyo; Leslie M. Henderson, 43, legal affairs editor of the Knoxville Journal; Andrea Louie, 24, metro staff reporter with the Akron Beacon Journal; and Brian Eliot Sullam, 40, metro desk reporter with the Baltimore Sun.

ABC anchor Ted Koppel, the first American reporter allowed into Iraq after that country's takeover of Kuwait, said officials may have let him in because they felt they had nothing to lose. ``Because the reporting has been all so anti-Iraq that I guess they feel it can't get much worse. And who knows? Some of their point of view might get across.''
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.HEAD: Camp Rerun Closes as Fall Season Approaches
DOC.TEXT: The following is a transcript of the final session at Camp Rerun, a minimum-security installation where TV critics are sent each summer for refresher courses on how to do their thing. All right, people, listen up. This is our final chance to review lessons learned, what to do with old videocassettes and how to cover the people covering a story, like anchormen. Questions? Q: What's ``Twin Peaks'' about? A: A surreal, postmodern seriocomic drama about the somber belly of American life. Part of David Lynch's brooding, complex oeuvre, it is at once darkly comic and brilliantly bleak. Q: That makes no sense. A: I know, but if you write that way often enough they'll promote you to movie critic. Q: Who killed Laura Palmer? A: You, sir, are a geek. Q: What is the Middle East? A: A large, dusty, oil-rich kingdom ruled on a rotating basis by three kings. The kings are Ted Koppel, Dan Rather and Tom Brokaw, although we see in People magazine that King Dan is mad at King Tom. Q: What are the ramifications of this? A: Hard to say. But we hear that King Tom's producer just got a very big blowgun. And now he's trying to find a heat-seeking missile to put in it. I don't know why. Q: What is this ``double-pump'' thing of NBC? A: They are having double premieres this month of some of their new shows before the new season starts next month. I think they're trying to whip up excitement, not to mention confusion. Q: I have a problem with one show, ``Working It Out.'' NBC sent me a review cassette. But now NBC says ``the character of Gail has been replaced by a new actress and scenes will be re-shot for air.'' A: So what's the problem? Q: How can I review a show where the character of Gail has been replaced by a new actress? A: Just write, ``in this performance, the character of Gail will be played by Laura Palmer.'' Q: I've heard that the new network series are going to be a lot bolder this year, particularly with the language in shows like ``Raw Sex'' and ``More Raw Sex'' and ``Unsolved Adulteries.'' A: I know what you mean. I saw that ``Unsolved Adulteries'' episode where the guy says, ``Boy, I'm sure hot, Martha.'' Q: How can we warn our readers? A: Just do what the networks do. Say portions of this show may not be suitable for yuppies. Q: Tell me again, what do you say when reviewing a boring 24-part PBS series about a British spinster and a Burmese doctor in Nepal? A: You write, ``Richly-textured, always compelling, this is splendid television.'' That's how they do it in New York. Q: Should we keep trying to interview Bryant Gumbel? A: Sure, but if he still says no, remember that you are to keep referring to ``Today'' as ``the troubled show'' or ``still mired in second.'' Q: Should we bother to review all those fishing shows on cable? You know, the kind where some pot-bellied guy talks about his Hula Popper and says, ``Whooo, looks like that crappie weighs 'bout 10, 11 pounds easy.'' A: Ignore those shows. They'll all out-dated by a new one coming out this fall. It's called ``Bass Fishing With Dynamite Dan.'' Q: Should we still do stories about new trends in television? I'm getting tired of making up new trends in television. A: No, your readers want to know about new trends in television, particularly if they're having trouble sleeping. Incidentally, you might keep an eye on a new trend the Middle East crisis has caused. There are more Middle East experts than ever before on the morning news shows. Q: I know what you mean. I saw one the other day from the Center for Strategic Studies of Strategic Centers. A: Well, we're just about out of time. I hope you've enjoyed your stay at Camp Rerun. I also hope we've helped you think about this incredible medium called television and its profound impact on American life. Q: Could you tell me again, what is the Middle East? __ Elsewhere in television... TROOPS MOVEMENTS, THE SEQUEL: NBC's ``Today'' anchor Bryant Gumbel is reporting this week from Saudi Arabia. ``CBS This Morning'' co-anchor Harry Smith, who reported on the Persian Gulf crisis last week from Cairo, is back in New York.
