DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
At the Movies: ``Darkman,'' ``Pump Up the Volume''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Darkman'' opens wide Aug. 24; ``Pump Up the Volume'' opens Aug. 24 at 800 theaters across the country.
DOC.TEXT: ``Darkman'' _ With little fanfare and none of the intrusive hype that heralded ``Batman'' and ``Dick Tracy,'' a tidy comic-book fantasy-thriller from Universal Pictures will fill screens across the nation on Aug. 24, and if you're smart, you'll get in line right now. At a fraction of the budget, ``Darkman'' is what ``Dick Tracy'' could have been without turning over the movie to the non-talents of Madonna and ignoring plot and action, or what ``Batman'' should have been without all the pretense and Joker-mania. It's a simple story of good vs. evil, seen through the talented lens of Bill Pope, with sure-fire direction from Sam Raimi (``The Evil Dead'') and the kind of special effects you only visualize in action comic books. Dr. Peyton Westlake (Liam Neeson) is on the brink of perfecting synthetic skin _ skin that can take on the features of any photograph fed into a computer. The only problem is that when exposed to light, the skin disintegrates after 100 minutes. Meanwhile, his true love, Julia (Frances McDormand), a lawyer, discovers a memo linking her client, a real estate tycoon, to the mob. Westlake is visited by a brutal team of hitmen who seek the memo and silence. Led by the slimey and vicious Robert G. Durant (Larry Drake), who likes to snip off the fingers of his victims with his cigar slicer and add to his digit collection at home, the killers bash Westlake through several glass cabinets, beat him, shoot him, dunk his head in a vat of acid and leave him a mangled mess after turning up the gas and lighting a flame to destroy their handiwork. The explosion propels Westlake through the window of his lab like a firey torpedo. The effect is stunning. As far as the world is concerned, Westlake is dead. He emerges at the local hospital as a John Doe, so badly burned that the doctor clips a vital nerve to alleviate pain. Only problem, the procedure leaves Westlake with superhuman powers and a rage the size of Texas. He somehow manages to recreate his lab and make enough skin to get him through several revenge killings and then some. Westlake becomes Darkman, a combo Phantom of the Opera-Amazing Hulk. With the chameleon charms of his synthetic skin, he can look like anybody. The action is nonstop and inspired. And for once, a screenplay with five names attached isn't an abomination. It's plump with wit and pathos, and has an eerie override. The story is by Raimi, whose claim to fame is ``The Evil Dead,'' a Cannes Film Festival cult classic. However, Raimi shows enormous talent with his kinetic camera work and angled shots, and he has a skilled companion with Pope, who makes his feature film debut with ``Darkman.'' Neeson, who has given solid performances in ``Suspect,'' ``The Mission'' and ``The Good Mother,'' offers a multi-faceted portrayal with Westlake. There is compassion, sensuality, intellect, horror. There are good support performances from Drake, who plays the retarded Benny on TV's ``L.A. Law'' and is the sadistic thug in this movie, and McDormand, the abused sheriff's wife from ``Mississippi Burning.'' Her genuine goodness is never cloying. ``Darkman'' is a visionary epiphany of man's inhumanity to man, the perils of greed, the tests of love and loyality. It is a fantasy world of horror, creation and destruction. And it's a full-throttled blast of a ride. Produced by Robert Tapert, ``Darkman'' is rated R for graphic violence. _ By Dolores Barclay, AP Arts Editor.

``Pump Up the Volume'' _ Contrary to common belief _ and some earnest hopes _ the youth movie is not dead. The once-thriving genre makes a comeback in ``Pump Up the Volume,'' a watchable film of surprising energy. Adults may well need to steel themselves for another wave of movies based on the time-worn theme, ``My parents don't understand me.'' ``Pump Up the Volume'' (and it does) is generally effective, thanks to a high-wattage performance by Christian Slater. His performance before a radio microphone matches the electricity of Eric Begosian in Oliver Stone's neglected ``Talk Radio.'' Slater is an Easterner whose parents have moved to Arizona, where the boy is almost paralyzed with shyness at his new high school. He tries to reach his East Coast buddies via ham radio. Instead, he happens on a frequency that broadcasts to his fellow students in Arizona. In an amazing and not altogether convincing transformation, Slater assaults the air waves with demonic fever. He attacks parents, school authorities, sexual and other inhibitions. For one frenetic hour he becomes Hard Harry, the foul-mouthed liberator of enslaved teen-agers, dispenser of heavy-metal rock and outrageous opinions. Grownups in the peaceful suburb pay little heed until Harry starts exposing a corrupt school administration. The ruthless principal (Annie Ross) launches a drive to stamp out Harry. Failing that, she enlists the help of the FCC, which dispatches a small army to track down Harry's signal. By this time he has inflamed his fellow students to the riot stage and has been located by a beautiful classmate, Samantha Mathis, who supports his cause. Allan Moyle wrote and directed ``Pump Up the Volume,'' which exploits the assets of youth films, which is mainly fresh faces and vibrancy. He also succumbs to the liabilities, especially the portrayal of adults as simpleminded clods or venal tyrants. A few improbabilities remain, such as how Slater could hide his rantings from his parents in the same house. Slater, who was Sean Connery's young companion in ``The Name of the Rose,'' is electrifying as the manic Harry. He is one of the best young actors around. Mathis as the would-be friend has real presence, though she seems too mature for high school. Ellen Greene is effective as a sympathetic teacher. The New Line release was produced by Rupert Harvey and Sandy Stern. The rating is R for raw language. Running time: 100 minutes. _ By Bob Thomas, Associated Press Writer.

Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G _ General audiences. All ages admitted. PG _ Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 _ Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R _ Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X _ No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: Retirees Study Everything from State History to Indochina
DOC.TEXT: The ``Big Easy'' credits rolled, the lights came up and the class was full of questions. Was the movie based on fact? Was Jim Garrison really responsible for cleaning up Louisiana? How do you pronounce that strange name, Chopitoola? Is Cajun music taught? As in most classes, a few people asked most of the questions and the class clown made a crack or two. But there was a difference between this class and others at the University of Southwestern Louisiana: no college kids. The 22 students had come from around the country to Lafayette for a weeklong ``Elderhostel,'' part of a national program for people 60 or older. ``We must continue our education,'' 66-year-old Douglas Rowley said, and winked. He and his wife, Lila, said they spent the past two winters in Texas. They came through south Louisiana on their way home last winter and wanted to see more of the area. They looked in Elderhostel Inc.'s fat tabloid catalog _ Elderhostels are given in every state and Canadian province and numerous countries overseas _ and found the right combination of time, place and subject in Lafayette. ``We've known about them for three or four years, but this was the first time we were finally motivated enough to try one,'' said Mrs. Rowley. The classes were an odd gumbo of topics: Cajuns and Creoles in Louisiana films, Louisiana architecture, Mississippi River customs and geology, and the Cajun waltz and two-step. That's often the case in elderhostels. You can go, for example, to Connecticut College in New London and study psychological portraits of American presidents, Dante's ``Inferno'' and country dances of old England. Elderhostels try to schedule a variety of topics, preferably divided among science and arts and humanities, said Cynthia Trahan, administrative director for USL's program. There are some exceptions. The elderhostel timed to coincide with the Festivals Acadiens focuses on Cajun food, Cajun music and dancing, and Louisiana arts and crafts. The Mardi Gras elderhostel describes the history of Carnival and its various traditions. Tuition at Louisiana elderhostels ranges from $210 to $265. The classes bring instructors and the schools a little money, but not riches, Trahan said. Many elderhostels put their students up in dormitories, but USL uses part of the tuition to pay for rooms in a motel, shuttling students back and forth in vans. John and Corabeth _ or Jack and Bess _ Fuller of Houston liked that. ``I always look for two or less to a room and a private bath,'' said Mrs. Fuller, 72. ``I look at the subject carefully, but if you stay in cabins with six people to a room ...'' She shook her head. Fuller, 69, said he was particularly interested in the daylong tour of the Mississippi River and in the descriptions of Cajun life and culture. They learned that Cajuns are the descendants of French Canadians whom the British kicked out of what was called Acadia in 1755. They also learned that the movie ``Belizaire the Cajun'' is, as teacher Mathe Allain put it, a fairy tale; that inaccuracies in ``Blaze'' include having someone as handsome as Paul Newman play Gov. Earl K. Long; and that a pair of dams in central Louisiana is all that keeps the Mississippi River from changing course and leaving New Orleans on a mud flat. As for ``The Big Easy,'' Allain told the class its plot wasn't based on any particular case; Garrison was a district attorney rather than the judge he played in the movie and was known best for his investigation of John F. Kennedy's assassination; and that there aren't a lot of formal lessons in Cajun music. One detail tripped her up. She spelled Tchoupitoulas Street correctly, but pronounced it ``ChoopiTOOla'' rather than the ``ChoppuhTOOlis'' heard in New Orleans. ``It does throw outsiders,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Elderhostel Program Brings Parents, Grandparents Back to School
DOC.TEXT: While most college students spend their time at school waiting for summer breaks, some of their parents and grandparents are spending vacations back in class. Elderhostel programs are patterned after European youth hostels, in which travelers can live in groups, and are offered at more than 1,500 schools worldwide to people aged 60 and over. ``What elderhostel shows is that learning really doesn't ever end,'' said William Washington, special programs director at Cranbrook-Kingswood School in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Cranbrook-Kingswood is one of 30 programs in Michigan. While some Michigan schools offer courses year-round, about 75 percent of the older students attend classes from June to August. ``People are living healthier, more active lives, and this is a program that helps them do that,'' said Lynn Kindel, state director at elderhostel's Central Michigan University headquarters. Cady Goldberg, public relations director for the elderhostel national headquarters in Boston, said the program ``transcends the stereotypical activities that have previously been assigned to the retirement years, like bingo and bowling.'' Kindel said there are no educational prerequisites. ``All you need to be is interested and active.'' The program started in 1975 under Marty Knowlton, a social activist who once drove an ambulance in the French Foreign Legion, and David Bianco, director of residential life at the University of New Hampshire. Programs started on five New Hampshire campuses with 200 participants. By 1980, the program had reached all 50 states. About 220,000 people signed up for 1989-90 sessions worldwide, Kindel said. Kindel said older students often are more challenging for teachers than traditional college students. ``Elderhostelers are going to say, `We don't believe you,' because they were around when history was being made,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Retirees Audit College Courses; Offer Their Services
DOC.TEXT: Edna Green devoted her life to education, retiring nine years ago as head of the science department at a public high school for gifted girls. Today she is back in school, a student this time, under a program at the University of Pennsylvania that permits retirees to audit courses in exchange for volunteer work. They also are asked to contribute $50 per semester to a scholarship fund. Retirees can audit anything from poetry to engineering courses. They also can use the gymnasium and pool and receive other student benefits, such as reduced theater rates. They volunteer as tutors, counselors, techincal assistants, office and library assistants. Last semester, Green took courses in speech, sculpture and poetry, and she's looking ahead to the fall schedule. She volunteered at the campus information center. The 9-year-old Senior Associates Volunteering Valuable Years program at Penn grew out of a trend that began in the 1970s, when retired teachers sought ways to stay intellectually active without the pressures and expenses of enrolling in degree programs. Other programs still going include ``Prime Timers,'' at California State University, ``Learning in Retirement,'' at Duke University in North Carolina, and the ``Senior Adult Program,'' at Phoenix College in Arizona. The special slant at Penn is getting seniors involved in all aspects of campus life, even as living textbooks for history students, said Nancy Ellis, associate director for education at the Center for the Study of Aging at Penn. As an American history requirement, for example, Bruce Kuklick has students interview people who lived through the Great Depression, World War II and the New Deal. The 200 senior associates for this year came from teaching, engineering and business backgrounds. They range in age from 62 to over 90, but the majority are in their 70s. The program began in 1981 when Norton Shapiro, a federal government retiree who was auditing courses, suggested an organization for retirees on campus, Ellis said. Until 1986, Shapiro chaired SAVVY's steering committee, which meets monthly during the academic year to organize activities. Initially, the program was strictly academic, said Green, who earned her master's degree in biology at Penn. ``The volunteer business didn't come until later when we thought we ought to give something back to the university for what they were giving us,'' she said. But, Ellis said, the seniors wanted to be real contributors. ``We do not want to stuff envelopes, we don't want to file in somebody's back room, and we don't want to do menial tasks,'' Ellis said. ``Also, we don't want to take projects away from the graduate students. We're not interested in being free help at somebody else's expense.'' Green volunteered at the Funderburg Information Center three days a week, providing campus information to students, tourists and others. Volunteers are expected to work at least three hours a week.

DOC.HEAD: Basic Needs Don't Change With Age, Author Says
DOC.TEXT: Self-defense against old-age stereotypes is the main skill people require as they grow old in this country, and those not yet retired must recognize a need to ``wholly abolish the mischievous idea that after a fixed age we become different, impaired or non-people,'' contends a new book. ``As an `old person' you will need four things _ dignity, money, proper medical service and useful work,'' says author Alex Comfort. ``They are exactly the things you always needed. As things are today, you won't get them, but there is no divinely ordered reason why you should not. So either set out now to see that you do get them or work to force society to change its posture _ or do both.'' Comfort, born in 1920, originally published much of the book in 1976 under the title, ``A Good Age.'' The revised and updated version, in paperback from Crown Publishers Inc., is called, ``Say Yes to Old Age.'' It details the stereotypes our society assigns to its older members, suggests how to develop positive attitudes toward aging, and details many notable people _ from actor George Burns to French President Charles de Gaulle to architect Frank Lloyd Wright _ who achieved great things in later life. ``What is unique in our culture is that older people are made arbitrarily roleless,'' says Comfort. ``Some avoid this because people are more sensible than society, but it is the accepted pattern.'' To change things, he suggests, it becomes necessary to lie down on the tracks and say, ``Stop.'' ``The new old will be more willing, I think, to do this than are the now old; when the now old were young, even in the early days of labor unions, protest was less an organ of orderly political change than it is today.'' By the year 2010, about 14 percent of the U.S. population is expected to be 65 or older. ``Unless we are old already, the next `old people' will be us,'' the book says. ``Whether we go along with treatment now meted out to those who are now old depends upon how far society can sell the bill of goods it sold them.'' This treatment, it contends, relies on two principles: the unpeople principle and the expendable people principle. ``When women were expected to faint at the sight of blood or black people to be amiable Uncle Toms, some did and were; now that those rules are seen to be demeaning or ridiculous, they don't and aren't. ... The trouble with the part we assign to `the old' is that it is the destructive part. They are supposed to be physically and intellectually infirm, slow on the uptake and rigid in their ways.'' Aging, as a physical problem, is real but ``old age, as it is now sold, is an imaginary state which need exist only as long as we believe it does and impose it on people by all kinds of economic and social pressures.'' ``We can't take the pain out of the facts that humans aren't immortal or indefinitely disease-proof, or that illnesses accumulate as we age,'' Comfort says. On the other hand, he says at another point, ``you need not count on illness or decrepitude. Your memory, sexuality, activity, capacity for relationship and zest should normally last as long as you do last in a majority of people.'' Other sample comments: _ ``The chief reasonable fears are of ill health, of poverty, of being the victim of attack or robbery, of falling and of becoming ill while alone. Unreasonable fears (fears, that is, laid on us by old-age role prescription) include fear of losing grip on memory, of being a burden, of making demands and of `losing our dignity' by insisting on public entitlements for which we have paid.'' _ ``The word `senile' is less a diagnosis than a term of abuse.'' _ ``There is no change in the ability of healthy people to learn up to and beyond the ninth decade of life. ... Using the mind preserves it.'' _ ``The commonest cause of sexual nonfunction at all ages is performance anxiety.'' If the last sounds vaguely familiar, this is the same Alex Comfort who wrote the best-seller, ``Joy of Sex,'' when today's retirees were young.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Women Earning Less than Retired Men
DOC.TEXT: Retirement income for many older women is falling significantly behind benefits received by older men, according to a study and congressional testimony. By the year 2000, more than 62 percent of American women are expected to be in the labor force. The percentage is expected to rise throughout the 21st century. But as the number of women workers rises, so does poverty among retirees, especially among retired women living alone, specialists in the problem say. A study by the Older Women's League contends the problem lies not with Social Security income but with private pensions. In 1970, according to the study, women received 70 percent of the Social Security benefits received by men. By last year this had increased to 73 percent. But the report says that while private pension income paid to women in 1974 was 73 percent of that paid to men, by 1987 that had fallen to 54 percent. The study said that nearly 75 percent of older Americans living below the poverty line are women. Of all older women, 41 percent live in near poverty, it said. Other findings: _ Almost four times more widows live in poverty than do wives of the same age. _ Half the widows who are now poor did not live in poverty before their husbands died. _ In 1988, almost half the women 65 or older were widows. Convening a recent hearing of the House subcommittee on retirement income, Chairman William J. Hughes, D-N.J., said: ``Although our mothers, wives and daughters are spending more time in the labor force, poverty among older women is projected to continue to grow well into the next century.'' Louise Crooks, immediate past president of the American Association of Retired Persons, contended that women are at risk ``because they outlive their spouses, are more likely to live alone and are more likely to have little or no private pension income and a low-wage history.'' Because women have tended to enter and leave the work force more often than men, as a group they receive lower Social Security and private pension benefits then men, other witnesses said. Ms. Crooks said that this is largely due to the responsibilities of caring for children, most often assumed by women. Lou Glasse, president of the Older Woman's League, said the Social Security system is best at accommodating the needs of ``families that consist of a lifelong breadwinner, a lifelong homemaker, and children.'' ``Less than 10 percent of American families fit that definition today, and even fewer will fit this mold in the future,'' she said. But other witnesses said Social Security at least provides an income floor for older women and that the real problem lies with their eligibility for private pensions. Many women receive no pensions because they tend to work in the service industry or for smaller firms that do not provide them. Hughes said that if an elderly couple is living on the husband's pension and he dies first, the wife generally receives only a fraction in survivor's benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Ninety-Four and Going Strong
DOC.TEXT: Grace Jordan retired 33 years ago to a riverside she named ``donrovin,'' but at 94 she acts more like the title of her favorite soap opera _ ``The Young and the Restless.'' Intellectually curious, unabashedly positive and suprisingly spry, this tiny woman is a testament to the aphorism taped to her kitchen wall: ``You can't help aging, but you don't have to grow old.'' Mrs. Jordan is believed to be the oldest graduate of Dale Carnegie training, completing a 14-week course when she was 93. She drove until she was 92. At 90, she was still taking aerobics classes. Mrs. Jordan has been slowed recently by fading vision, but she had no trouble climbing the steep slope leading to her pier that juts into the clear water of the lower Corrotoman River. As a tender spring breeze caressed tendrils of silver hair streaming below her straw hat, she sat at the end of the pier and expounded on her philosophy of life. ``Joy in the heart, pleasure in the mind, a body free of pain. If you have that you can be happy all day,'' she said. But one has to begin with an enthusiastic embrace of life. ``He who wakes at dawn with enthusiasm may expect satisfaction at sunset,'' Mrs. Jordan said. ``Youth is enthusiastic and old age likes to sit. It's crazy to do nothing. There's no enthusiasm in nursing homes. They're just sitting around. Life is over. They're just waiting for the end.'' ``Have something to look forward to,'' she advised. ``Before I go to sleep at night I plan what I want to do the next day. ``You've got to keep the mind active and exercised.'' Mrs. Jordan never went to college and quit high school after 2{ years, but she has taken correspondence courses in English grammar, sewing, dress design, flower arranging, interior decorating, landscaping, astrology and oil painting. Many of her paintings hang in area restaurants. ``All my life I've been seeking truth,'' she said. ``I've read every book I could get my hands on. If I can get one new idea out of a book I consider it worth the price.'' After leaving school at 16, the Richmond native went to work in a dry goods store for $4 per week. She later learned bookkeeping and in 1918 began a career in that field. Her lifelong love of learning was the reason she took the Dale Carnegie course in Effective Speaking and Human Relations. ``I might get something to think about,'' she said. As it turned out, she gave her 34 classmates something to think about, said instructor Buck Stahl. ``A deep respect grew from all classmates for her,'' Stahl said. ``When she got up (to speak) you could hear a needle drop. People didn't even squirm in their seats. She was an inspiration to all of us.'' Lillian Taylor, a spokeswoman for Dale Carnegie & Associates Inc. in New York, said Mrs. Jordan is believed to be the oldest gradute of a Carnegie course. More than 3{ million people have graduated from the personal development courses since 1912, she said. In addition to intellectual exercise, Mrs. Jordan is an avid believer in keeping the body active. She isn't participating in an organized exercise program at the moment, but follows a home exercise routine. Loading a cassette into her tape player, she placed a 5-foot-long wooden rod over her shoulders and started waltzing, slowly pulling the rod down her back. The exercise ``keeps the chin out of the navel,'' said the 5-foot woman only slightly bowed by her years. Her husband died in 1979 and she has no children, but Mrs. Jordan said she doesn't get lonely. ``I would if it wasn't for the fact I've learned how to accept what is. I'm interested in life and learning and getting ahead.'' Another secret to her long and productive life, she said, is, ``I don't worry at all.'' She said she learned long ago to turn problems and low periods into growth experiences. ``After each problem worked itself out I had learned a lesson. I was either a little bit stronger, a little bit wiser or had more self-confidence.''

DOC.HEAD: A Plant Will Let You Know What's Wrong
DOC.TEXT: Ailing plants usually provide clues as to what's wrong. Often, just asking why you're concerned points to the solution. Sometimes a little luck helps, too. As an example of such luck: I wanted purple-flowering Texas sage (Leucophyllum frutescens) for an informal, 6-foot hedge to hide a cement-block wall. Six of seven took hold beautifully. The laggard seemingly had an identical start and care. Naturally, it was the middle one. I checked things like drainage, watering and insects and even considered genetic differences. It turned out to be a live wire. Our gray kitten of that name was discovered rolling on the center plant several times a day. A chicken-wire enclosure diverted Wire to such fruitless pursuits as chasing hummingbirds until he forgot about the bush. The hedge soon filled in. Fortunately, most plant problems fall into more routine channels. But it's wise to never assume anything and to check everything. Keep notes. Eliminate possible causes methodically. Bark splitting? Leaves yellowing? Is the entire plant affected or just one side? Has the decline been sudden or over a period of time? How does adjacent vegetation look? Are insects obvious? Is just one plant in trouble, or do similar ones show the same symptoms? Was it planted too deeply or shallowly? Asking such questions usually pinpoints the trouble or provides sufficient information for someone more knowledgeable to suggest the cure, even without seeing the plant. Start by making sure what concerns you isn't normal for a certain time of year. Leaf drop in the fall is expected from deciduous plants. It can be worrisome from evergreens anytime. However, evergreens routinely replace some leaves and many drop lots of them at certain seasons. If the remaining leaves look OK, the plant probably is healthy. If there is a persistent, premature leaf drop, check watering practices first. A sprinkler system may produce a fine lawn but it seldom supplies sufficient moisture for trees and shrubs. These days, with drought and water rationing, occasional deep watering becomes even more important to avoid shallow roots and declining tree and shrub vigor. But remember also that excess water kills a plant as easily as extreme dryness. Wilting foliage can be an early symptom of either. Probe into a few inches of the soil with a trowel, a soil augur, or try inserting a long-blade screwdriver. This may supply the answer. If not, what's adjacent to the plant? An alley, swimming pool, driveway, a patio, the neighbor's yard? What's happened recently? A cement expansion that may have damaged roots or changed drainage? Swimming pool overflowed? Lawn fertilized with possible excess amounts? Chemical spills? Are underground animals a possibility? A neighbor's collection of agaves was ruined by gophers who ate the succulent stems before their tunnels were noticed. A general yellowing of all leaves can be caused by lack of fertilizer, extreme sunlight or high temperatures. If only older leaves are affected, it could be lack of nitrogen or potassium, soil high in salts or poor soil aeration. Yellowing of youngest leaves suggests lack of iron or chemical damage. Marginal burning usually is traced to salinity. Plants under stress seem to attract insect pests. Honeydew on leaves indicates sucking insects. Large numbers of ants may be another clue of their presence. Which side of the plant showed symptoms first and when? Have a soil sterilant or vegetation-killing chemicals been used under or around the plant within three or four years? Some persist in the soil for years but are not picked up by a plant until roots grow into the area. How long have you had the plant? Even with the best care and most favorable growing conditions, many can't be expected to survive more than a year or two. If the worst happens, and the plant dies, the roots and the soil surrounding them may tell why. A bad odor often means the soil was kept too wet. Limited root development may indicate the same. Make it a practice to water in the morning so foliage dries before dark. Deeply and infrequently normally is best. In general, moist conditions favor plant diseases. Among the easiest problems to solve are things like tiny red flowers suddenly appearing on a rosebush that normally has large yellow flowers. Or poor-quality lemons appearing on an orange tree. Trace the branch with the off-type fruit or blooms and usually it will be growing from below the graft _ a noticeable bulge in the main trunk around ground level. Such off-growth, called a ``sucker,'' must be removed. It comes from the rootstock, which normally is much stronger than the top growth. Unless pruned, the inferior but stronger suckers take over the plant.

DOC.HEAD: Non-Hospital Care on the Rise, Medicare Review Shows
DOC.TEXT: Older Californians are spending less time in hospitals and undergoing fewer major surgeries, according to a Medicare review. Medicare patients 65 years and older are being moved out of hospitals and into nursing homes and home health care settings ``earlier and more frequently,'' said Jo Ellen Ross, chief executive officer of California Medical Review Inc., a non-profit organization that contracts with the federal government to monitor Medicare services. As a result, more federal resources should be spent on health care outside hospitals, she said. The shift corresponds to a national trend toward lower hospitalization rates among the elderly. But it can create financial strain for the elderly, according to experts who note that Medicare does not pay for much of the care provided in private homes or elsewhere. About 3.2 million Californians over 65 receive Medicare coverage, but many supplement the coverage by private insurance or out-of-pocket payments. The number of California Medicare recipients admitted to hospitals dropped about 45,000 from 1987 to 1989, although the number of elderly people served by Medicare during that period increased by nearly 110,000, according to the report, which was issued last month. Surgery rates dropped nearly 11 percent in the 12 months after doctors were required in April 1989 to get permission from CMRI before performing a number of major surgical procedures, the report said. The changes have saved taxpayers $114 million. Some physicians complain that they have to fend off pressures from hospitals to discharge Medicare patients because hospitals are paid a flat rate for certain types of care. But Ross said studies show that rarely occurs.
DOC.HEAD: Baton Rouge, La., Selected for 1993 Sports Competition
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. National Senior Sports Organization-The Senior Olympics has selected Baton Rouge, La., as host for the U.S. National Senior Sports Classic IV in June 1993. The event is a multisport competition for senior athletes 55 and older. More than 4,000 athletes are expected to participate in the 1991 games, to be held in Syracuse, said Ellen Conant, president of the USNSO.
DOC.HEAD: Guide Available on Hospice Care
DOC.TEXT: The National Consumers League is releasing a revised guide on the advantages and disadvantages of hospice care for terminally ill patients. ``As medical science finds more sophisticated ways to prolong life, many Americans are facing new and painful questions about death and dying; hospice care is one answer to this question,'' said Linda Golodner, the league's executive director. ``For terminally ill patients and families, one of the most difficult decisions to make is choosing between continuing treatments oriented toward cure or the comforting approaches of hospices,'' she said. The guide describes hospice services and organizations, explains costs, and describes existing standards for hospices. The publication, ``A Consumers Guide to Hospice Care,'' is available for $4 from the National Consumers League at 815 15th St., N.W., Suite 516, Washington, D.C., 20005.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for Aug. 23

DOC.HEAD: Earnings Edge Up in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: K mart Corp. said Monday its second-quarter earnings rose 2.1 percent despite lower prices, mainly because of growth in apparel and seasonal hardware sales. The nation's second-largest retailer said it earned $148 million, or 74 cents a share, during the 13 weeks ended Aug. 1, compared with $145 million, or 72 cents a share, during the same time last year. Revenue rose to $7.8 billion this year from $7 billion last year. ``The strength in apparel sales was particularly encouraging,'' said K mart Chairman Joseph Antonini. He said the corporation's profit margin was dented by K mart's strategy of lowering shelf prices and including the lower-profit margin PACE Membership Warehouse operation in the second-quarter results. For the first half of its fiscal year, K mart's profit rose 3.8 percent to $248.1 million, or $1.24 a share, from $239.1 million, or $1.19 a share, a year earlier. First-half revenue rose to $14.8 billion from $13.1 billion last year. K mart operates more than 4,000 retail stores in the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico, including K mart discount stores, Pay Less Drug Stores, Builders Square, Waldenbooks, PACE and The Sports Authority outlets., Antonini said he expected the corporation's specialty businesses will add to K mart's profitability in the future despite a probable economic slowdown and uncertainty in the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Says Not Enough Support to Hold Emergency Meeting
DOC.TEXT: OPEC said Monday there was not enough support among its members to call an emergency meeting to consider Saudi Arabia's request to boost oil production. A brief statement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said its president, Algeria's Sadek Boussena, would meet with some other oil ministers before the end of the month to discuss the situation. It did not elaborate. Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Hisham Nazer, said Saturday his country would boost oil production by as much as 2 million barrels a day with or without the support of OPEC. He had urged the cartel to hold a special session to try to take measures to bring down oil prices, which have soared because of the Middle East crisis. But the statement issued by OPEC's headquarters in Vienna said that ``an extraordinary meeting of the OPEC conference has not been able to secure the necessary support'' of seven of the group's 13 members. ``An extraordinary meeting of the OPEC conference will, consequently, not be held,'' the statement said. But it said Boussena would meet with other ministers because of the ``situation in the oil market and to reflect the organization's serious concern.'' Saudi Arabia's pledge to increase its production by as much as 2 million barrels a day would make up about half of the crude lost to world markets because of the international embargo on oil shipments from Iraq and Kuwait. The kingdom, the world's No. 1 oil exporter, was pumping about 5.3 million barrels of oil a day at the end of July, according to the International Energy Agency.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 354.95 points since it reached a record close of 2,999.75 on July 16, rose 16.09 to 2,660.89 in the first half hour of trading. DOC.HEAD: British Petroleum to Sell Netherlands Unit
DOC.TEXT: British Petroleum Co. PLC said Monday it will auction off its gas exploration and production holding company in the Netherlands. BP refused to disclose the estimated value of BP Exploratie BV, a wholly owned subsidiary of British Petroleum Nederland. The unit holds stakes in 23 offshore blocks and two on shore. And analysts said the offer would fetch between $60 million and $70 million. The fields produce 14 million standard cubic feet of natural gas each day, said a British Petroleum spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The yield is 1.2 percent of British Petroleum's world production and 2.1 percent of the firm's European production, the spokesman said. The company added that the fields include two areas being developed which could add a further 3 million standard cubic feet to the unit's daily production. Bids have been invited from a small number of companies, which BP declined to identify, the company said. John Browne, BP exploration chief executive officer, said the proposed sale ``is in line with our recent review of worldwide activities and future strategic direction'' which will focus on the company's core producing assets and frontier exploration.

DOC.HEAD: Harleysville Group to Acquire USLICO's Insurance Business
DOC.TEXT: A Pennsylvania insurance firm announced plans Monday to buy the property and casualty insurance operations of Arlington, Va.-based USLICO Corp. for $135 million in cash and notes. Harleysville Group Inc. and its parent company, Harleysville Mutual Insurance Co., said they had signed a letter of intent to buy USLICO's Hawkeye-Security Insurance Co., based in Des Moines, Iowa. The deal also includes Hawkeye-Security's subsidiaries, Des Moines-based United Security Insurance Co. and Freeport, Ill.-based Western States Insurance Co. USLICO would receive $93 million cash from Harleysville Group, $17 million cash from Harleysville Mutual and $25 million in a seven-year, 10 percent note from Harleysville Mutual. Hawkeye-Security would return to USLICO 500,000 shares of USLICO common stock just before closing Jan. 2. The deal, subject to approval by regulators and boards of directors, would be effective Jan. 1. The companies to be acquired are represented by more than 1,000 independent agents in 15 midwestern and western states. ``This acquisition provides us with a tremendous opportunity to achieve the strategic diversification we have sought since we began pursuit of our strategic goal to build a `national network of regional insurance companies' several years ago,'' Bradford W. Mitchell, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Harleysville Group, said in a statement. The move would extend the company's territory to 34 states, he said. In a separate announcement, Harleysville Mutual said it would sell its subsidiary, Harlesville Life Insurance Co., to USLICO for $17 million in a seven-year, 10 percent note. Harleysville Group is a holding company for four East Coast property and casualty insurers, Atlantic Insurance Company of Savannah, Harleysville Insurance Company of New Jersey, Huron Insurance Co. and Worcester Insurance Co. Harleysville Group also manages the operations of Berkshire Mututal Insurance Group, based in Pittsfield, Mass. Last month, Harleysville Group announced an agreement in principle to acquire New York Casualty Insurance Co. and Phoenix General Insurance Co. from Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Co. Harleysville Group had net written premiums of $300.8 million in 1989 and assets of $568.5 million on Dec. 31.

DOC.HEAD: Hyatt Hotels Get New Logo
DOC.TEXT: The Hyatt Corp. announced Monday it is replacing the 19-year-old logo for its hotels and resorts with an updated symbol designed to project a more stylish image. The new rectangular-shaped logo features the word Hyatt, written in stylized white letters on a deep blue backround. A slim red crescent drawn through the letter ``A'' ``symbolizes the sunrise-to-sunset experience of the Hyatt guest,'' Chicago-based Hyatt said in a statement. A grey border beneath the main part of the logo features the words ``Hotels & Resorts'' in white block letters. The old logo, dubbed ``the bug'' by many employees, featured a white and black four-leaf clover shape inside a circle and contained no words identifying it with Hyatt. The new logo will be used for hotels and resorts affiliated with Hyatt Hotels Corp., a subsidiary that operates facilities in the United States, Canada and the Caribbean; and for those run elsewhere in the world by sister subsidiary Hyatt International. ``We've already spent in excess of $1 million developing the new logo _ and it has yet to appear on even one of our hotel cocktail napkins,'' said Adam Aron, Hyatt Hotels' senior vice president for marketing. The new logo will begin appearing next month in national and international advertising. It will take between two to five years to complete the changeover, said Aron. He said the total cost has not been determined. Hyatt Hotels Corp. operates 91 hotels and 15 resorts in the United States, Canada and the Caribbean. Hyatt International operates 35 hotels and 19 resorts in 28 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Markets Ignore Saudis, Prices Up Again
DOC.TEXT: Unleaded gasoline hit record high prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange this morning, and the price of crude oil kept rising despite news that Saudi Arabia would increase production. In early trading, September futures prices for unleaded gasoline hovered around $1 a gallon, more than 4 cents higher than Friday's record-high closing price of 95.97 cents per gallon. ``There's a lot of tension,'' said a vice president with Merrill Lynch Energy Futures who did not want his name used. ``The products, unleaded gasoline and heating oil, are on the way up. They are moving up much faster than the price of crude.'' West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, was up 32 cents to $28.95 per 42-gallon barrel for September delivery in early trading today on the Merc, a leading world market for petroleum products. Some traders had thought petroleum prices might drop today, because Saudi Arabian oil minister Hisham Nazer promised Saturday to boost oil production by as much as 2 million barrels a day with or without the support of OPEC. That would make up roughly half of the 4 million barrels per day that are kept out of the world markets by the embargo of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. Prices opened a bit lower this morning on that news. But the market soon turned around and prices moved higher, with the exception of natural gas, which fell in early trading from $1.440 to $1.425 per 1,000 cubic feet on September futures. Wholesale heating oil was up 1.36 cents to 81.90 cents per gallon for September delivery. ``Basically, what we're seeing here is very frenetic and choppy trading,'' said Jerry Samuels, a vice president with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. The Merrill Lynch vice president said the prices of refined petroleum products were moving higher much faster than crude prices because of fears of supply problems. For example, he said, no one knows what will become of Kuwaiti facilities that supply refined products in Europe. Traders have also expressed concerns of supply problems in the United States because three modern Kuwaiti refineries have been taken out of the market by the embargo. Many of the world's refineries that could boost output are not equipped to produce petroleum products that meet U.S. requirements.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 390.91 down 2.58 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed; Heavy Rains Pressure Beans
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures were mostly lower and corn and wheat futures were narrowly mixed in quiet dealings today on the Chicago Board of Trade. There were some concerns that heavy rains overnight in the Midwest might have damaged corn and soybean plants, especially in north-central Illinois, analysts said. But those fears were offset by perceptions that the rain helped crops in other areas. ``Our weatherman says that overall the rain is more beneficial than detrimental,'' said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Trading in the corn and wheat pits was subdued as players awaited fresh supply-and-demand developments and news about the Middle East. In early trading, wheat futures were } cent lower to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.81{ a bushel; corn futures were { cent lower to \ cent higher with September at $2.51 a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent lower with September at $1.15} a bushel; soybeans were 4 cents lower to 3 cents higher with August at $6.12 a bushel. Cattle futures were lower while pork futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cattle futures dropped in a response to Friday's monthly Agriculture Department cattle-on-feed report, which showed far more cattle placed on feedlots last month than the market had expected. Live cattle futures were .65 cent to 1.05 cents lower with August at 77.25 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .50 cent to .85 cent lower with August at 89.15 cents a pound; live hogs were .37 cent lower to .08 cent higher with August at 57.20 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .88 cent higher with August at 49 cents a pound. Livestock futures fell on Friday; pork bellies were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: GM Contract Proposal Due This Week
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. will present the United Auto Workers union with a contract proposal this week, less than a month before the UAW-GM labor contract expires, the company's chief negotiator said today. Alfred Warren said he expects the company's proposal to cross the main bargaining table late this week. Warren met with reporters this morning, shortly after UAW President Owen Bieber told the media he had urged GM to come up with a proposal soon. ``I had hoped that they would have had a proposal out by this time,'' Bieber said. ``It hasn't been forthcoming. I expect we'll see one in the next few days, (which) ought to be one that is not a starter proposal.'' The UAW has been bargaining with GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. since July for three contracts covering more than 450,000 workers. For the first time in 11 years, the Big Three contracts expire at the same moment _ on Sept. 14. Bieber said the union would choose its target company for bargaining within 10 days. The union has high-level meetings set for Aug. 27-28, and it's likely the target will be chosen at that time. Analysts expect GM will be chosen. Traditionally, the agreement reached with the target company forms a pattern for contracts at the other two of the Big Three. DOC.HEAD: Rocky Mountain News Announces $100 Million in New Presses
DOC.TEXT: The Rocky Mountain News said Aug. 15 it will spend $100 million over the next three years to more than double the size of its printing plant and install new offset presses to improve color reproduction. The new, eight-unit Goss Colorliner presses will allow the News to print 48 pages daily in full color, said Larry Strutton, the newspaper's publisher, president and chief executive officer. Strutton said the first press will arrive at the News plant in a year and will be installed over the next nine months. After that, a new press will be added every six weeks. The new presses will be fully computerized and have no manual controls. They also will be faster, with the capacity to print 75,000 papers an hour, 5,000 more than the existing presses, said Strutton. The News has a daily circulation of 364,790 and Sunday circulation of 415,322.
DOC.HEAD: Government Recommends Against Merger
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Justice Department official is recommending against the proposed merger of the daily Manteca Bulletin and semiweekly Manteca News. ``We almost feel like we're being picked on because we're smaller,'' Darell Phillips, director of California newspaper operations for Morris Newspaper Corp., said Aug. 13. Morris owns the Bulletin. The Justice Department's antitrust division found that poor management caused a $4.7 million loss by the News since it began publishing in 1977, said James Rill, assistant attorney general. The division also decided that owners of the News did not try to make a profit or sell the newspaper, he added. ``I conclude that the applicants have not carried their burden of showing that no other management efforts would be likely to succeed in reversing the News' losses,'' Rill said. Thus, he found that the News is not a failing newspaper under the law. The Bulletin has a daily circulation of 6,000 in Manteca, a San Joaquin Valley city 70 miles southeast of San Francisco. The News is distributed free to about 19,000 households on Wednesdays and has a paid circulation of about 2,400 for its Friday edition.
DOC.HEAD: South Pittsburg Hustler Sold
DOC.TEXT: The South Pittsburg Hustler has been sold by the grandson of the man who founded the weekly Marion County newspaper 91 years ago. Publisher Rob Woodfin, in an announcement in the paper Aug. 16, said Sequatchie Publishing Inc. had been sold Aug. 10 to investors organized as Marion County Newspapers Inc. The sale includes Sequatchie Printing Co. and the Sequatchie Valley Purchase and Sequatchie Valley Plus shoppers guides, as well as the newspaper. The purchase price was not disclosed. The newspaper was founded in 1899 by Roy Woodfin, and his sons, Robert Woodfin Sr. and Oran ``Woody'' Woodfin, later took over operation. Rob Woodfin began managing the paper in 1981 and bought it from his father, Robert Woodfin Sr., in 1983. William C. ``Chris'' Smith, the new publisher, said readers would see few changes. The staff and the name will stay the same, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Number of Working Rigs Declines by Five
DOC.TEXT: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States dipped by five this week to 987, according to a widely-watched index of drilling activity released Monday. Baker Highes Inc, an oil toolmaker, said its count had climbed by 26 to 992 a week ago. In the two previous weeks before that increase, the count had dropped by a combined 56 rigs. A year ago this week, the count was 903. The Houston-based company has kept track of the rig count since 1940. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not those producing oil. Ike Kerridge, a vice president at Baker Hughes, said Monday he was not sure why the count dropped slightly this week. But he added he expected the count to increase if the Middle East crisis continues to push oil prices higher. ``There is a time lag. Price changes are not immediately reflected'' in the rig count,'' Kerridge said. Oil is just one half of the rig count, he noted. The other factor is natural gas, ``and those prices are still depressed.'' ``If oil prices are looking like they're going to stay higher, there probably will be an increase soon,'' he said. ``If I had to guess, I'd say two to four weeks.'' At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Among major oil-producing states, Texas gained seven rigs. Michigan, Louisiana, Kansas and Pennsylvania each gained two more rigs. States reporting declines for the week include New Mexico, down eight; Colorado, down five; Oklahoma, down four; and Ohio, down three. North Dakota and Wyoming each lost one rig.

DOC.HEAD: Sprint Changing Long-Distance Sales Division
DOC.TEXT: US Sprint said Monday it is reorganizing its long-distance sales and service division in an attempt to attract greater numbers of small customers and improve service to larger ones. The company's national markets division will switch from five service groups to two, one focusing on customers with more than $100,000 in business and the other on residential and smaller business customers. Sprint, the nation's third largest long distance company, announced a 55 percent drop in second quarter earnings a month ago. It said at the time it would eliminate 1,000 jobs nationwide and switch more employees to sales and service jobs. Sprint said about 500 administrative jobs would be trimmed from its national markets division because of the changes there. The two divisions will ensure that larger customers receive the more sophisticated products they want while smaller customers receive a level of sales and service that was only available to larger customers before, said Richard C. Smith, president of national markets. Sprint, based in Kansas City, is owned 80 percent by United Telecommunications Inc., of Kansas City and 20 percent by the GTE Corp. of Stamford, Conn.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with closing European figures, midday New York prices.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar rose today against most major foreign currencies but lost ground against the Japanese yen and Canadian dollar in volatile trading in Europe. Gold prices also rose. Traders said the currency markets have concerns about sluggishness in the U.S. economy but are focused on developments in the Middle East. They said signs of increasing trouble will boost the dollar. ``But I think it's still fairly clear that the trend is for a lower dollar,'' said one trader. ``We're in a stabilization phase right now, which is actually quite healthy for the market.'' Dealers added that the dollar found some further support from concerns about Iraq's intentions surrounding Western nationals in Kuwait. The Iraqi government over the weekend said it intended to hold U.S. and other nationals whose nations were supporting economic sanctions against Baghdad. The yen is gaining against the dollar, dealers said, because it initially fell following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. It was thought that Japan's economy would be hardest hit by the prospects of soaring oil prices, but the thinking has changed, traders said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 147.47 Japanese yen from 147.35 yen at Friday's close. Later in London, it fell to 146.90 yen. At midday in New York, the dollar was quoted at 146.70 yen. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9185 from $1.9195 late Friday. In New York, the pound was quaoted at $1.91625 at midday. DOC.HEAD: Cirrus, Plus Automatic Teller Networks Agree to Share Machines
DOC.TEXT: Cash-strapped consumers will soon have access to about twice as many automated teller machines. Plus System Inc. and Cirrus System Inc., the nation's largest networks of ATMs, announced a formal agreement Monday to share their machines. ``Plus and Cirrus are no longer competing for ATM locations,'' D. Daniel Browning, president of Plus System Inc., said in a statement. ``Competition in the future will be based on the value and service we provide.'' Those who hold cards that work in either system should be able to get cash from about twice as many machines as they do now within 1{ years, according to Plus. About three-quarters of the nation's ATMs belong to either Plus or Cirrus networks. The systems have up to 55,000 ATMs combined in locations such as airports, shopping centers and financial institutions. Banks, though, will continue to be restricted from issuing cards for both networks, Plus said. ``With today's agreement, Plus and Cirrus have virtually eliminated the concern people have about running out of cash while away from home,'' Browning said.

DOC.HEAD: Share Prices Drop on Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Uncertainty and mounting tensions in the Gulf sent share prices plummeting Monday on the London Stock Exchange. Dealers said investors were unwilling to take new positions nor hold existing ones, and largely overlooked Wall Street's early gains. Commentators said declines on other European stock markets over Mideast jitters spilled over into the London market. At the close, the broad-based Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100 index stood at 2,156.6, a loss of 20.3 points or 0.9 percent. The index ranged from a high of 2,176.5 to a low of 2,149.2. The narrower 30-share index closed down 19.4 points at 1,659.5, while the broader 500-share index finished at 1,163.46, down 10.97 points. Turnover was a moderate 350.6 million shares, compared with 500.5 million shares a day ago.

Blue-chip stocks rallied today, but the rest of the market remained on the defensive after its slide of the past five weeks. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 354.95 points since it reached a record close of 2,999.75 on July 16, rose 23.27 to 2,668.07 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. But losers outnumbered gainers by about 5 to 4 in the overall tally of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 629 up, 796 down and 501 unchanged. Analysts said stocks appeared to benefit from an easing of some of the most extreme worries that had developed of late as a result of the tensions in the Middle East. That helped encourage buyers to move in looking for ``bargains'' among recently depressed stocks. But brokers said serious misgivings persisted about prospects for the U.S. economy after this summer's upsurge in the price of oil and other forces set in motion by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Economists say the Federal Reserve has little room to maneuver as it seeks to avoid a recession and at the same time minimize the inflationary effects of the new oil shock. DOC.HEAD: Company Helps Scientist Create `Cockroach Hell'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Cockroaches might prefer to starve to death than scurry anywhere near powerful repellents that researchers hope can be used to build roach-proof homes and businesses. Richard Brenner has spent six years creating a deterrent to cockroaches as an entomologist for the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Gainesville, Fla., research lab. He has worked with Air Vent Inc. of Peoria Heights to develop the repellents and a deadly new bait that someday might provide owners of infested homes and businesses a lethal one-two punch for controlling the pesky insect. ``There's no silver bullet to do the job of cockroach eradication,'' Brenner said. ``No single solution will ever solve cockroach problems. ``But we're coming up with some things that will prevent infestation and eliminate the growing number of health problems we've linked to cockroaches.'' The products resulted from a two-year research project funded by Air Vent. Mike Daniels, national sales manager for Air Vent, envisions putting the repellent in insulation and other construction materials. And Air Vent is ready to market the bait as part of a new attic ventilation system, designed with Brenner's help, that is designed to drive roaches out of attics. Brenner's research has determined that cockroaches often enter a home through roof vents and small openings. The insects prefer warm, moist, dark environments to breed and find attics ideal because of the static air. Other ideas for the repellents include using them on cardboard boxes that carry food and attract roaches when they sit in warehouses and storerooms. The repellents are five years from receiving EPA approval for sale to the public, Brenner said. But the attic ventilation system and bait could reach the marketplace within a year, he said. The investment may be worth the wait. Brenner estimates that $1.5 billion is spent each year on pesticides to kill cockroaches. Another benefit of the research was Brenner's discovery that cockroaches are responsible for serious allergy problems. His study found cockroaches produce allergens that affect an estimated 10 million to 14 million people. He said the cockroach allergens are the second most common allergy causer among asthmatics. ``We need to design more insect-resistent structures and eliminate infestation by cockroaches,'' Brenner said. ``That's why we're excited about these products. We are making some progress.''

DOC.HEAD: Arco Keeps Gasoline Freeze, Hikes Diesel and Jet Fuel
DOC.TEXT: Atlantic Richfield Co. said Monday it will keep a 12-day freeze on gasoline but raise prices for diesel and jet fuel. Arco had heeded a call 12 days ago for oil companies to control prices during the Middle East crisis. The company had included diesel and jet fuel in the freeze announced Aug. 8. But George H. Babikian, president of Arco Products Co., a marketing and refining division, said Arco ``cannot continue the freeze on diesel and jet fuel prices in the face of sharp differences in marketplace prices between Arco and its competitors.'' Arco has also been forced to augment jet fuel supplies with purchases on the spot market at high prices, Babikian said in a statement. Babikian said the gasoline freeze was being reviewed daily. The company said it was encouraging dealers to ``show restraint in setting prices'' and urged drivers to reduce use of gasoline during the crisis. President Bush on Aug. 8 asked oil companies to do what they could to hold down gasoline prices following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Arco receives most of its crude oil from Alaska and not the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Slip in Quiet Session
DOC.TEXT: Soybean and wheat futures prices closed modestly lower Monday while corn ended mixed in a quiet session on the Chicago Board of Trade. Rainy weather in the Midwest weighed on the soybean market and limited gains in corn, analysts said. ``All in all, it was a dull, nondescript day,'' said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Soybeans traded in a narrow range, from $6.24 to $6.34 a bushel for the contract for November delivery. Lespinasse said the lower $6.30 range has been established as an area of considerable resistance for soybeans. When market bulls were unable to rally the November contract beyond $6.34, many turned sellers and pushed the market back down. At the close, wheat futures were } cent to 1\ cents lower with the contract for September delivery at $2.81 a bushel; corn was { cent lower to 2{ cents higher with September at $2.52 a bushel; oats were { cent lower across the board with September at $1.16\ a bushel; soybeans were 4{ cents lower to 1{ cents higher with August at $6.10{ a bushel.
Stock prices were mixed today as the market struggled to recover from its recent slide. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 11.14 at 2,655.94.

DOC.HEAD: Forecast Says Construction Will Fall 7 Percent In 1990
DOC.TEXT: Construction contracts will decline 7 percent this year as the nation struggles to pull out of a continuing building slump, according to a private forecast issued Monday. Contracts in 1990 are expected to total $247.07 billion, compared with $266.96 billion last year, McGraw-Hill Information Services Co. said. In its latest Dodge-Sweet's Construction Outlook, McGraw-Hill predicted housing starts would tumble 11 percent to 1.38 million units this year, with most of the drop from the apartment and condominium sector. The contract value of housing construction is expected to fall 7 percent, McGraw-Hill said. Commercial and manufacturing building is expected to drop 16 percent this year, hurt largely by big decrease in office buildings, McGraw-Hill said. Institutional building, which includes schools and hospitals, should decline 3 percent, it said. The total value of non-residential buildings is expected to slip 10 percent, according to the forecast. Meanwhile, the total value of public works construction is expected to decline 1 percent, McGraw-Hill said. But George A. Christie, McGraw-Hill's chief economist, said the worst appears to be over for the nation's building market. ``Every decline has its limit,'' he said.

Blue-chip stocks staged a mild rally today, but the rest of the market remained on the defensive after its slide of the past five weeks. Analysts said stocks appeared to benefit from an easing of some of the most extreme worries that had developed of late as a result of the tensions in the Middle East. That helped encourage buyers to move in looking for ``bargains'' among recently depressed stocks. Brokers said serious misgivings persisted, however, about prospects for the U.S. economy after this summer's upsurge in the price of oil and other forces set in motion by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Economists say the Federal Reserve has little room to maneuver as it seeks to avoid a recession and at the same time minimize the inflationary effects of the new oil shock.

DOC.HEAD: Say Russian Republic Wants to Join OPEC
DOC.TEXT: Russia's foreign economics minister said Monday the Soviet Union's largest republic would like to join OPEC. Viktor Yaroshenko told a news conference that the republic considered itself free to join such organizations because of its assertion of independence of central Soviet control. The republic's parliament has decided that it _ and not Soviet authorities _ control the resources on Russia's territory. ``We are prepared to enter as one of the members of OPEC, now perhaps as an observer but in the future, if we are accepted, to enter fully,'' Yaroshenko told reporters gathered in Russia's Supreme Soviet chambers. It wasn't clear how the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would respond to an application, if it received one. The cartel produces a substantial portion of the West's energy needs. The Russian government is now headed by Ivan Silayev, a reform-minded leader who works closely with Boris N. Yeltsin, the republic's president. They are trying to generate foreign currency to help solve dire economic problems, and the republic's oil is one potential revenue source. Most of the Soviet Union's oil is located in Russia. The country as a whole produces about 12.1 million barrels daily, making it one of the world's leading producers. But much of that oil is consumed domestically.

DOC.HEAD: T-Bill Interest Rates Rise
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose in Monday's auction to their highest level in a month. The Treasury Department sold $9.2 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.55 percent, up from 7.41 percent last week. Another $9.2 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.45 percent, up from 7.31 percent last week. The rates were the highest since July 16 when three-month bills sold for 7.62 percent and six-month bills averaged 7.52 percent. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.80 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,807.10 and 7.85 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,623.40. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable-rate mortgages, rose to 7.73 percent last week, up from 7.70 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: K-III Holdings Buys Private Book Club Operator
DOC.TEXT: The publishing concern K-III Holdings said Monday it has agreed to buy Reader's Garden Inc., a privately-held company that operates special interest book clubs. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Reader's Garden operates the Reader's Subscription book club, which features serious fiction and nonfiction titles, classic literature and poetry, and the Garden Book Club which reaches serious gardeners. The company has sales estimated at $5 million a year. The acquisition is being made through K-III's Newbridge Communications division, which was formerly known as the Macmillan Book Clubs Inc. K-III Holdings is a private firm formed in February 1989 by the buyout specialists Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. and several former executives of the publishing and information services company Macmillan Inc. Macmillan was acquired in 1988 by Maxwell Communication Corp. of Great Britain. K-III Holdings acquired Macmillan Book Clubs from Maxwell in July 1989, and renamed it Newbridge Communications. It also owns Intertec Publishing Corp., a publisher of trade magazines and technical books, and K-III Press, which publishes directories and other information products for the transportation industries. K-III Holdings' annual revenue exceeds $200 million.

DOC.HEAD: GM Contract Proposal Due; Bieber Turning Up Heat at Big Three
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. said Monday it will give the United Auto Workers union a contract offer later this week designed to make the union pick the automaker as the target company for nationwide negotiations. GM Vice President Alfred Warren, the company's chief labor negotiator, disclosed its intentions in his first meeting with the press since the opening of union talks on July 18. He didn't specify a day or give further details about what the No. 1 automaker would offer. ``We would always rather lead than follow,'' he said. ``It seems only appropriate that we would go first.'' Contracts covering more than 450,000 workers at GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. expire Sept. 14, contributing to a growing sense of urgency in an industry that has been troubled by a slow economy and foreign competition. On Aug. 28, after a UAW leadership conference in Detroit, the union is expected to choose one of the three automakers as a target for further negotiations. Historically, an agreement reached with the target company becomes a pattern for the other automakers. Each company prefers to be the union's target because it provides the opportunity to bargain a contract with more flexibility toward that company's needs. Shortly after talks opened between the union and each of the Big Three, negotiators broke into subcommittees to address specific contract issues, such as job security, health care costs and time off. Warren said work in those subcommittees has helped form the company's proposal. But another aspect in formulating the proposal was the company's desire to be the target company, he said. Meanwhile, UAW President Owen Bieber goes to the main bargaining tables at Ford on Wednesday and Chrysler on Thursday. He was at GM on Monday to remind bargainers that 25 days remain before the current contracts expire. ``I had hoped that they would have had a proposal out by this time,'' he said. ``It hasn't been forthcoming. I expect we'll see one in the next few days, (which) ought to be one that is not a starter proposal.'' Warren said Monday he would fulfill that wish late this week. A spokesman for Ford who declined to be identified said his company's initial proposal was due Thursday. Chrysler spokesman Lee Sechler said he knew of no timetable for such a proposal.

DOC.HEAD: Lilly Announces $540 Million Expansion
DOC.TEXT: Eli Lilly & Co. will create a new technology center under a $540 million expansion project expected to create 1,000 new jobs, officials announced Monday. The pharmaceutical manufacturer will build several new buildings at its Lilly Industrial Center in Indianapolis. The company's 3,000 employees there are expected to increase to 4,000 by the turn of the century, according to a Lilly statement. Most of the new jobs will be high-paying professional research and development positions, the company said in a statement. The project is expected to create 800 construction jobs as well, said Lilly spokesman Edward A. West. Under the project's first phase, a $120 million biotechnology development center will be built, to employ 100 scientists and engineers. Another $235 million will be spent on additional projects and on-site improvement. Lilly will fund the major expansion through its continuing strong sales and profits. In fiscal year 1989, the company reported record net sales of $4.1 billion, up from $3.6 billion in 1988. Profits for the year totalled $939 million, up from $761 million a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: United Artists Signs $2.8 Billion Financing Agreement
DOC.TEXT: United Artists Entertainment Co. has signed a $2.8 billion agreement that refinances the company's existing debt, company officials announced Monday. The transaction also will enhance the company's ability to replace short-term floating funds with long-term fixed rate funds, and will provide funding availability to pursue future opportunities, the company said in a news release. ``The refinancing was successful due to the breadth, depth and quality of the company's lending relationships,'' said Brendan Clouston, UAE executive vice president and chief financial officer. Company executives would not release financial details, but said they believed the terms on the debt were attractive and appropriate given the strength of the credit. The agreement does not represent any material increase in borrowing costs, they said. Eight institutions led the various financings, but about 100 banks and institutions comprise the financing syndicate, UAE said. The refinancing has been planned since the firm acquired United Cable in May 1989 in order to create a flexible long-term capital structure for UAE, Clouston said. UAE owns or manages 86 cable television systems serving about 2.7 million subscribers, as well as 2,660 motion picture screens in 609 locations.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed mostly higher against the world's major currencies in moderate trading Monday, recovering ground after many days of decline. Gold prices also rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, an ounce of gold closed at $410.10, up 50 cents from Friday. Later, Republic National Bank quoted an after-hours bid of $409.25, up 75 cents, as of 4 p.m. EDT. Traders said much of the dollar's advance was due to investors selling positions they held in other currencies in exchange for the U.S. currency in order to take a profit. ``The market was stretched to the point of a need for a correction,'' said Lorenzo Troni, vice president of foreign exchange at PaineWebber International in New York. ``There is always a point of profit-taking.'' The dollar also was boosted by President Bush's strong statements to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein about the fate of foreigners held in Iraq and Kuwait. ``People are a little bit concerned we could be approaching a flashpoint in this issue,'' said John McCarthy, chief dealer at Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York. The dollar typically is viewed as a safe haven in times of international turmoil. Another factor boosting the dollar was a slight weakness in the German mark due to trouble in the Social Democratic coalition government in East Germany, McCarthy said. ``It demonstrate that things are not completely in order there,'' he said. But McCarthy didn't expect the dollar's rebound to last. He said the currency remains weak against other major currencies due to rising interest rates abroad, which tend to support those foreign currencies, and sluggishness in the U.S. economy. The dollar closed at 1.5641 marks in New York, up from Friday's close of 1.5500 marks. Friday's close was an all-time low for the dollar against the Germany currency. Earlier, in Europe, the dollar closed at 1.5625 marks, up from 1.5485 Friday. The dollar also strengthened against the British pound. One pound cost $1.9135 in New York, cheaper than $1.9230 late Friday. In London, the pound fell to $1.9185 from $1.9195 late Friday. But the dollar lost ground against the Japanese yen. Troni said the yen was boosted by weekend reports that Iran would supply oil to Japan, whose economy is almost entirely dependent on imported oil. But in London, it fell to 146.90 yen.
