DOC.HEAD: Interco Announces Details of Restructuring Plan
DOC.TEXT: Interco Inc., a footwear and furniture maker, will ask its bondholders to exchange their bonds for 95 percent of the company's common stock and other consideration under a complicated restructuring plan announced Monday. The plan is designed to restructure the $1.9 billion debt that has plagued the St. Louis-based company for the past two years. It calls for the company to undertake a 23.5-for-1 reverse stock split of Interco's roughly 38.7 million shares of common stock, issue 98 million new shares of stock and take on $202 million in new debt. Interco's stock closed at 31\ cents a share in consolidated trading Monday, down 12{ cents from Friday. Most of the new shares and the new debt, along with warrants to buy additional stock, will go to bondholders in exchange for about $900 million in current debt. Some of the new shares of stock will go to preferred stockholders, who will be asked to convert their preferred stock to common stock under the plan, which must be approved by the company's creditors. The company reached a basic agreement with representatives of its creditor groups three weeks ago after a weekend of marathon negotiations in New York. That agreement led to Monday's plan. Interco has been struggling to pay off its large junk-bond debt since it borrowed $1.65 billion in 1988 to fend off a hostile takeover attempt by corporate raiders Steven and Michael Rales. At the time, the company made men's and women's apparel, operated 201 retail stores such as do-it-yourself hardware stores and discount clothing stores, and owned footwear and furniture stores. To pay off its debt, the company announced plans to sell off all of its companies except the four it currently operates: Converse and Florsheim footwear manufacturers along with furniture makers Lane Co. and Broyhill Industries. That plan faltered when the subsidiaries were sold for far less than what the company anticipated. That, coupled with the collapse of the junk-bond market, left Interco with more debt than it started with. ``The changes contemplated by the agreement in principle will resolve that burdensome situation by restructuring Interco's balance sheet,'' said Richard B. Loynd, chairman and chief executive officer.

DOC.HEAD: Orange Juice Futures Crash to 8-Month Low on Brazil Price Cut
DOC.TEXT: Orange juice futures prices settled at their lowest levels in nearly eight months Monday after two Brazilian processors cut their prices for the first time since a Christmas-time freeze shriveled the Florida orange crop. On other commodity markets, petroleum futures were mostly higher; precious metals were mixed; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Wholesale frozen concentrated orange juice futures settled 1.95 cents to the permitted daily limit of 5 cents lower on the New York Cotton Exchange with the contract for delivery in September down 1.95 cents at $1.687 a pound, the lowest settlement of a near-month contract since Dec. 29. Monday's decline followed a plunge of 9.95 cents in the September contract on Friday amid rumors that the large Brazilian juice processor Cutrala S.A. had slashed its preferred-customer price more than 20 percent to $1.813 from $2.078 a pound. Cutrala confirmed the price cut on Monday. Another Brazilian processor, Citro Sucro S.A., said it had cut its prices by the same amount. The reductions were the first by the Brazilians since a freeze last winter destroyed about 30 percent of the Florida orange crop. The freeze drove prices up sharply and forced U.S. beverage companies to rely on Brazil for about half of their orange juice needs. The price cut was a surprise, said analyst Judith Ganes of Merrill Lynch & Co. ``It was generally expected by most industry sources that Brazil would keep prices steadfast for at least another month or two, until after first Florida crop estimate,'' she said. Analysts said the Brazilians apparently reduced their prices in hopes of stimulating sales following industry reports of slumping orange juice consumption. There was no sign that Florida processors intend to follow suit. Esther Eskansy, a trader with Cargill Investor Services Inc., said Florida processors' prices already were below the Brazilians' and were now close to the new Brazilian levels. Ms. Ganes said that even if retailers decided to pass the savings along, it could be two to three months before consumers see a reduction in orange juice prices. Petroleum futures continued to rise on the New York Mercantile Exchange as Persian Gulf tensions escalated, fueling speculation that Middle East oil shipments to the United States will remain restricted. In the gulf, Iraq announced it had carried out a plan to move Western hostages to vital military installations to deter any U.S. attack and warned its people not to try to hide any of the thousands of foreigners trapped in the country. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 7 cents lower to 63 cents higher with September at $28.56 a barrel; heating oil was 2.42 cents to 4 cents higher with September at 82.96 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2.85 cents to 4.28 cents higher with September at $1.0025 a gallon. Cattle futures prices fell on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, as expected, after the Agriculture Department on Friday reported a larger-than-expected number of cattle were placed on feedlots in July. Thomas Morgan, president of Sterling Research Co., said losses in the near-term contracts were limited by perceptions that fed cattle supplies will be relatively tight before the animals placed on feed in July begin to reach the market in November. Pork futures advanced, led by sharp gains in the belly market. Live cattle settled .03 cent to .60 cent lower with October at 77.27 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .60 cent lower to .02 cent higher with August at 89.67 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .65 cent higher with October at 50.07 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.6 cents to 2 cents higher with August at 49.72 cents a pound. Soybean and wheat futures prices closed modestly lower Monday while corn ended mixed in a quiet session on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat futures settled 1 cent to 1{ cents lower with September at $2.81\ a bushel; corn was { cent lower to 2{ cents higher with September at $2.52\ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to { cent higher with September at $1.16\ a bushel; soybeans were 4\ cents lower to 1\ cents higher with August at $6.10} a bushel. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures ended 50 cents to $1.10 higher with August at $410.10 a troy ounce; silver futures were 5 cents lower across the board with September at $5.145 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Outlook for Prolonged Crisis Boosts Oil Prices
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf to CORRECT attribution to a Merc spokeswoman; PICK UP 15th graf pvs, There are . . .
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale unleaded gasoline prices surged over the $1 mark for the first time Monday, boosted by what traders called a growing belief the Middle East crisis will persist and create a long-lasting tightness in supply. Anxiety over supplies also pushed prices up at the pump. The American Automobile Association said its nationwide check of unleaded self-serve regular averaged $1.237 a gallon Monday, up 2.1 cents from a week earlier. The average is 16.2 cents higher since the crisis erupted Aug. 2, AAA said. The volatility that has beset oil trading over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait compelled the New York Mercantile Exchange to temporarily amend its rules Monday to allow bigger daily price swings on oil-futures contracts. The Merc is one of the world's leading markets for oil and gasoline products and is an important pacesetter for prices at the retail level. Unleaded gasoline for September delivery reached $1.015 per gallon at one point during the Merc's trading day Monday, the first time that's ever happened. The price later settled for the day at a record close of $1.003 per gallon, an increase of 4.28 cents over Friday's closing price. West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, dipped 7 cents per barrel to $28.56 for September delivery. But prices for later months were all up, some by more than 50 cents a barrel. ``More players think the crisis is going to last longer,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. The market was responding partly to President Bush's declaration that Americans held in Iraq and Kuwait are ``hostages'' and that the United States holds Iraq responsible, she said. Some traders had predicted oil prices would drop Monday on the news that Saudi Arabia promised over the weekend to boost production by up to 2 million barrels per day. That would make up roughly half of the shortfall caused by the international boycott of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. Hittle said the markets might not respond to any increase in Saudi production until they see more than verbal assurances. She said the September contract price of crude oil might have been the only month to fall because traders were already starting to concentrate on prices for October futures, with just one more day of trading to go on the September futures contract. Unleaded gasoline and home heating oil contracts rose quickly because of concerns about shortfalls, said a Merrill Lynch Energy Futures vice president who did not want his name used. ``There's a lot of tension,'' he said. ``The products, unleaded gasoline and heating oil, are on the way up. They are moving up much faster than the price of crude.'' Home heating oil for September delivery closed at 82.96 cents per gallon, up 2.42 cents from Friday's close. The price of natural gas stayed sluggish Monday, falling from $1.440 to $1.417 per 1,000 cubic feet for September delivery. The rules change at the Merc will be in effect for the next 30 days and could only become permanent following another vote by the board and notification of federal regulators, a Merc spokeswoman said. There are no limits to the movements in spot prices, or the prices for petroleum products to be delivered in the next month. But limits are imposed on the upward or downward movements on futures prices for subsequent months. Under the temporary rules, the limits will be expanded by up to $1 for crude futures and 2 cents for gasoline and home heating oil futures. The limits are designed to give investors an idea of their potential losses when each trading day begins, offering them a degree of protection from rapidly moving markets.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Says Not Enough Support to Hold Emergency Meeting
DOC.TEXT: OPEC said Monday it will not hold an emergency session to consider increasing oil production to help make up for the shortage caused by the Mideast crisis. But analysts predicted Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, would fulfill its pledge to boost output by as much as 2 million barrels a day to try to steady nervous oil markets. ``It is beyond assumption. ... The kingdom of Saudi Arabia is going to increase production,'' said Peter Gignoux, director of the international energy department at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in London. ``Saudi Arabia probably would have preferred to do it with OPEC's authorization. (But) they'll do it,'' agreed Peter Bogin, associate director for oil markets at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Paris. Meanwhile, Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez said Monday that several OPEC nations with the capacity to increase oil production expect to meet within days, despite the OPEC announcement. Perez, who had previously offered to increase oil output by 500,000 barrels daily if OPEC agreed, said his country would produce more oil without an OPEC meeting. Monday's news was greeted with generally higher prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. grade of crude, was down 7 cents to $28.56 per 42-gallon barrel. But later contract months settled higher. The average price of a basket of crudes monitored by OPEC surged last week to $25.29 a barrel, surpassing the cartel's newly set target of $21. Analysts say about 4 million barrels a day have been pulled off the market because of the international embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil shipments imposed after Iraq invaded its tiny neighbor. Iraq produced about 3.1 million barrels a day in late July, while Kuwait produced 1.6 million barrels, according to the International Energy Agency, an arm of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. Saudi Arabian Oil Minister Hisham Nazer said Saturday that his country intended to increase oil production with or without approval from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. He had urged the 13-nation cartel to hold an urgent meeting to discuss the situation. But a brief statement issued by OPEC headquarters in Vienna said a majority of members did not endorse the call. ``Since the proposal of Saudi Arabia to hold such a conference has not been able to secure the necessary support, ... an extraordinary meeting of the OPEC conference will, consequently, not be held,'' said the statement carried by OPECNA, the group's news agency. It said OPEC President Sadek Boussena, the Algerian oil minister, would meet with some other ministers before the end of the month because of the ``situation in the oil market and to reflect the organization's serious concern.'' It gave no details. The Algerian news agency APS quoted an unidentified source close to Boussena as saying that three nations had joined Saudi Arabia and Venezuela in supporting a special meeting. It did not name the countries. Iranian Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh was quoted by the official Islamic Republic News Agency as saying he opposed an immediate meeting because there was enough oil in storage in the industrialized world to make up for the loss. Saudi Arabia, which pumps about a quarter of the cartel's oil, has an OPEC quota of just under 5.4 million barrels a day. While its production could be boosted by as much as 2 million barrels more a day, analysts predicted Venezuela could produce about 500,000 more barrels above its current level of 2 million barrels to help fill the oil gap. Nigeria could add a few hundred thousand barrels to its OPEC quota of 1.6 million barrels, analysts said. The United Arab Emirates also has the capacity to lift production from its quota of 1.5 million barrels a day to 2 million barrels or more. But Bogin predicted it might be reluctant to do so. The U.A.E., like Kuwait, was criticized earlier this year by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein for producing more than its OPEC quota and helping drive down oil prices. He claimed lower prices cost Iraq $14 billion in oil revenues in the past year. Late last month in Geneva, OPEC ministers agreed to limit production to 22.5 million barrels a day to try to push crude prices up to the new benchmark of $21 a barrel by year's end.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Dives, Share Prices Rise Back
DOC.TEXT: The dollar opened sharply lower against the Japanese yen Tuesday morning in Tokyo as share prices quickly rebounded on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar opened at 146.30 yen, down 1.17 yen from Monday's 147.47-yen close. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average rose 585.49 points, or 2.24 percent, to 26,775.96 in the first 30 minutes of early trading. The index declined 296.25 points Monday, closing at 26,490.47. The currency's decline in early Tokyo trading followed a similar downswing in New York. The dollar's drop was mainly due to active sales of the German mark against the yen, said a Bank of Tokyo dealer who spoke on condition of anonymity. But the dollar slowed its decline near the 146-yen level because some investors who were reaping profits had bought at that level, dealers said. Weakness in the German mark resulted from the collapse of the Social Democratic coalition government in East Germany, dealers said. The dollar was stronger against other major currencies in New York. In New York, the dollar closed at 146.51 yen on Monday, down from 147.60 yen late Friday. Traders attributed the Nikkei's early strength to active buying by investors who had been encouraged by recovery of the yen against the dollar and by firm New York stocks. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 8.00 percent from Monday's 8.030-percent finish. Their price rose to 83.46 points from 83.33.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Convicts Pilots of Flying While Under Influence of Alcohol
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 9th graf pvs, `U.S. District...,' to UPDATE with one defendant's planning to appeal. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MP2
DOC.TEXT: A jury Monday convicted three former Northwest Airlines pilots of flying while intoxicated, rejecting defense claims that the smoothness of the 91-passenger flight proved they were not impaired. The convictions were the first under a 1986 federal law cracking down on drinking and drug use in commercial transportation, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Elizabeth de la Vega. ``The impact of the trial was more than the verdict,'' she said. ``With the attention it's been given for months, it's had an impact on pilots.'' The felony convviction carries a maximum 15 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. However, de la Vega said sentencing guidelines called for prison terms of 12 to 18 months. ``I came into this expecting the worst, so in that sense I had no surprise,'' said former Capt. Norman Lyle Prouse, who testified he drank up to 20 rum and Diet Cokes at a lounge the night before Flight 650 left Fargo, N.D., on March 8. The Boeing 727 landed safely at the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, where the pilots were arrested. A customer who argued with one of the pilots at the lounge had reported them to the Federal Aviation Administration. Prouse, 51, of Conyers, Ga.; 1st Officer Robert Kirchner, 36, of Highland Ranch, Colo.; and flight engineer Joseph Balzer, 35, of Antioch, Tenn., each were convicted of one count of operating a common carrier while under the influence of alcohol or drugs. U.S. District Judge James Rosenbaum ordered a presentence investigation and released the defendants on their own recognizance. William Mauzy, attorney for Kirchner, said he would appeal. Balzer's attorney, Bruce Hanley, declined to comment, and Peter Wold, Prouse's lawyer, said he was considering an appeal. A waitress at the Speak Easy lounge in Moorhead, Minn., adjacent to Fargo, testified that Prouse fell as he left the bar at about 11:30 p.m. and returned to get directions to his hotel, which was about three blocks away. Balzer and Kirchner shared at least six pitchers of beer and left the bar about an hour before Prouse, according to testimony. The plane left at 6:30 the next morning. Prouse, an acknowledged alcoholic who entered a treatment program after his arrest, said he had little hope of flying again. Balzer was more optimistic. ``It's kind of hard to keep a good pilot on the ground,'' Balzer said. ``That's kind of like asking Picasso if he were going to paint again.'' The federal law against flying under the influence of alcohol doesn't define drunkenness as a specific blood-alcohol level, as do many state drunken-driving laws. However, it suggests that a pilot with a blood-alcohol content of 0.1 percent would be impaired. The law, adopted in 1986 and amended in 1988, also applies to those controling commercial boats, trains and passenger-carrying buses. In tests about two hours after the plane landed, Prouse had a blood-alcohol concentration of 0.13 percent, Kirchner's was 0.06 percent and Balzer's was 0.08 percent. Defense lawyers argued that the smoothness of the 40-minute flight proved the pilots were not impaired. But de la Vega questioned whether they could have handled an emergency. Herbert Moskowitz, a behavioral scientist, testified for the prosecution that as little as half a can of beer can cause delayed reactions. A blood-alcohol concentration of just 0.03 percent cause significant impairment, he testified. ``I think it came down to the expert testimony of Dr. Moskowitz,'' the prosecutor said. ``That was the key part of the trial.'' Jurors deliberated about nine hours on the case. Before the law was enacted, pilots were covered only by FAA regulations. Northwest fired all three pilots for drinking within 12 hours of a scheduled flight and the FAA revoked their licenses. The agency forbids pilots from flying within eight hours of drinking or from flying with a blood-alcohol content of 0.04 percent or more. The three also face misdemeanor charges in North Dakota.

DOC.HEAD: Contractors Announce Agreement With Trump
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump has reached an agreement with a group representing about 60 contractors who say the developer owed them $60 million for work on the Taj Mahal casino-hotel, the creditors said Monday. The announcement was made one day before the state Casino Control Commission is scheduled to rule on whether Trump can use the Taj Mahal and his two other casinos as collateral for a $65 million emergency loan. Trump negotiated the loan to allow him to make an overdue bond payment in June on the Trump Castle Casino Resort By The Bay. Marty Rosenberg, a spokesman for a group of seven contractors negotiating with Trump, said an agreement had been reached but did not release details. ``I do not have the particulars of this agreement,'' Rosenberg said at a news conference held at his business, Atlantic Plate Glass, which was among the creditors. ``We will be meeting with the other contractors in the near future,'' he said. Trump already faces at least four lawsuits for money allegedly owed contractors who did roofing, ornamental, metal, fiber glass and steel work on the Taj Mahal. His representatives have said they are auditing all work on the casino to make sure it met their standards. Rosenberg indicated the negotiations had been arduous. ``We have had many, many meetings,'' he said. ``I have been in a rush for a long time to get this finished.'' The news conference began 2{ hours late as negotiators wrapped up the final details, he said. ``If you've ever dealt with Donald Trump, you know he has his own timetable,'' Rosenberg said.
